text:
The epic, or “long heroic song,” is called the nanang in Labin Agta; sugidanon in Karay-a; candu or caranduun in Waray; olaging/ulahing in Bukidnon, Matigsalug, Bagobo, and Manobo; wahingon in Manuvu; bendigan in Livunganen-Arumanen; owaging or dawot in Mandaya; diawot in Mansaka; kata-kata in Sama; and hlolok in Tboli. Many of these terms, which also serve as titles for specific epics, are actually words for “song” or “chant,” such as Guman in Subanon, Darangen in Maranao, Hudhud in Ifugao, and Ulahingan in Manobo.

The epic is a long, narrative poem belonging to the indigenous tradition; it tells of the feats and adventures of an ethnic hero with supernatural powers, in language that is rhythmic and descriptive. This narrative, which is composed of many long episodes involving one hero, is transmitted orally from one bard to another. It is chanted or sung by a especially trained individual or group before a mixed audience during social gatherings convened for weddings, wakes, and other special feasts. Epics are also called ethnoepics not only because they are created by an ethnic group but also because they serve to codify the values of that group, thereby strengthening the basis of unity among members of the group. Philippine epics depict a precolonial society, although they are still very much alive today as their meanings adjust to historical circumstances over the centuries. In Agyu, the antagonists, who are Maguindanao, have taken on the identity of “Moros” (Muslims), although the epic originated in pre-Islamic times. The Dulimaman of the Itneg encapsulates the history of hostilities between the lowland Ilocano and the mountain groups. Here, the protagonist is persecuted by the Ilocano in Paoay, jailed in Laoag despite his innocence, and forced to flee to the mountains of Abra. In some cases, elements from foreign cultures have crept into the epic, as in the Ilocano Lam-ang, whose characters bear Spanish first names and the titles “Don” and “Doña”; the Tboli Tudbulul, in which guns are used; the Tagbanwa Pala’isgen, in which the man-eating tigre (tiger) has replaced the malignant spirit of Tagbanwa cosmology; and the Karay-a Sugidanon, in which a lion’s heart, instead of a white boar’s, holds Saragnayan’s life force.

Epics have a sustained length and an episodic structure. Although many epics have a single story line involving a complex of characters and events, others are composed of several songs, ballads, and chants, thematically interrelated. These songs can be considered sub-epics, constituting an epic cycle. The Ulahingan of the Livunganen-Arumanen, for example, consists of several cycles, each of which is made up of songs revolving around a hero.

The central motif of the hero’s quest varies according to the object of the quest. In the Karay-a Hinilawod, Tagbanwa Kudaman, and Maranao Darangen, it is the quest for a woman, or a series of women. In Sandayo, a variation is that the man’s quest for the woman is paralleled by the woman’s quest for him. In Lam-ang, the hero’s initial quest is for his father before he sets off again to woo Doña Ines Cannoyan. In the Ibaloy Bindian, Cagayan Agta Nanang, Tagbanwa Pala’isgen, Tiruray Berinareu, and Tboli Tudbulul, the quest is in aid of an abducted maiden. In another Tudbulul cycle and a Samarnon Candu, the quest is for a betel chew. At regular intervals during these quests, the heroes, whether male or female, must engage in the requisite battles with mortals or supernatural beings. However, some epics center on battles for their own sake: Aliguyon of the Hudhud revives hostilities between his clan and Pumbakhayon’s because he needs to do battle; and in the epic of Agyu, the hero must go on sea raids to initiate and train the young men of Nalandangan in the ways of war.

Cycles arise from variations in each performance of an epic. Bards may adapt details to suit the contemporary setting; they may add new stories if their listeners want variety; or they may omit the details or entire episodes that they do not recall, and improvise. Agyu of the Arakan-Arumanen is constantly updated with episodes about the adventures of Agyu and his relatives.

Epics are transmitted from one generation to the next by bards, male or female, gifted with a good voice and a capacious memory. This oral transmission has resulted in the proliferation of multiple versions of the same basic story. The epic of Panay, which is called Hinilawod by F. Landa Jocano and Sugidanon by Alice P. Magos, has multiple versions by various chanters. In Jocano’s Labaw Donggon cycle of the Hinilawod epic, Nagmalitung Yawa is the sun god’s wife whom Labaw Donggon takes by force from her husband; but in the Humadapnon cycle of the same epic, Humadapnon is Labaw Donggon’s nephew who woos the solitary woman, Nagmalitung Yawa, with great difficulty. In Alicia P. Magos’s Sugidanon, Nagmalitung Yawa is Labaw Donggon’s daughter; therefore, her husband, Humadapnon, is Labaw Donggon’s son-in-law. Paubari, aka Paiburong, is Labaw Donggon’s father, brother, or brother-in-law in various cycles of the Hinilawod and Sugidanon. In the Nanang of the Labin Agta of Cagayan, Talimanog and Ammani are brothers in one cycle but are brothers-in-law in another. There are characters in the Ulahingan who are brothers in one version but are father and son in another.

 
 
 

Epic chanting or singing usually takes place from sundown to sunrise during communal affairs. Generally, the tales that the bards chant or sing are directed at the entire community. Among the Ilocano and the Kalinga, weddings, rites, and peace-pact agreements called budong occasion the performance of an epic. The performance of an epic adds grandeur to the celebration and memorializes an important event to those in attendance. Most epics are chanted in part during weddings, feasts, and harvests. The excerpts chanted are appropriate to the occasion or celebration. Except among the Ifugao, the singing of an epic is done solo. The performance is often accompanied by musical instruments. The bard Elena Gardoce, while performing the Hinilawod, plays the tambor (drum), the agong (a metal gong), the tultugan (a set of bamboo tubes), and the basal (a rhythmic pounding of the earth by means of two sticks).

 

Epics revolve around supernatural events and heroic deeds deemed to have occurred in some undated past, and deal with relations among mortals in the earth world, and between mortals and the immortals who dwell in the sky world. Supernatural beings such as the diwata (nature spirits) and the anito (ancestral spirits) appear, and natural objects like water, trees, rocks, fire, animals, and fruits (the betel nut is a favorite) acquire magical potencies. They often aid the heroes in their feats. In Tuwaang, the wind is the hero’s messenger; and the lightning, his vehicle. In the Nanang, the messenger bird is a comic figure who wearies of flying from person to person to deliver messages. A thousand betel chews in Agyu transform into maya birds and fly to the injured to heal their wounds and to the dead to revive them.

Cosmology is drawn in varying degrees of detail in the epics. The epic of Tudbulul offers very detailed geographies of its other worlds, which defy human logic. The entrance to these other worlds is through a mountain of iron that can be split open only by a man who possesses not only a kris (or cutlass) a million lakes long but also a pure heart. To the left are eight deep craters of the moon and to the right are deep craters of the sun. Inside the mountain, Tudbulul rides on his flying horse through the Waterfall in the Rain and the Waterfall in the Clouds. He passes by a pair of stars that are also a pair of ebony black trees, and then by a twinkling star sprung from a mountain. He hides inside the moon, which is also a tree root, where he awaits the earthquake that, according to a prophetic dream, will demolish his homeland. He is in front of a tabuan (traditional market place) and a gambling place, where there are singing and the sound of gongs and fighting horses. The leaves carry oceans; tree buds contain lakes. Tudbulul enters Kayung, which is the Red Realm, where those killed violently are sent. At its entrance hang many kulintang (sets of gongs) that are played constantly by the beheaded inhabitants. Those who have died a natural death, such as illness and old age, go to Mount Mogow. The realm of suicides is the Seductive Mountain, where the fruit of the makopa and banana trees, as well as sugarcane, entice men and women to eat them.

On the other hand, the three layers of the universe in the epic of Hinilawod are succinctly defined by the stock epithets of Labaw Donggon’s three wives: Abyang Ginbitinan, “who lives by the mouth of Handug by the river Halawod”; Abyang Doronoon, “of the Underworld”; and Nagmalitung Yawa, “in the land of the morning sun where bright light began.”

Epics have great entertainment value because they vividly evoke scenes through the power of language. Whether read in printed form or listened to as it is delivered orally, the epic possesses the literary qualities of cadence and symmetry, parallelism and alliteration. Ulahingan contains 800 lines of meticulous description of the landscape, the beauty and elegance of the city, the buildings whose pillars require several men linking arms to embrace them, the scenes of dancing ladies attired in gold, the beams carved in the shape of crocodile mouths. Hyperbole is a distinctive feature of the epics, in the description of the passing of time and of the forces of nature, for example. In the Ifugao Hudhud, the battle between Aliguyon and Pumbakhayon starts when the girls they eventually marry are but babies slung on their mothers’ backs. Saplings grow into trees at the same time as the dueling boys grow to be men. On the other hand, the seemingly exaggerated description of the giant sweep of water that snatches Tudbulul and drowns him in the navel of the sea may have its realistic basis in the natural disaster currently known as a tsunami.

Hyperboles may also be read as myths embedded in the epics explaining the origin of natural forces and formations. In Labaw Donggon, it is said that whenever an earthquake occurs, it is Saragnayan’s body falling to earth with a thud when he is killed by Baranugun in a battle, because “the earthquake is kept in Saragnayan’s body” (Ulang Udig [1963] 2011, 91). In Agyu, the giant python swallowing all the people of Nalandangan in the dead of night is identical to the mythical bakunawa, a giant python that swallows the moon when an eclipse occurs.

It is often remarked by academics that the repetition of basic words and phrases also serves as a mnemonic or memory device for the bard. However, the epic convention of repetition serves a more meaningful function than as a mere aid to memory. In the Ifugao Hudhud, for instance, the duels between Aliguyon and Pumbakhayon are told twice in exactly the same words although the settings differ: the first duel occurs in Pumbakhayon’s village, the second in Aliguyon’s. The prolonged fight ends in a draw, as foreshadowed by the repetition of the lines depicting their fighting skills. Similarly, Labaw Donggon in the Hinilawod epic makes exactly the same elaborate preparations three times for his courtship of the three maidens. The same degree of respect that he accords all three wives will afterward satisfy them that he speaks the truth when he promises them that he will care for them all equally.

Being an ancient collective heritage, epics possess a gravity of intent unaccorded to other forms of folk literature. In them are enshrined the belief and value systems of the community, although these may be conveyed in a humorous or satirical fashion. Epics codify and transmit customs and norms involving different aspects of life, such as courtship and marriage, household management and child-rearing. This function of the epic is illustrated in Hudhud hi Aliguyon (Hudhud of Aliguyon), which suggests that marriage between members of warring tribes can put an end to feuds.

Wars are also resolved when a diwata of peace descends to earth to tell the warriors they are relatives. In the various related epics of the Manobo, the diwata of peace may function as comic relief: his nap is disturbed by the war down below, so he comes down from the sky world, hits the warriors on the head, and scolds them before telling them they have the same father or a common ancestor. Tudbulul and Datu Lobun are bent on killing each other because Tudbulul has tried to steal the other’s wife. But Tudbulul’s exiled uncle appears and tells them that Datu Lobun is his son; hence Tudbulul’s first cousin. A wife, he says, is only a head of hair, but a fight between kin brings a curse down upon the whole clan. The datu placatingly offers his wife to Tudbulul in exchange for Tudbulul’s horse and gongs. In Pala’isgen, five warring heroes solicitously examine each other for injuries after the Maiden of the Isle sends her bee to tell them they are brothers. Then they merrily return home together.

On occasion, Philippine epic heroes utter expressions of extreme self-deprecation as a requisite of good manners. The Guman of Sandayo has a wealth of ritualistic speeches of deprecation, beginning with Sandayo’s father describing his son as “an ugly child.” Drinking sessions are preceded by ritualistic praise of the liquor, worded ironically thus: “The rice wine tastes terrible,” says the datu, shaking his head, “and more sour than the tartest fruit.” When a villager exclaims in admiration of Sandayo’s noble bearing, a lowly slave counters the curse that might fall upon Sandayo by cautioning the admirer against such explicit praise. The taboo against boasting is why, when Labaw Donggon’s mortal father in the Hinilawod grandly promises to build “a very big house with 10 rooftops and a hundred doors” for his prospective daughter-in-law, he is a comic figure, especially because it is, after all, only the demigod Labaw Donggon who can, and does, perform this feat. Sincere humility may also be necessary so that the hero may not fatally overestimate himself. Banna in the Ullalim mutters to himself twice that he fears the giant he is tasked to kill, but in the next line he is victoriously holding the giant’s severed head.

Discretion is allowed to be the better part of valor when indomitable enemies invade an epic hero’s territory. Talimanog, the hero of the Nanang, invites their traditional enemy, the Kalinga headhunters, into his family home and apologizes for its “pitiful seats.” Kudaman, the Tagbanwa epic hero, calmly invites the dreaded Ilanun into his home when they come to abduct his wives. At the same time, however, these heroes show a readiness to fight should their attempts at diplomacy fail. Talimanog holds his spear and shield but keeps it out of sight as he welcomes the enemy in. When the Ilanun reject Kudaman’s courteous gesture, he duels with the Ilanun leader for so long that they penetrate the several levels of the cosmos.

A hero’s tragic flaw, or error in judgment, may stem from the quandary of his having to break a rule of right conduct so as to remain true to his heroic quest. On the one hand, to behave badly is to bring cosmic punishment upon oneself; on the other, to deviate from one’s destiny is to bring ruin to his clan’s name, including that of his descendants down through all generations. This is what Dumalapdap repeatedly reminds his brother, Humadapnon, in the Hinilawod. Humadapnon is admirable for his determination to stay true to his quest for the maiden of his dreams; nevertheless, he must be punished for refusing, no matter how politely, a binukot’s invitation for him to drop in on her island. This becomes the crux of the story, because the maiden who is the object of his quest is now forced to come to his rescue. Thus, his punishment for breaking a code of conduct unexpectedly brings about the success of his quest. On the other hand, in the Subanon Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan (The Country of Keboklagan), Datu Timoway causes his own death and of his ship’s crew after he rejects the invitation of the storm goddess Diwata Pegderaman to tarry awhile.

The motif of the abduction of maidens in the Philippine epic tradition may be realistically explained by the existence of the “well-kept maiden,” who is called “binukot” in the Visayas, “buyan” in Mindanao, and “alimban” in northern Luzon. The binukot (literally, “wrapped up”), as described in early Spanish chronicles, was a datu’s favored daughter, who was kept closely guarded in her room. Her feet were not to touch the earth, and thus she was borne on the shoulders of male slaves, or carried on a hammock. Considered a grave crime deserving of dire punishment was for a man to pass by, wittingly or not, while a binukot was in her bath. Thus, what is thought to be a “stock epithet”—“the well-kept maiden”—as it is read in the English translation of an epic, may actually be the literal designation for a type of woman in Philippine indigenous society. A binukot of the contemporary period is Elena Gardoce, chanter of the sugidanon, aka Hinilawod, and recipient of the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 1992.

In the Sama Silungan Baltapa, the buyan is alluded to when Silungan’s mother wishes to keep him under his seven-layered gauze canopy all his life to shield him from the sun, the dew, and seawater; and Silungan protests that only maidens should be thus sheltered to enhance their beauty in preparation for a suitor. In Agyu, the goddess of weaving and embroidery guards the door of the buyan’s pina-iyak (room) against men, including male relatives. The Mandaya Yang Mangngagaw (The Taking by Force) gives a detailed description of the architecture of a datu’s house, where one must traverse a virtual obstacle course to reach a buyan’s digpi (room), only to be barred from it by her spirit guardian keeping vigilance at the door.

 

Living in the confines of her room or tower does not inevitably make a binukot frail and demure. Looking out of her window, she might espy the handsome, young hero and initiate the courtship, which might begin with a battle of wits and escalate into a battle of magic powers. In Tudbulul, the binukot sends a challenge to Tudbulul through her cloud messengers to fetch her a special betel nut. There now follows an exchange of demands between her and Tudbulul until she finally comes down to his territory as he so demands. In the Darangen, the princess sends her maid to invite the hero to her tower and be her sweetheart. There follows a duel of magic powers between the hero and the princess. She imprisons him in a boulder near the balete tree. He sends the same boulder to envelop her tower. She shatters the boulder into pebbles, which rain down on him, and she adds a wall of fire to encage him, but he quickly sends this flaming prison to her tower. She produces a balete tree on either side of him and crowns him with a boulder. In a gesture of surrender, the hero walks to her tower to ask her for a betel chew, but his ridiculous appearance is greeted with laughter from onlookers. Humiliated, he causes a grove of trees to stand on either side of her tower and an orange tree to grow on her head. The desperate pair finally call on their mountain-sized, guardian crocodiles to continue the duel in their place.

A binukot fetches a high bride-price, or dowry, this being sometimes so unattainable as to make the abduction of the maiden the only recourse for a suitor. In the Maranao Darangen, the bride-price consists, in part, of Manobo slaves as many as leaves of grass in the courtyard; sheets of cloth with colors and kinds as numerous as leaves on the trees; a carabao the size and weight of the boulder in the bay; sand of gold paving the village courtyard and streets; the reversal of the river current from its mouth to its source; and a pair of trees with “leaves of precious gems and with talking birds in them” (McKaughan 1995, 183). In this case, although the suitor grandly fulfills these demands with his magic powers, he wonders if, perhaps elsewhere, there might be some unfortunate “well-kept maiden” forced to grow old and decrepit before her suitor could produce the bride-price.

On the other hand, a clever binukot could well use the practice of bride-price negotiations to make herself deliberately unattainable. In a Samarnon (or Waray) candu, Datong Somangga and Bubu nga Humayanun (aka Huamianun), the reluctant binukot sends the datu on several quests for the various ingredients of the betel chew, the sources of which become increasingly dangerous. The series of quests begins in Samar’s neighboring islands of Camiguin, and then moves on to Mindanao, to China, and finally to heaven, where he must obtain a flash of lightning for her.

The enumeration of items composing the bride-price is an example of the epic convention of the catalog of names of persons or objects. Genealogy is another example, such as that in the Darangen. In the Tiruray Berinareu, the names of the eight datus who abduct the maiden are later matched by another set of names of eight datus who come to her rescue under the leadership of the hero. One of the most enchanting catalogs of names in world literature is that in the Ulahingan, in which the enumeration of each plant, tree, and stone in the forest of Nalandangan is matched by the sound of an indigenous musical instrument it is said to make: the kutyapi, kudlong, and buntung (three types of bamboo guitars), the pulala (flute), and vocal chanting, as well as the rustling of grass blades and the whistling of stones. Thus, the forest of Nalandangan is also a symphony orchestra with a human chorus.

 

Epics of the Philippines

To date, only about 30 epics have been recorded, published, or translated out of supposedly over a hundred. The Cordilllera peoples in northern Luzon have the Dulimaman of the Itneg, aka Tinguian, Ullalim of the Kalinga, Alim and Hudhud of the Ifugao, and Biwag anni Malanda of the Gaddang. In southern Luzon: Handiong of the Bikol. In Palawan, Pala’isgen of the Tagbanwa and Kudaman of Palawan. In the Visayas, the Karay-a Hinilawod and the Sugidanon of Panay, of which two cycles, Tikung Kadlum, and Amburukay, have been published and translated to contemporary Karay-a, Filipino, and English. In Mindanao, Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan, Keg Sumba neg Sandayo (Life of Sandayo) and Guman of the Subanon, Agyu of the Arakan-Arumanen, Ulahingan of the Livunganen-Arumanen, Tuwaang and Tulalang of the Manuvu/Manobo, Yang Mangngagaw of the Mandaya, Silungan Baltapa of the Sama, Ulod of the Matigsalug, Manggob of the Mansaka, Tudbulul of the Tboli, and Darangen of the Maranao. Summaries have been made of Kanag Kababagowan of the Itneg; Bindian of the Ibaloy; Datong Somangga and Bubu nga Humayanun (aka Huamianun) of the Samarnon (aka Waray); Cabungao and Bubu nga Ginbuna also of the Samarnon; and Dumaracol of the Tagbanwa.

 

The exact origins of the Ilocano epic Biag ni Lam-ang have not been fully established. Thus far, six versions of the epic exist; old men still recite fragments of the epic in the style of the dallot (a poetic debate between the sexes). Vested with supernatural powers, Lam-ang searches for his father, whom he has seen in a dream being killed by Igorot warriors, the traditional enemies of the lowland Ilocano. With magical weapons, Lam-ang wipes out a band of Igorot. Then, he wins the hand of Doña Ines Kannoyan. In his last adventure, Lam-ang goes out in search of the rarang, a big clam, but instead, he is swallowed by the giant fish berkakan. His pet rooster, however, resurrects him after his bones are recovered.

The Dulimaman is in the Itneg language of Inlaud, which is spoken in certain towns of Ilocos Norte and Ilocos Sur. The title of the epic refers to a very elite class of Itneg society believed to have supernatural powers. Thus, the principal characters of this epic are dulimaman. The epic, as recorded, consists of 13 songs, two of which have been published and three, summarized. One summarized song, “Si Babey a Dulimaman” (The Maiden Dulimaman), is about an alimban, “well-kept maiden,” who sneaks out of confinement to bathe in the river. Strands of Ligi Wadagan’s hair from upstream cling to her belly and make her pregnant. When her brother discovers her with a baby, he calls for a say-ang (communal feast) to compel the father to own up. Ligi Wadagan comes disguised as a monkey, but his baby daughter recognizes him instantly. The brother strips Babey of all her beads and sends her and her daughter away with Ligi. But Ligi is a dulimaman, and so he sends his betel nut to invite everyone, including Babey’s brother, to a betrothal ritual. The dowry negotiations are easily settled, with Ligi providing several jars of gold and precious beads

Another Itneg epic is Kanag Kababagowan, consisting of narratives collectively referred to as “stories of the first times.” These are woven around the events in the places known as Kadalayapan and Kaodanan in some imagined distant past. These places are inhabited by mythical creatures, spirit-birds, spirit helpers, monsters and giants, and magical betel nuts. The principal characters are the goddess Apo-ni-Bulinayen, a mortal-turned-divinity Apo-ni-Tulau, and their son Kanag.

The Ullalim is the epic of the Kalinga of northern Luzon. Recorded and published by Father Lambrecht, CICM, and Father Billiet, CICM, it is actually a series of ballads recounting the fantastic deeds of the Kalinga heroes such as the lovers Banna and Laggunawa. The heroic songs of the northern Kalinga are called gassumbi, the hero of which is Gawan. Among the western Kalinga, they are called dangdang-ay, the hero of which is Magliya or Cono. However, only the Ullalim is still being sung. In one song, “The Heroic Exploits of Banna,” Laggunawa sends her lovers Banna and Dungdunan on a kayaw (headhunt). Banna succeeds in slaying the inhabitants of Bibbila while a giant and a powerful warrior, his rival, idle, thinking that Banna will not succeed. Banna wins Laggunawa’s hand, but Dungdungan marries Banna’s sister. In a song later recorded by Ernesto Constantino, Laggunawa sends Banna off to fetch her a giant’s head. A series of misfortunes takes him to an enemy village, where he marries Gassinu. The song ends with the resumption of the traditional enmity between the two villages because of Banna’s marriages to the two women.

The two epics of the Ifugao are Alim and Hudhud. The Alim is religious and is chanted; the Hudhud is secular and is sung. Not intended for the general public, the Alim is performed for the dead or for the sick and their relatives. The Alim is also performed as a part of certain religious observances, like the installation of the hagabi (a large, rough-hewn ceremonial bench carved out of a single piece of wood deep in the forest). In every village where the bearers of the hagabi rest, the Alim is chanted. It is chanted again when the hagabi is finally placed underneath its owner’s house. Similarly, the Alim is performed when the bulol (squat wooden sculptures depicting the rice god Wigan and rice goddess Bugan) are installed. The bulol are bought from expert Ifugao wood-carvers; a kanyaw/cañao (grand feast) is held in the village. When the bulol has been installed in the granaries to assure abundance, the mombaki (spiritual leader) chants the epic.

In contrast, the Hudhud is sung during most social festivities, including weddings and funerals, but especially during harvest. The epic has several versions recounting the marvelous deeds of Aliguyon from Hananga, who vanquishes the enemies of his people, earning glory for himself and for his tribe. Hudhud hi Aliguyon, recorded by Amador Daguio, relates Aliguyon’s combat with his archfoe Pumbakhayon. Aliguyon goes to Pumbakhayon’s place and challenges him to a duel. The two hurl spears at each other, observed by the villagers including Pumbakhayon’s mother. They only stop to eat. The seesaw battle lasts for one and a half years. Aliguyon returns to Hananga, but Pumbakhayon and his followers bring the war there. Another battle ensues, lasting for a year and a half, broken only by the periodic announcement by Dangunay, Aliguyon’s mother, that it is time to eat. After several rounds of combat, the two warriors agree to end the feud. Wine jars are opened; betel nuts, shared. Aliguyon marries Bugan, Pumbakhayon’s sister; Pumbakhayon marries Aginaya, Aliguyon’s sister.

The epic of the Gaddang people of Nueva Vizcaya and Isabela is Biwag anni Malana (Biwag and Malana), a written version of which is in 78 stanzas of seven lines each, by F. G. Soriano, and published, with English translation, in 1984. The title characters are maternal first cousins and demigods: Biwag is the son of the earth god Bunag and the Princess Beling of Sumatra; Malana is the son of the sea god Limat and Princess Casta, also of Sumatra. The two princesses are banished by their mother, the queen of Sumatra, together with their sons. Landing in Aparri, they are adopted by the Gaddang. Biwag and Malana later prove themselves heroes when they lead the Gaddang to victory against the Ilongot, the tribe’s traditional enemy, and they also slay a giant. The Gaddang, led by the cousins, win more battles.

The Ibaloy of Benguet have Bindian, a fragment of which is included in a manuscript, dated 1948, in the personal collection of E. Arsenio Manuel. The text is in Ibaloy verse, with an English translation. The hero Bindian tries to rescue the goddess Bugan from the clutches of the sky god Kabuniyan. Kabuniyan decapitates him, but Bugan brings him back to life. The enraged Kabuniyan rains fire and brimstone, boiling water and ash at the earth. When Bindian yields, Kabuniyan spares him; but Bugan, who persists in eluding Kabuniyan, turns into a waterfall. Bindian marries a snake-turned-woman but continues to yearn for Bugan.

Although of dubious provenance, Handiong is considered by the Bikol to be their epic, although only fragments of it now survive. These were first transcribed and translated into Spanish by Fr Bernardino de Melendreras and later included by Fr Jose Castaño in his book on the Bikol. The epic was translated into Dutch by Hendrik Kern, from which came the English translation made by A. V. H. Hartendorp and H. Otley Beyer in 1920. Jose Calleja-Reyes and MeritoB.Espinas translated these back into Bikol. The epic recounts how Handiong kills different monsters, including a monocular beast, a winged tiburon (shark), a wild buffalo, huge crocodiles, and snakes. It also celebrates Handiong’s domestic contributions, such as the invention of the plow and harrow. Stories about other inventors and heroes are included in the epic, as are accounts of great upheavals.

The Palawan epic Kudaman, as recorded, takes seven nights to perform. The hero Kudaman remains a child all throughout, but incorporates in his being the three ages of man: infancy, adulthood, and wise old age. As he journeys to faraway climes in the Palawan universe, and fights the forces of the aggressive Ilanun led by Apo Tugbu, Kudaman accumulates 10 wives. The entire context of the narrative is the ceremonial drinking of tabad (ritual rice beer). As the story of Kudaman and his wives unfolds, the bard also gives an account of Palawan social ethics, concepts of love and harmony, and peaceable attitudes toward the outsider, no matter how invasive.

The epic of the Kalmianen Tagbanwa of the towns of Taytay, El Nido, and Linapacan in southern Palawan is Dumaracol. Only fragments of it so far have been intermittently recorded, amounting to a total of 8 hours and 40 minutes of chanting; and notes on it published. The epic is about the singlehanded battles of Dumaracol, aka Iwananen and Ulgan, with the Lingagan, or Muslim marauders. Dumaracol is the eldest son of a wealthy trading partner of the Moros. He is born dark, whereas his four younger siblings are fair skinned. Nevertheless, it is Dumaracol, bedecked in gold, who possesses supernatural powers. Whenever Moros raid their territory, he pursues them either on a large ship with 10 sails and in the company of numerous warriors, or he walks on a bridge of rainbows to reach the fleeing Moros on their fleet of prahu, or vintas. However, Dumaracol always fights the Moros alone. From either his ship or rainbow, he jumps onto the Moro prahu one by one, which sinks under his weight. The Moros are forced to swim toward the shore, where Dumaracol kills them all while his two brothers are rescuing the abducted women from the sinking prahu.

It is, however, Limbonganen, the woman who captures his heart, who becomes his undoing. He pays court to Limbonganen but, receiving only contempt from her and her sisters because of his dark skin, Dumaracol kills himself. His parents place him in a white casket, which they let float on the sea. A pananankan (shaman) finds the floating casket and restores Dumaracol back to life. In the end, Dumaracol does win the hand of Limbonganen.

A third epic of Palawan is Pala’isgen, of which seven songs of varying lengths have been published with a Tagalog translation. Pala’isgen is a demigod, who resides in the heavens but whose father lives by the sea. He is the third of four brothers, the youngest of whom, Liokyangan, is his constant companion. Riding on his flying, gold biday (ship), he looks down at the war-torn earth and commands it to let peace reign. He marries Tubod kat Bulawan and impresses her father and people with his supernatural powers and his house with gold interiors. Then he must rescue his wife from seven human-eating giants. He succeeds with the help of an old man in a dream, a small crab, a wise bird, and a bee. The seventh, and last, song is also the longest: Pala’isgen goes in quest of his father in the land of the monster Tigre. Finding his father’s head adorning Tigre’s window, Pala’isgen engages in a long battle with the monster. In the meantime, Pala’isgen’s brothers and his brother-in-law, led by Baybayanen, start a search for him. The brothers are thrown apart at sea when the angry Daragat Pungtudanen (Maiden of the Isle) sends a typhoon because Baybayanen has refused her offer of tobacco and betel chew. Pala’isgen and his brother-in-law meet but, not recognizing each other, they fight. A messenger bee stops the fight. All the brothers unite to defeat Tigre but it takes years before Pala’isgen finally kills him. On their way home, they do battle with another man, whom the messenger bee reveals to be their brother. They all fly home, except Baybayanen, who decides to travel home by sea.

Hinilawod is the epic of the Karay-a Bukidnon people of Panay in western Visayas. It consists of two cycles: Labaw Donggon and the longer Humadapnon. Versions of each vary. The first cycle relates the exploits of Labaw Donggon, one of the three sons of a diwata and a mortal. He easily acquires himself two wives, but his luck changes when he feels compelled to marry Malitung Yawa Sinagmaling Diwata, who is already the wife of Saragnayan, lord of the arc of the sun. Labaw fights Saragnayan, but because Saragnayan’s life force is kept inside a pig’s body, Labaw cannot kill him. After many years of fighting, Labaw falters. Saragnayan imprisons him underneath his house. However, Labaw’s sons—Asu Mangga and Buyung Baronogon—rescue him and defeat Saragnayan with the help of their ancestors.

In the second cycle, Humadapnon is Labaw’s nephew. He searches for Tubigon Daligan-Umis Kuyam-isan, whom he has seen in his dream. Accompanied by his brother Dumalapdap, he fights Mamang Mangalayo and Dumadakang Dagat, Tubigon Daligan-Umis Kuyamisan’s husband. The brothers are assisted by their cousins Buyung Baronogon and Padanong Palinti. Because it is ultimately Baronogon who kills Mangalayo, he gets the wife. Baronogon, however, agrees to give Humadapnon his sister Malitung Yawa. The brothers part ways, each eventually acquiring his own wife. Then, they help their cousin rescue their uncle, Labaw Donggon, imprisoned by Mamang Magtangub. The last episode concerns the rescue by Malitung Yawa of her husband Humadapnon, bewitched by the binukot with supernatural powers.

The principal characters of the Sugidanon Series: Epics of Panay, transcribed and translated under the supervision of Alicia P. Magos, are Labaw Donggon (aka Abaw), his wife Matang-ayon (aka Ayon), and their daughter Malitong Yawa (Mali); Humadapnon, Mali’s husband and Labaw Donggon’s son-in-law; Humadapnon’s younger brother, Dumalapdap, and his wife, Kinangay; Mali’s mother, the goddess Laonsina; and Abaw’s father, Paubari or Paiburong (alternatively, his brother-in-law and brother). The brothers’ antagonists are the human-eating monster, Makabagting; Paglambuhan, the aswang who is Humadapnon’s rival for Mali’s hand in marriage; and Abaw’s various rivals for possession of Ayon: Balanakon, Sinagnayan, Masangladon of the undersea world, and Pahagunon of the upper world. Other characters are Tikum Kadlum, an enchanted hunting dog; Amburukay, a muwa (female hermit) with gold pubic hair; Sarandihon of the sky world and gatekeeper of the Bangga-an River; Kalampay, a magic crab; Luyong Kabig, archdeity of the undersea world; Panday (ironsmith) Katnub Magkaruruan, Abaw’s brother-in-law; and Datu Panlinugon and Makapunaw, Sinagnayan’s parents.

The Samarnon, aka Waray, are known to have had at least two candu, only summaries of which now remain as written down by Jesuit missionary Francisco Alcina in 1623. “Cabungao and Bubu nga Ginbuna” is the story of Cabungao’s quest for his wife after he comes home from a pangayaw (slave raid) and finds her gone. He learns she is in self-exile on an islet because she has been treated shabbily by his own mother and sister. There follows a large gap in the narrative because Alcina leaves out “many details and particular episodes so as not to prolong” it (Alcina [1668] 1960, 271). Cabungao makes three attempts, which are fraught with untold dangers, to reach Bubu. The reunited couple stay together on the island that they name Natunawan (melted or fused), which bespeaks of their love for each other.

 

 
 
 

The Subanon of the Zamboanga peninsula in western Mindanao have three recorded epics: Ag Tobig nog Keboklagan, Guman, and Keg Sumba neg Sandayo. Recorded by Gaudiosa Ochotorena, the first is a sweeping, violence-filled tale about the life and valorous exploits of Taake of Sirangan. His successful courtship of Lady Pintawan of Keboklagan in the navel of the sea ignites a series of wars between Sirangan and Keboklagan. The Supreme Being Asog, bothered by the widespread death and destruction caused by the wars, intercedes. The people hold a buklog (thanksgiving feast).

Guman is the generic term for the Subanon epic, but it has been customary to use it as the title for one Subanon epic, recorded by Esterlinda Mendoza Malagar, relating the beginnings of the Subanon kingdom of Dumalinao. Ruled by Datu Pombnwa of Mount Dliyagn and Datu Manongaling of Mount Paktologon, Dumalinao is invaded by the forces of three queens: Bae Kindagaw, Bae Salompatay, and Bae Ginoonon. The children of the two chieftains defeat the evil spirits led by the three queens. A buklog is celebrated afterward, and the two datus finally fulfill their plan of having their sons and daughters united in marriage.

Keg Sumba neg Sandayo also describes an ancient kingdom frequently threatened by invaders. Sandayo, the son of Bae Salaong and Datu Salaria of Liyasan, is born from his mother’s hair. When he matures, he attends the grand buklog in Lumanay with Datu Daugbolawan. There, he develops an affair with Bae Bolak Sonday and engages a rival datu in a duel which lasts for years. Asog, the Supreme Being, intervenes and reveals that the two are long-lost brothers. Later, Sandayo falls ill and dies. But Bolak Sonday finds his spirit and revives him. When Bolak Sonday wounds herself and dies, Sandayo looks for her spirit and resurrects her.

The epic of the Maranao, who are located in the Lanao provinces, is the Darangen. Seventeen songs have been recorded, mostly about the lives and deeds of ancient heroes and heroines representing the royalty of old mythical Maranao kingdoms. One of the most celebrated characters in the complex genealogy of Darangen heroes, heroines, and nobility is Bantugen, a great warrior who conquers kingdoms and who wins a good number of women whom he brings home to his native kingdom of Bembaran. The songs “How Bantugen Died below the Mountain-by-the-Sea” and “How Bantugen Came Back from Heaven” deal with Bantugen’s exploits. Bantugen dies after displeasing his brother, the king of Bembaran, for having courted Babali Anonan. His soul is placed in a bottle, but a warrior named Mabaning releases his soul; Bantugen lives again. Meanwhile, enemies attack, having heard that Bantugen has died. But the resurrected hero leads his people to victory. Later, having fully regained his strength, he sails on a ship to other lands where he finds his wives: Maginar, Princess Minoyod, Princess Maginawan, Princess Timbang, Bolontai a Pisigi. Apart from them, he attracts 40 other women. With his company of princesses and ladies, he sails back to Bembaran, warmly welcomed by his people.

 

The Arakan-Arumanen, aka Ilianon, and the Livunganen-Arumanen of North Cotabato share a common hero: Agyu, variously spelled Agio, Agyo, Aguio. The word for epic among these peoples is ulahing, olaging, or ulahingan, consisting of two parts: the kepu-unpu-un or account of the events leading to Agyu and his relatives’ ascencion to heaven, and sengedurug or stories about the adventures of Agyu and his relatives since then. Whereas the kepu-unpu-un is a standard narrative, sengedurug after sengedurug can be composed, and this accounts for the cycles revolving around different kinsfolk of Agyu. The epics revolving around Agyu and his relatives depart from the usual pattern of a hero on a voyage to search for a woman (or women) to become his wife. The main objective of the hero’s exploits in this epic is the defense of the homeland, equated with the very survival of the tribe.

The Ulahingan is the epic of the Livunganen-Arumanen of North Cotabato. This epic has been published in five volumes, the first of which contains four versions of the kepu-unpu-un, or history of Agyu and his people, and one sengedurug, or narrative episode titled “The Visit of Lagabaan to Nalandangan.” This episode recounts the invasion of Nalandangan by an elderly king and the battle with the use of magical weapons, such as an iron rod with a deadly aim, shields that grow as big as mountains to form a protective cliff, and a sipa that is a ball from the sky to encase the enemy. The hero is Agyu’s brother Lena/Lono. On the other hand, Agyu is the epic of the Arakan-Arumanen. Recorded by E. Arsenio Manuel, it recounts how Agyu and his clan escape from Muslim bondage and then how Agyu’s son Tanagyaw defends his kinsfolk from invaders. He also helps the people of Baklayon against its enemies.

 

Other epics center on Matabagka, Agyu’s sister, and Baybayan, Agyu’s son, reputed to be the first to chant an ulahing. The Banlakon celebrates the heroism of Agyu’s brother Banlak. Tulelangan centers on the adventures of Tulalang, Agyu’s cousin. In the version recorded by Hazel Wrigglesworth, the hero kills a giant eagle and a dragon in whose heart is kept the life-breath of a band of robbers. Like many Agyu epics, Tulelangan also has an account of the ascension to heaven.

Tulalang is also identified as the hero of the Manuvu, who inhabit the boundary areas of Cotabato, Bukidnon, and Davao: Tuwaang. Tuwaang is performed as entertainment during wakes, weddings, thanksgiving rituals for bountiful harvests, visits by relatives and friends, successful hunts, or in the settlement of disputes. Two songs in the Tuwaang cycle are Tuwaang and the Maiden of the Buhong Sky and Tuwaang Attends a Wedding. In the first song, Tuwaang saves a maiden from her gigantic, jilted suitor, the Young Man from Pangumanon. With his spittle, Tuwaang resurrects the persons that the giant has killed. He brings the maiden to his homeland and there fights another enemy. He and his countryfolk ride a boat to heaven. In the second song, he attends a wedding, only to become the groom when the Young Man of Sakadna fails to pay the bride-price. He subdues the Young Man of Sakadna and takes the bride to his home.

The Matigsalug in Davao have Ulod, a collection of songs on the exploits of the hero Ulod. Ulod meets the Maiden of Misimalun Mountain, working in the datu’s rice fields. Ulod’s sister is abducted by the Young Man from Buttalakkan. Ulod challenges him and wins his sister back. He turns her into a comb which he inserts in his hair and imprisons his opponent’s sister in his locket. When he visits the Maiden of Misimalun Mountain, she returns his love. He rides an air boat with his people to heaven after they have all chewed the betel nut of immortality.

The diawot are the epics of the Mansaka, who reside in the provinces of Davao del Norte, Davao Oriental, and Compostela Valley. Manggob, composed of about 15 episodes, recounts the adventures of Manggob who, like many other epic heroes, is amorous and adventurous. Separated from his parents when he is still an infant, Manggob returns to his community after being raised by a giant. His brother accepts him only after a combat in which Manggob subdues him. Manggob fights the Subanon to retrieve his top and the Conogcogan who have abducted his sisters. A tribal war erupts when Manggob steals the bride of Tibay. The gods, however, intervene and restore peace.

Dawot, owaging, or hullobation is the term for “epic” among the Mandaya, who are located in Davao Oriental, Davao del Sur, and Surigao del Sur. A fragment of Gambong Panguub sang Kabasing (Gambong, Terror of Men) recounts how Gambong, aka “panguub sang kabasing” (terror of the people), fights Diomabok, an equally powerful hero, who has ruined Gambong’s flower Sabullak. A full-length cycle of the dawot is the Yang Mangngagaw, consisting of 2,020 lines, divided into 10 episodes. Sabong of Kadigi desires Sadya of Ullaynun, who has appeared to him in a dream. But she is already betrothed to Ombang of Biyadbadan. With his two brothers, he departs for Ullaynun to win Sadya’s hand. When they arrive in Ullaynun, the marriage negotiations between the eldest brothers of Sadya and of Ombang are in progress. The brothers from Kadigi are warmly welcomed into the Ullaynun home. There is much haggling, drinking, and the ceremonious breaking of wine jars. When the bride-price is settled, Sadya is called from her room, but Sabong grabs his chance and steals a kiss. Amidst Sadya’s weeping and wailing, Sadya’s eldest brother Tibay furiously engages Sabong in battle. Sabong’s brothers, themselves smitten with Tibay’s and Sadya’s other sisters, are unwilling to aid their brother against Tibay. Lipig, the diwata of peace, comes down from earth and reveals to the warriors that they are all brothers from Ullaynun. Thus the story ends. Despite a seemingly action-packed story line, the epic is a treasury of startling imagery and enchanting turns of phrase, such as a description of Sabong’s hair being as thick as a bamboo grove so that only a flute can tame it; and the distance between Kadigi and Ullaynun being the distance between two guitar strings.

The Tiruray, who inhabit the northwestern part of South Cotabato, have Berinareu, the 1989 published version of which was chanted in 1984 by Andao Tinorio Angel, aka Mo Mukas, in Nuro, aka Upi, which is the political center of the Tiruray and located 40 kilometers south of Cotabato City. The epic, which consists of 8,524 lines, begins with the hero, shaman Lagei Lengkuwos, aka Seonomon, explaining to his people that, before they achieve final happiness, they must first undergo teresai (suffering), which consists of the heavy labor of swidden farming. The action of the story begins with Seonomon’s quest for his betrothed, Seangkaien, who has been abducted. After his rescue of Seangkaien, a quarrel between them results in his marriage to another. Seangkaien leads her datu allies into battle against Seonomon’s wife and is victorious, but her betel chew kills Seonomon. She now goes on a quest for Seonomon’s spirit in the afterlife. In the end, Seonomon and Seangkaien together lead their people to the land of final happiness, which is ruled over by the female Supreme Being, Fulufulu.

Silungan Baltapa is the epic of the Sama Bajau, aka Sama Dilaut (Sama of the Ocean), who are from the Zamboanga peninsula and Sulu archipelago. The hero, Silungan Baltapa, marries Dulmata after his sister, Magkapala, kills his rival for Dulmata’s hand, Datu Misil Balan. Magkapala also obtains Dulmata’s bride-price, which is the Tree of Purity in Paradise. When the newlyweds, Silungan and Dulmata, sail home, Magkapala continues to protect them from marauders. Dulmata dies after childbirth, and the grieving Silungan travels through several levels of the afterlife in search of her soul. Reunited in Heaven, the couple return to earth, where Silungan holds the ritual to bring his beloved wife back to life. After one failed attempt, Dalmuta awakens and the family, which includes their son Datu Muhmin, is complete.

Among the Tboli of South Cotabato and Sarangani, the most significant piece of oral literature is Tudbulul, which is sung at weddings from dawn till dusk, sometimes for as long as 16 hours. The five cycles of this epic so far transcribed and translated into Filipino reveal a Tboli cosmology that defies the limits of space and time as they are commonly understood: premonitory dreams with the same literary function as oracles; a ball of fire inside which is a datu on a horse; a messenger comb with 17 precious stones; a flying horse that can transform into a white boulder; a dragon tooth and a snake tooth, which are Tudbulul’s amulets; shields shooting fire and whirlwinds; a valley of tattoos and a forest of finger rings; the navel of the sea; a giant python that gives up its liver and right horn with which to poison Datu Busaw (head of all malignant beings); a deadly datu who sleeps while walking; and the one amulet that guarantees invincibility—a pure heart.

The epics of the Philippines are a recreation of a people’s ancient history elevated to the level of the wondrous and the magical; a living link to age-old practices and customs when they are part of rituals to divinities or commemorations of ancestral spirits; an expression of a collective wish for the mythical golden age or the advent of better times. In short, they are the more or less accurate, though embellished, records or sources of a people’s social institutions, value systems, and historical aspirations. The epics of the Philippines are literary masterpieces that have a distinct place in the canon of world literature.  Written by Edgardo Maranan, E. Arsenio Manuel, and Jonathan Chua, updated by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article.value: The epic is a long, narrative poem belonging to the indigenous tradition; it tells of the feats and adventures of an ethnic hero with supernatural powers, in language that is rhythmic and descriptive. This narrative, which is composed of many long episodes involving one hero, is transmitted orally from one bard to another. It is chanted or sung by a especially trained individual or group before a mixed audience during social gatherings convened for weddings, wakes, and other special feasts. Epics are also called ethnoepics not only because they are created by an ethnic group but also because they serve to codify the values of that group, thereby strengthening the basis of unity among members of the group. Philippine epics depict a precolonial society, although they are still very much alive today as their meanings adjust to historical circumstances over the centuries. In Agyu, the antagonists, who are Maguindanao, have taken on the identity of “Moros” (Muslims), although the epic originated in pre-Islamic times. The Dulimaman of the Itneg encapsulates the history of hostilities between the lowland Ilocano and the mountain groups. Here, the protagonist is persecuted by the Ilocano in Paoay, jailed in Laoag despite his innocence, and forced to flee to the mountains of Abra. In some cases, elements from foreign cultures have crept into the epic, as in the Ilocano Lam-ang, whose characters bear Spanish first names and the titles “Don” and “Doña”; the Tboli Tudbulul, in which guns are used; the Tagbanwa Pala’isgen, in which the man-eating tigre (tiger) has replaced the malignant spirit of Tagbanwa cosmology; and the Karay-a Sugidanon, in which a lion’s heart, instead of a white boar’s, holds Saragnayan’s life force.

Epics have a sustained length and an episodic structure. Although many epics have a single story line involving a complex of characters and events, others are composed of several songs, ballads, and chants, thematically interrelated. These songs can be considered sub-epics, constituting an epic cycle. The Ulahingan of the Livunganen-Arumanen, for example, consists of several cycles, each of which is made up of songs revolving around a hero.

The central motif of the hero’s quest varies according to the object of the quest. In the Karay-a Hinilawod, Tagbanwa Kudaman, and Maranao Darangen, it is the quest for a woman, or a series of women. In Sandayo, a variation is that the man’s quest for the woman is paralleled by the woman’s quest for him. In Lam-ang, the hero’s initial quest is for his father before he sets off again to woo Doña Ines Cannoyan. In the Ibaloy Bindian, Cagayan Agta Nanang, Tagbanwa Pala’isgen, Tiruray Berinareu, and Tboli Tudbulul, the quest is in aid of an abducted maiden. In another Tudbulul cycle and a Samarnon Candu, the quest is for a betel chew. At regular intervals during these quests, the heroes, whether male or female, must engage in the requisite battles with mortals or supernatural beings. However, some epics center on battles for their own sake: Aliguyon of the Hudhud revives hostilities between his clan and Pumbakhayon’s because he needs to do battle; and in the epic of Agyu, the hero must go on sea raids to initiate and train the young men of Nalandangan in the ways of war.

Cycles arise from variations in each performance of an epic. Bards may adapt details to suit the contemporary setting; they may add new stories if their listeners want variety; or they may omit the details or entire episodes that they do not recall, and improvise. Agyu of the Arakan-Arumanen is constantly updated with episodes about the adventures of Agyu and his relatives.

Epics are transmitted from one generation to the next by bards, male or female, gifted with a good voice and a capacious memory. This oral transmission has resulted in the proliferation of multiple versions of the same basic story. The epic of Panay, which is called Hinilawod by F. Landa Jocano and Sugidanon by Alice P. Magos, has multiple versions by various chanters. In Jocano’s Labaw Donggon cycle of the Hinilawod epic, Nagmalitung Yawa is the sun god’s wife whom Labaw Donggon takes by force from her husband; but in the Humadapnon cycle of the same epic, Humadapnon is Labaw Donggon’s nephew who woos the solitary woman, Nagmalitung Yawa, with great difficulty. In Alicia P. Magos’s Sugidanon, Nagmalitung Yawa is Labaw Donggon’s daughter; therefore, her husband, Humadapnon, is Labaw Donggon’s son-in-law. Paubari, aka Paiburong, is Labaw Donggon’s father, brother, or brother-in-law in various cycles of the Hinilawod and Sugidanon. In the Nanang of the Labin Agta of Cagayan, Talimanog and Ammani are brothers in one cycle but are brothers-in-law in another. There are characters in the Ulahingan who are brothers in one version but are father and son in another.
