article.value: During the last quarter of the 19th century, the discursive, argumentative, and didactic literature that the missionary writers had propagated for their proselytizing purposes began to serve the Filipino intellectuals well, for they used the same form to consolidate the archipelago into one nation against the common colonial master. The essay, in both Spanish and the vernacular, became the natural venue for the propaganda and reform movements, which required a means by which issues could be logically presented, Spanish abuses exposed and condemned, and the people sufficiently provoked into action.

The strong nationalistic sentiments produced not only more editorials, columns, and feature articles, but also letters, diaries, sermons, speeches, travelogues, papeles volantes (loose sheets), and prosa poetica (poetic prose). The propaganda movement may be said to have begun at the turn of the 19th century, with Luis Rodriguez Varela’s Proclama Historica que para Animar a los Vasallos a que Defienden a Su Rey del Furor de Su Falso Amigo, Napoleon, Primer Emperador de los Franceses (Historical Proclamation Which Aims to Exhort the Vassals to Defend Their King from the Ire of His False Friend, Napoleon, First Emperor of the French), 1809, which began to express an emerging Filipino consciousness. A model of “pulpit oratory” was Fr Pedro Pelaez’s Colecciones de Sermones (A Collection of Sermons), 1869. Pelaez was the leading exponent of the secularization of the Philippine parishes, and he published his articles of protest in the Madrid newspaper El Clamor Publico. His follower, Fr Jose Burgos, is better known for the work Manifiesto de los Leales Filipinos en Defensa de Su Honra y Fidelidad (Manifesto of the Loyal Filipinos in Defense of Their Honor and Faithfulness), 1864. Impulses of protest began with an early figure in the propaganda movement, Gregorio Sancianco, who was the first Filipino to write a treatise on Philippine problems, El Progreso de Filipinas (The Progress of Filipinas), 1881. The book urges the improvement of government policies, especially regarding the imposition of taxes. It makes an impassioned defense of the small farmer, whose apathy caused by abuse and exploitation, is often mistaken for indolence. This later became one of  Jose Rizal’s sources for his own essay, “Sobre la Indolencia de los Filipinos” (On the Indolence of the Filipinos), 1890.

A conscious attempt to grapple with the concept of “Filipino” is found in Pedro Paterno’s series of works, 1887-92, which exalt the people’s pre-Hispanic civilization. La Antigua Civilizacion Tagalog (Ancient Tagalog Civilization), 1887, depicts the people as highly civilized even before the Spaniards came; El Cristianismo en la Antigua Civilizacion Tagalog (Christianity in Ancient Tagalog Civilization), 1892, equates indigenous religious beliefs and practices with Christian doctrines and rituals. Other books by Paterno are pseudoethnographic studies of Filipio marriage customs, morality, and the Tagalog political structure. The best features of Paterno’s rhetoric are contained in his inspiring inaugural speech of the Malolos Congress on 15 Sep 1898. The literature of the propaganda movement was essentially a profession of adherence and loyalty to Spain, an appeal to Spain’s sense of justice and its manifest destiny, and a strong protest against friar rule. Since it was addressed to the Spanish government, and since its writers were in exile in Madrid and Barcelona as “filibusters,” most of it was written in Spanish.

Marcelo H. del Pilar’s La Soberania Monacal en Filipinas (The Monastic Supremacy in the Philippines), 1888, analyzes the power of the friars in the economic, political, and religious levels. Earlier in his career, he also wrote nationalist tracts in Tagalog when he addressed himself to a large non-Spanish readership.

Rizal delivered his first political speech when Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo won in an international painting contest in 1884 in Madrid. He published his articles in the movement’s periodical, La Solidaridad, 1889-90. His versatility is seen in his combative “La Verdad para Todos” (The Truth for Everybody), his bitterness in “Ingratitudes” (Ingratitudes), his socio-anthropological opinion in “La Indolencia de los Filipinos” (The Indolence of the Filipinos), and his acute sense of history in the prophetic “Filipinas dentro de Cien Años” (The Philippines within a Century). His satirical essays include “La Vision de Fray Rodriguez” (A Vision of Fray Rodriguez), “Por Telefono” (By Telephone), and “Una Visita del Señor a las Filipinas” (A Visit of Our Lord to the Philippines). At del Pilar’s request, Rizal wrote “Sa mga Kababayang Dalaga ng Malolos” (To My Young Countrywomen of Malolos), 1889, praising Filipino women for their courage and urging them to continue their struggle to free themselves of the yoke of ignorance imposed upon them by Spanish rule.

Graciano Lopez Jaena’s speeches and articles were collected in the book Discursos y Articulos Varios (Discourses and Various Articles), 1891. First and foremost an orator, Lopez Jaena wrote articles which were sometimes as florid as his speeches. However, they also reveal an eclectic knowledge of the Philippines, such as his survey of its agricultural products and a proposal for an arts and trade curriculum. There is a treatise on the imposition of tribute, another on the corruption endemic in Philippine political institutions. In an 1884 article, he remarks on the peculiar logic of the Filipino people thus: “It is a country where the paraos walk, house building begins with the roof; the feet are always held higher than the head, etc., etc.” (trans. Alzona 1964, 121).

Other essays in Spanish during this period were Antonio Luna’s “Impresiones” (Impressions), 1891; Jose Felipe del Pan’s “Hay Que Vivir!” (We Have to Live!), 1884; Carlos Peñaranda’s “Prosa” (Prose), 1893; and E. Polo de Lara’s “Tipos y Costumbres” (Types and Customs), 1897.

The revolutionary movement against Spain produced literature meant to rally the people to arms; hence, it was written in the native languages. Andres Bonifacio’s Katipunan manifesto, “Ang Dapat Mabatid ng mga Tagalog” (What the Tagalog Should Know), 1896, follows a neat syllogistic structure but is nevertheless imbued with a strong emotional appeal. It calls for his fellow Tagalog to awaken themselves and rise to action in the pursuit of national freedom. He wrote the first primer on the 10 duties of the members of the Katipunan movement called “Katungkulang Gagawin ng mga Anak ng Bayan” (Duties of the Sons and Daughters of the Nation), ca. 1893.

Emilio Jacinto wrote clear, precise, forceful essays for the revolution. He provided the pragmatic, simple, and lucid style needed to attract followers to the ideals of the Katipunan. Liwanag at Dilim (Light and Darkness), 1896, is a collection of Jacinto’s essays, the most famous of which is “Ang Ningning at ang Liwanag” (Glitter and Light). The others in the same collection are “Ang Kalayaan” (Freedom), “Ang Tao’y Magkakapantay” (People Are Equal), “Ang Pag-ibig sa Bayan” (Love for Country), “Ang Bayan at ang mga Gobiernong Pinuno” (The Country and the Government Officials), “Ang Maling Pagsampalataya” (False Belief), and “Ang Gumawa” (The Creator). His other essays, not in this collection, are “Pahayag” (Statement), “Sa mga Kababayan” (To the Citizens), and “Ang Kasalanan ni Cain” (Cain’s Sin). Kartilya ng Katipunan (Primer of the Katipunan), 1894, was acknowledged by Bonifacio as superior to his own, and so was used as the Katipunan primer.

Apolinario Mabini lived through both the revolution against Spain and the Filipino-American war. “El Verdadero Decalogo” (The True Decalogue), 1898, which he translated himself into Tagalog as “Ang Tunay na Sampung Utos” (The True Ten Commandments), expressed a concept of a Filipino government. His “Ordenanzas de la Revolucion” (Ordinances of the Revolution), 1898, was used by Emilio Aguinaldo as a basis for the program of the revolutionary government established on 12 Jun 1898.
The American Colonial Period

The Filipino-American war began almost immediately after the Filipinos had won their independence from Spain. The nationalist tradition in writing in Spanish, begun by the propaganda movement, was fueled by this turn of events. Defiance of the new enemy ran high and was expressed in historical accounts, memoirs, and biographies of patriots. Mabini’s memoirs, La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), published in 1931, was written while he was in exile in Guam from 1901 to 1903. A chapter of it recounts the rise and fall of the Philippine Revolution. Artemio Ricarte’s “Apuntes Historicos de la Insurreccion por los Asociadas al Katipunan” (Historical Memoirs of the Insurrection by the Katipunan Members), later published as a book, Himagsikan nang manga Filipino Laban sa Kastila (The Revolt of the Filipinos against the Spaniards), 1922, was written while he was confined in the Bilibid Prison, 1904-10. Other memoirs were Santiago V. Alvarez’s Ang Katipunan at Paghihimagsik (The Katipunan and the Revolution), 1927; Emilio Aguinaldo’s Mga Gunita ng Himagsikan (Memoirs of the Revolution), written in 1928-41 and published posthumously in 1964, and Reseña Veridica de la Revolucion Filipina (True Account of the Philippine Revolution), 1899, translated into English and reprinted in the journal Philippine Social Science Review in 1941; Felipe Calderon’s Mis Memorias sobre la Revolucion Filipina (My Memoirs about the Philippine Revolution), 1907; Mariano Ponce’s Cartas de la Revolucion, 1897-1900 (Letters of the Revolution, 1897-1900), 1932; and Isabelo de los Reyes’s La Sensacional Memoria de Isabelo de los Reyes sobre la Revolucion Filipina de 1896-97 (Sensational Memoirs about the Philippine Revolution of 1896-97), 1899. Pio Valenzuela, Jose Alejandrino, and Gregoria de Jesus also wrote their own memoirs. Biographies were written by Manuel Artigas, Teodoro M. Kalaw, Rafael Palma, Mariano Ponce, Jaime C. de Veyra, and Epifanio de los Santos. Kalaw’s romanticized biography of Gregorio del Pilar may be considered the most literary of the crop.

An essay aptly depicting the temper of the ilustrados (educated native) at the height of the Filipino revolutionaries’ victory and showing the generation gap at the turn of the century is “Venerables Puputs” (The Venerable Puputs), 1898, by Manuel S. Guerrero. It is an anticlerical piece in the tradition of Rizal’s, Lopez Jaena’s, and Marcelo H. del Pilar’s satires. It pokes fun at colonial mentality and religious fanaticism as personified by two spinsters and a married woman well-placed in society. Serving as foil is the married one’s 15-year-old granddaughter, a free spirit who finds these three religious devotees laughable.

article.value: Isabelo de los Reyes began writing during the time of the propaganda movement, and then continued writing well into the American colonial period. Like Pedro Paterno, he used history to express his nationalism; but, unlike Paterno, his historical accounts were more carefully and accurately researched. His books consist of Historia de Ilocos (History of Ilocos), 1890; two volumes of El Folk-Lore Filipino (Philippine Folklore), 1889; Las Islas Visayas en la Epoca de la Conquista (The Visayan Islands at the Time of the Conquest), 1889; and Historia de Filipinas (History of the Philippines), 1889.

De los Reyes wrote in both Spanish and Ilocano. He founded El Ilocano in 1889, the first regional paper established by a Filipino. It published articles in both Spanish and Ilocano. Among the notable essayists who wrote in Ilocano during the last two decades of the 19th century were de los Reyes, Ignacio Villamor, Claro Caluya, Mena Pecson Crisologo, Fr Justo Claudio Fojas, Fr Mariano Dacanay, and Canuto Ruiz Medina. Their topics ranged from folklore to local history and sociopolitical issues. An attempt to capture the vigor of theater life in Manila is the series of articles published by Juan Atayde, titled Los Teatros de Manila (The Theaters of Manila), 1892. It gives cursory descriptions of the architecture of particular theaters (e.g., the theaters of Binondo and Tondo), drama and musical societies, and some performers, both local and foreign, both laudable and eccentric.

The essay in Spanish continued to enjoy great popularity from 1900 to about a decade after World War II. Subjects were on folklore, literature, and social, political, and religious problems. It was a formidable tool for forming public opinion. The more significant essayists of the older generation were Rafael Palma, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, Cecilio I. Apostol, and Trinidad Pardo de Tavera. They were followed by Vicente Sotto, Epifanio C. de los Santos, Teodoro M. Kalaw, Jorge Bocobo, and Claro M. Recto.

Patriotic writings continued to appear in the papeles volantes of Anacleto Ramos and in newspapers like El Renacimiento, La Vanguardia, La Opinion, El Mercantil, El Debate, and other magazines. The newspaper El Ideal published a series of articles alternately written by Jaime C. de Veyra and Mariano Ponce, who both wanted to promote a national consciousness. These articles, written 1911-12, ranged over topics of social, historical, and political interest; these were later compiled in a book called Efemerides Filipinas (Philippine Almanac), 1914. Another columnist, Teodoro M. Kalaw, wrote columns later compiled into Dietario Espiritual (Spiritual Diary), 1930, which discussed the methods and ideology of American colonization among others. His “Cinco Reglas de Nuestra Moral Antigua” (Five Precepts from Our Ancient Morality), 1935, and Hacia la Tierra del Zar (Toward the Land of the Czar), 1908, are of considerable literary merit. Kalaw was also associated with the controversial editorial of Fidel Reyes, “Aves de Rapiña” (Birds of Prey), 1908.

Along with patriotic works, scientific essays were written by Trinidad Pardo de Tavera and Manuel Guerrero, technical essays by Leoncio Gonzalez Liquete, philosophical essays by Kalaw and Manuel Ravago, and journalistic essays by Pedro Aunario.

In the 20th century, outstanding writers on the Spanish legacy were Rafael Palma, who wrote “El Alma de España” (The Soul of Spain), 1900; Macario Adriatico, “Voto por el Intercambio de Ideas” (I Vote for the Exchange of Ideas); Tirso de Irureta Goyena, “Por el Idioma y Cultura Hispanos” (On the Spanish Language and Culture); and Benigno del Rio. Columnists were Jesus Balmori, Antonio M. Abad, and Benigno del Rio.

As American rule became more firmly established, contrary positions were taken by the writers in Spanish. Pardo de Tavera’s essays and speeches, such as “El Legado del Ignorantismo” (The Legacy of Ignorantism), 1920, had for their counterpoint the anti-American essays of Kalaw, Palma, and Irureta Goyena. Adriatico’s speeches stirred his audience, as did those of Sergio Osmeña, Manuel Quezon, and Claro M. Recto. Some of the more representative essays of the period are Recto’s “El Castellano como Factor de Nuestra Nacionalidad” (Spanish as a Factor in Our Nationality); Palma’s “Alma Mater,” 1930; Epifanio C. de los Santos’s “Filipinos y Filipinistas” (Filipinos and Filipinists), 1909; Vicente Sotto’s “Una Rapida Vuelta al Mundo” (A Quick Trip Round the World), 1930; Jose G. Reyes’s “Ideales de Humanidad” (Ideals of Humanity), 1933; and Luis Guzman Rivas’s “Pigmeos” (Pygmies), 1940.

The best essays in Spanish were those that exalted the virtues and heroism of the Filipino race, defended the Hispanic legacy, and prophesied the coming of the new colonial masters. But with the entrenchment of Americanized culture in the country, literature in Spanish declined. Journalism generated articles that were either informative or polemical in intent. Pamphlets, monographs, lectures, and speeches were also published as essays. In Tagalog in 1910, Carlos Ronquillo serialized the results of his research on Philippine folklore in the newspaper El Renacimiento. Writing in the same vein was Sofronio Calderon, who wrote of pre-Hispanic culture in “Dating Filipinas” (Ancient Philippines), 1907. Lope K. Santos published in monograph form a philosophical and moral tract called Hindi Talaga ng Diyos (Not God’s Will), 1912, which expressed his antifeudal and antiobscurantist beliefs.

Muling Pagsilang, 1901-10, and Lipang Kalabaw, 1907-9, were weekly outlets for the Tagalog writers who published their poems, essays, and dagli (vignettes or sketches). Other periodicals followed: Telembang, Siling Labuyo, and Buntot-Pague, 1914. Literary organizations were formed, the first being Aklatang Bayan, 1910. Its members, besides being fictionists or poets, or both, were also literary critics and essayists. These were Rosauro Almario, Faustino Aguilar, Lope K. Santos, Benigno Ramos, Patricio Mariano, Leonardo A. Dianzon, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, Pascual de Leon, Rosalia L. Aguinaldo, Julian Cruz Balmaseda, Pedro Gatmaitan, Carlos Gatmaitan, Carlos Ronquillo, Antonio K. Abad, Sofronio G. Calderon, Patricio Dionisio, Valeriano Hernandez Peña, Francisco Laksamana, Severino Reyes, Engracio L. Valmonte, Nemesio Caravana, Amado V. Hernandez, Jose P. Laurel, Gonzalo Cue Malay, and others.

In the other Philippine languages, a number of essayists during the first three decades of the 20th century wrote quasi-scholarly studies of their own languages. In Ilonggo, an anonymous article describing the Ilonggo language, “Ang Bisaya Malulut kag Matamis Gid Pamation” (Visayan Is Soft Because Very Sweet to the Ear), appeared in the Ilonggo newspaper Makinaugalingon. Two leading Ilonggo writers of that period who wrote on the same topic were Serapion C. Torre and Delfin G. Gumban. Others tried their hand at the philosophical essay. Policarpio Y. Cuanico’s “Sulat kay Kamatayon” (Letter to Death), 1939, in which the persona observes that Death is a happier state than life because “those who are rich … live in abundance and bliss because they depend on the poor whom they pressure and oppress” (Hosillos 1992, 225).

In Bicol in the 1920s, Luis Dato and Fr Luis Dimarumba demonstrated an interest in their own language. Dato, in his work “Kasagkoran nin Bikol na Pagtitinkopan kan Taramon sa Ilawod asin Habagatan Kaining Kaporoan nin Pilipinas” (Bicol Represents All the Languages from North to South of This Archipelago of the Philippines), concludes that the three progressive Philippine languages—namely, Ilocano, Tagalog, and Bisaya—will finally meet in the Bicol area, the middle ground, and the result would be the formation of a truly national language. Fr Luis Dimarumba’s article, “Ka Ke Ki Ko Ku / Ca Ce Ci Co Cu” advocates changes in Bicol orthography, such as using k instead of c. An exchange of letters between Father Dimarumba and one Fr Eutiquio Revatoris on this subject was published in the Bikol newsmagazine Sanghiran nin Bikol, indicating that a debate occurred between adherents of purism and those who would opt for linguistic modernization. Antonio Salazar likens the dynamism of the language to the many moods of a person.

The Bikol essayists wrote other types of essays with a strong Filipino consciousness in the periodicals and in the Bikolana magazine. Casimiro E. Perfecto wrote historical essays. Francisco Celebrado wrote patriotic editorials, whereas Mariano Villafuerte wrote philosophical and reflective essays. Patricio M. Janer, a prolific essayist, wrote social criticism in a passionate vein, using literary devices like dialogue, rhetorical questions, or a lyrical style to convey the urgency of his themes.

In Cebu, newspapers carried commentaries on local politics, history, culture, places, and personalities. Essayists from the 1920s to 1940 were Vicente Sotto, Filemon Sotto, Vicente Rama, Tomas Alonso, Vicente Flores, Marcos Trinidad, and Maria Kabigon. Essays and articles compiled in books were V. Sotto’s Mga Handumanan sa Sugbu (Reminiscences of Cebu), 1926; and Pantaleon V. Kardenas’s In Memoriam, 1937, and Naglantaw sa Kagahapon (Look Back at Yesterday).

Ilocano newspapers encouraged essays of various types: lyrical, satirical, and political. Notable essayists of this period were Camilo Osias, Mariano Gaerlan, Hermogenes Belen, Mauro Peña, Agapito Kuramen, Buenaventura Bello, Leon Pichay, Florencia Lagasca, Santiago Alcantara, and Mena Crisologo.

Kapampangan essayists wrote in the same vein as all the other vernacular writers. Zoilo Hilario, also a poet, was inclined toward the historical essay, such as “Tarik Soliman,” in which he questions the Spanish historians’ account of Rajah Soliman’s death in the Battle of Tondo of 1571. Other essayists active in 1921-41 were Serafin D. Lacson, Felix B. Bautista, Eligio G. Lagman, Silvestre M. Punsalan, and Jose P. Fausto.

From 1901 to 1946, the English language was imposed upon the Filipino people through popular education; hence, it became the language of the educated, especially of the intellectual elite. Students were introduced to the essays of American and British writers like G. K. Chesterton, William Hazlitt, Charles Lamb, James Thurber, Robert Benchley, E. B. White, Jonathan Swift, Francis Bacon, and others. College Folio, the literary magazine of the University of the Philippines, which first came out in Oct 1910, contained 18 pieces; of these, 13 were essays. Among the essayists in this first issue were Fernando Maramag, Tarcila Malabanan, and Jorge B. Vargas.

The informal essay in English began with Alejandrina Santiago’s idyllic portrait of Iloilo in “A Call,” 1918. Other topics of the early essays were various aspects of nature, clean living, and the need for virtue. The style tended toward sentimental idealizing that was also characteristic of the fiction and poetry of that period. The first anthology of familiar essays was Dear Devices, 1933. Among the authors included were Antonio and Ariston Estrada, F. B. Icasiano, A. E. Litiatco, Amador Daguio, Pura Santillan, Amanda Dayrit, Lydia Villanueva, Alfredo Q. Gonzalez, and Estrella Alfon. According to critic and literary historian Mona Highley in 1941, Antonio Estrada had possibly the best style. Inspirational essays were written by Jorge Bocobo, Mauro Baradi, and Zoilo M. Galang. Conrado Benitez and Leandro H. Fernandez wrote historical essays for the Philippine Review, a monthly magazine in both Spanish and English.

Philippine political and cultural independence was a topic of great concern for many of these writers. Following the tradition of the 19th-century propagandists who refuted foreigners’ disparaging remarks about the Filipino race and culture, Pedro de la Llana in “The Preservation of White Prestige,” 1930, takes to task an American journalist’s assertion that the Malay race is inherently inferior to the white. Other essays affirming the Filipino national identity amid the onslaught of foreign cultures are Amador Daguio’s “The Old Chief,” 1933, and “The Malayan Spell and the Creation of a Literature,” 1934; Arturo B. Rotor’s “Notes on Contemporary Art and Culture,” 1936; Mauro Mendez’s “Problem for Narcissus,” 1936.

Parallel to this concern was the anxiety of some writers about the decline of independent and critical thinking among students. Such was the theme of Bocobo’s “College Uneducation,” 1928; Vicente M. Hilario’s “Producing a Crop of Soft Brains?,” 1930; and F. B. Icasiano’s “On Finding Our Feet,” 1929. On the other hand, the absorption of an Americanized outlook is evidenced by Juan Collas’s informal essay, “The American Flapper,” 1922.

Other essayists who were educated exclusively under the Americanized curriculum were Gabriel A. Bernardo, Pedro de la Llana, Cristina Jamias, Eliseo Quirino, Vicente M. Hilario, Mauro Mendez, I. V. Mallari, and Carlos P. Romulo.

Fernando Maramag was probably the most respected essayist of the period, dominating literary criticism in 1910-30. He also wrote political essays as editor of the Rising Philippines, founded in 1917, which was the first publication of English-reading Filipinos, and wrote editorials for the Tribune, till his death in 1936. An editorial in the 1929 issue of the UP Writers’ Club journal Literary Apprentice affirmed the profound influence of Fernando Maramag on the journal’s editors, likening his influence on them to that of Cecilio Apostol on the writers in Spanish.

Encarnacion Alzona, Maria Paz Mendoza Guazon, and Honoria Acosta Sison wrote on the Filipino woman, on women’s suffrage, and history. A long autobiography by Emilia Malabanan appeared in the Herald Midweek Magazine, 1941. Maria Luna Lopez’s essays, written between the 1930s and the 1970s, were compiled in a book Sand in the Palm and Other Essays, 1976. Maria Kalaw’s language was straightforward and emotionally restrained, even when she was writing about the homesickness of the scholar in America. Lydia C. Villanueva-Arguilla’s flippancy echoed that of the French and English authors. Platon Callangan was influenced by Hazlitt. Federico Mangahas and Amando C. Dayrit wrote good-natured satires. Mangahas’s works were posthumously collected in Maybe: Incidentally, 1998. Although Salvador P. Lopez was better known for his scholarly and urbane essays, he also dabbled in personal essays in his early years. Two examples are “A Little Child Smiled at Me,” 1935, and “Leaves from a Poet’s Vacation Journal,” 1932.

In 1935, a new Tagalog writers’ organization, Kapisanang Panitikan, was founded. Salvador Barros, a founding member, proclaimed themselves to be both sakdalista (an allusion to the radical peasant movement bearing this name) because they were rebelling against the literary standards of the old, established writers, and aristokrata (aristocratic) because they were ready to face unpopularity for the sake of their literary convictions. Other founding members were Alejandro G. Abadilla, Teodoro A. Agoncillo, Clodualdo del Mundo, Brigido Batungbakal, Epifanio Gar. Matute, Teo S. Buhain, and Fernando B. Monleon. Others who soon joined them were Nieves Baens del Rosario, Macario Pineda, Anacleto Dizon, Pablo Glorioso, Apolonia Arriola, Genoveva D. Edroza, Jesus A. Arceo, Cresencio C. Torres, Manuel Car. Santiago, Gonzalo K. Flores, Manuel Principe Bautista, and Ruben Vega. Besides fiction and poetry, they also variously wrote feature articles, editorial columns, and formal, informal, and critical essays.

Clodualdo del Mundo and Antonio B. L. Rosales were columnists of Liwayway magazine. Their essays advocated the more creative use of the Tagalog language. At the 1940 Commonwealth Literary Contests, honorable mentions were awarded to “Salawikaing Tagalog” (Tagalog Proverbs) by Jacinto Suban and “Saan, Kabataang Pilipino?” (Whereto, Filipino Youth?) by Pablo R. Glorioso.
From World War II to the Present

During the Japanese occupation, the use of English was discouraged. The two English-language magazines with literary sections, Pillars and Philippine Review, were issued monthly, whereas Liwayway and Taliba magazines were weeklies. Hence, some writers who had been using English before World War II turned to Tagalog as their medium. These included Lina Flor, Hernando R. Ocampo, Lydia Villanueva Arguila, Paz Latorena, Trinidad Tarrosa Subido, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Maria Luna Lopez, and N. V. M. Gonzalez. Iñigo Ed. Regalado, Alejandro G. Abadilla, Ildefonso Santos, Juan Laya, and others who were already writing in Tagalog continued doing so.

In 1950, Alejandro G. Abadilla compiled representative Tagalog essays in Mga Piling Sanaysay (Selected Essays), more than half of which were taken from Liwayway magazine during the Japanese occupation. Some of the essays included are “Alaala ng Taglagas” (Memories of Fall) by Pedro S. Dandan, “Ako’y Isang Tinig” (One Voice Am I) by Genoveva Edroza-Matute, “Ang Siste Nito” (There’s the Rub) by Macario Pineda, and “Diwang Kayumanggi” (Spirit of the Brown Race) by Narciso G. Reyes. Other essays in this collection are by Manuel Principe Bautista, Rufino Alejandro, Liwayway Arceo, Brigido C. Batungbakal, Vito C. Santos, Epifanio Gar. Matute, Teo S. Baylen, Mabini Rey Centeno, Lina Flor, Eleuterio P. Fojas, Juan C. Laya, Silvina C. Laya, Alfredo S. Enriquez, Pablo R. Glorioso, David Mamaril, Clodualdo del Mundo, Gemiliano Pineda, Cornelio S. Reyes, and Ildefonso Santos.

Epifanio Gar. Matute was popular for his astute eye for the ordinary and his lighthearted humor, especially evident in his radio series Kuwentong Kutsero (Rig Driver’s Tales). In his satirical essay “Sanaysaging,” a word he coined to mean “an essay on the banana,” he ranges through the national problem of hunger and neocolonialism, as represented by the United Fruit Co., in a self-mocking tone. His “Ang Pagpupulis-Trapiko Ay Isang Sining” (The Art of Being a Traffic Policeman) shows his eye for detail in his description of the policeman that he calls “diktador ng mga sasakyan” (dictator of vehicles).

A nationalist consciousness typical of the Philippine essay runs through Genoveva Edroza-Matute’s three collections: 15 Piling Sanaysay: Kasaysayan, Pag-aaral at Pagsulat ng Sanaysay (15 Selected Essays: History, Study and Writing of the Essay), 1984; Ako’y Isang Tinig (One Voice Am I), 1952; and Maiikling Kuwento at Sanaysay ng Tatlo (Short Stories and Essays of Three), 1988. Her futuristic essay in epistolary form, “Liham sa Kabataan ng Taong 2070” (Letter to the Youth in the Year 2070), 1970, deplores people’s preference for English over the national language but ends on the optimistic note that the tide will inevitably change. “Ako’y Isang Tinig” (One Voice Am I), 1950, defines the writer’s voice as “the voice in the wilderness.” Even her travel writing ultimately focuses on the Philippines by comparing it with all the other countries that she has been to.

Essay writing in Tagalog was further encouraged by the contest called Patimpalak-Bognot sa Sanaysay, which was begun in 1952. Winning entries were “Isang Panimulang Pag-aaral sa Pinanggalingan ng Wikang Pilipino” (An Initial Study of the Roots of the Pilipino Language) by E. Arsenio Manuel, “Lupang Baog: Ako” (Sterile Land: I) by Florencio N. Garcia, and “Saan Patungo ang Langay-Langayan?” (Where Goes the Swallow?) by Buenaventura S. Medina Jr. Other contests followed. The Kapisanang Aklat, Diwa at Panitik sponsored an interuniversity contest for the Tagalog section of college papers. Efren R. Abueg, as a student representative of Manuel L. Quezon University, won for “Ang Ating Nasyonalismo” (Our Nationalism) in 1957, and Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat, representing the University of Santo Tomas, won for “Ang Trahedya ng Manunulat sa Pilipinas” (The Tragedy of the Writer in the Philippines) in 1963.

In 1979, an essay category in Pilipino was introduced into the Palanca Awards, further validating the essay as a literary form. The winners were Virgilio S. Almario for “Mga Talinghaga sa Panahon ng Krisis” (Metaphors in a Time of Crisis), Alice Guillermo for “Ang Kaisipang Pilipino Batay sa Sining Biswal” (Filipino Thought Based on the Visual Arts), and Anselmo S. Roque for “Sa Ibabaw ng Kapirasong Lupa” (Upon a Piece of Land).

Lamberto E. Antonio’s essays and short stories written for his newspaper columns from the 1970s to 1991 were collected in Rebanse: Sanaysay at Kuwento (Return Match: Essays and Stories), 1991. The essays recall his childhood in his hometown of Cabiao, Nueva Ecija, recount episodes in his life marked by rain and flood, and discuss the author’s various interesting acquaintances, friends, and relatives. Similar to these are Ligaya Tiamson-Rubin’s personal essays on her native Angono in Sining at Kultura sa Bayan ng Angono (Art and Culture in Angono), 1992. May Awit ang Bakal (Steel Has a Song), 1976, edited by Jess Calixto, contains samples of writing by the working class. “Ang Paggawa at ang Manggagawa” (Work and the Worker) by Jake Gregorio, in a light vein, describes the behavior of workers and classifies them according to the degree by which they get their hands dirty while at work. “Ito Ba ang Katotohanan?” (Is This the Truth?) by Linda Esguerra (aka Karlorelex) compares the lifestyles of the rich and the poor and rejects the prevailing belief that all people are created equal. “Nasa Diyos ang Awa, Nasa Tao ang Gawa” (God Dispenses Mercy, the Person Does the Work), by Nestor Loraya, asserts a worker’s philosophy of self-reliance.

Martial law, imposed by Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1972, produced prison literature. Pintig sa Malamig na Bakal: Poems and Letters from Philippine Prisons (Life Pulse in Cold Steel: Poems and Letters from Philippine Prisons), 1979, and Pintig 2: An Anthology of Prose and Poetry from Philippine Prisons, 1985, contain manifestos, personal essays, journal entries, and reflections by political detainees. Fr Edgardo Kangleon’s essay “A Moment of Uncertainty” was found inside the seams of his clothes after his death in a mysterious car accident. The piece is a detailed account of the mental and physical torture he underwent, the luxuries he was rewarded with after his forced confession, and the guilt he suffered for what he perceived to be his cowardice. The narrative is interspersed with reflections that consistently express sympathy for the downtrodden and skepticism of the ruling class hegemony. Other personal reflections are by Fr Jeremias Aquino, Fr Edicio de la Torre, and Doris Baffrey. A moving piece is Rene J. Marciano’s “Marahil … Bukas” (Perhaps … Tomorrow), which follows one detainee’s stream of consciousness as he waits vainly for his family during visiting hours. Three essays by Satur Ocampo demonstrate his ability for incisive analyses, whether speculating on the possibility of being released from political detention, or marking the ninth year of his incarceration. Similarly analytical is Fr Karl Gaspar in his essay “Institutionalized Violence: The View from the Belly of the Beast.”

article.value: A form of autobiographical writing is testimonial literature. Sa Tungki ng Ilong ng Kaaway: Talambuhay ni Tatang (On the Tip of the Enemy’s Nose: Diary of Tatang), 1991, is an example. Testimonial literature is the transcribed version of a tape-recorded account of a worker or peasant. He or she represents the masses whose history has been silenced by the ruling class’s own version of history. The first-person point of view is guided by a political consciousness that is anti-imperialist, pro-masses, and liberating.

Awareness of specific issues in human development endures in such works as Fanny Garcia’s Erick Slumbook: Paglalakbay Kasama ang Anak Kong Autistic (Erick Slumbook: Journey with My Autistic Child), 2005. The author discusses the government policies pertinent to and public perception of persons with disability alongside sketching her life as a mother and guide to her autistic son. Buhay Pinoy: Mga Piling Interbyu’t Artikulo (Philippine Life: Interviews and Articles), 2007, is a compilation of Garcia’s human interest stories—on the elderly, traditional healers, overseas workers, among other subjects—written mostly in the 1970s.

Writers in Tagalog still contribute regularly to the weekly magazine Liwayway, which publishes personal essays by a different writer every week. The column True Confessions collects narratives that reveal hidden, private lives, thereby providing the necessary counterpoint to the magazine’s impersonal news stories, entertainment news, and short stories.

By the 1950s, literature in Spanish had begun to decline. Some representative essays of this period were Enrique Fernandez Lumba’s “Hispanofilia Filipina” (Philippine Love of Spain), 1954; Manuel Briones’s Discursos y Ensayos: Temarios y Vida Filipina (Speeches and Essays: Philippine Themes and Life), 1955; Vicente Guzman Rivas’s “En España Son Asi” (It’s That Way in Spain), 1959; and Encarnacion Alzona’s “El Legado de España a Filipinas” (The Legacy of Spain to the Philippines), 1956. Recto’s “El Monroismo Asiatica” (Asiatic Monroism), 1929, was thought to be the pinnacle of Philippine prose in Spanish until the publication of The Recto Valedictory in 1985. This book, which carries an English translation by Nick Joaquin, is a compilation of Recto’s speeches on the Spanish heritage in the Philippines. He had intended to deliver these in Madrid in 1960 but death stopped him in Rome.

In the 1960s, the straightforward, almost belligerent style of Guillermo Gomez Rivera, best illustrated by his “Filipino: Origen y Connotacion y Otros Ensayos” (Filipino: Origin and Connotation and Other Speeches), 1966, contrasted strongly with the impeccable language and serene style of Fernandez Lumba and the flowing lyrical prose of Nilda Guerrero Barranco, as seen in her Nostalgias, 1969. A literary history tracing the development of Hispanic culture in the country from the 17th to the 20th century is Jaime de Veyra’s Hispanidad en Filipinas (Hispanism in the Philippines), 1961.

In the mid-1990s, readership in Spanish was for some time sustained in Cronica de Manila, a Spanish-language section in the Manila Chronicle broadsheet established by then Instituto Cervantes de Manila director Jose Rodriguez and foreign affairs secretary Raul Manglapus, before the paper became defunct at the beginning of the 2000s. It featured news items and opinions.

In English, the essay as a genre eventually merged with journalism, especially with the feature article, reportage, and the opinion column. Before and after World War II, F. B. Icasiano, using the byline Mang Kiko for his column My Nipa Hut in the Sunday Tribune Magazine, wrote with gentle humor about Chinamen, handbags, and barrio life. Francisco Arcellana’s column in This Week in the 1940s, Through a Glass, Darkly, was a cross between the personal essay and literary criticism. Juan T. Gatbonton’s column pieces written from 1954 to 1958 and compiled in Little Reports, 1986, were modeled after E. B. White’s Notes and Comment in the New Yorker and showed the author’s sundry preoccupations, ranging from nuclear disaster, national politics, to clock watching. Amando Dayrit in his column Good Morning, Judge satirized current events both major and minor.

Emilio Aguilar Cruz wrote historical and cultural vignettes, compiled in Maynila and Other Explorations, 1978. Napoleon G. Rama’s editorials have been compiled in A Time in the Life of the Filipino, 1990.

Nick Joaquin, using the pseudonym Quijano de Manila when he was writing as a journalist for the Philippines Free Press in the 1950s and 1960s, practically started a whole genre with his reportage and character sketches, using fictional elements and devices like characterization, dialogue, atmosphere, and a classical plot. These were collected in the 1970s in eight books, among them Amalia Fuentes and Other Etchings, Doveglion and Other Cameos, Gloria Diaz and Other Delineations, and Nora Aunor and Other Profiles, all published in 1977, and later Reportage on the Marcoses, 1964-1970, 1979, Reportage on Crime: Thirteen Horror Happenings That Hit the Headlines, 1981, and Language of the Street and Other Essays, 1980.

This tradition of reportage was continued by journalist-poet Jose Lacaba Jr in his Days of Disquiet, Nights of Rage, 1986, and journalist-fictionist Ninotchka Rosca in Endgame, 1987, who through her storytelling chronicled the death of Sen Benigno Aquino Jr, the rise of the underground revolution, and the fall of Ferdinand Marcos following the events of EDSA.

Joaquin also wrote popular essays on culture and history, beginning with “La Naval de Manila” in 1943. This essay expressed a theme that would surface again and again in his literary works: that Filipino identity could be defined only if its Hispanic heritage were acknowledged. His other essays in this regard, written between the 1950s and 1980s, would be collected in Culture and History: Occasional Notes on the Process of Philippine Becoming, 1988, and A Question of Heroes, 1981.

Editorials or feature articles with a literary quality were written by poet-essayist-fictionist Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, whose column pieces in various dailies and magazines were collected in My Personal Chronicle: 1971-1987, 1990; Amadis Ma. Guerrero, whose travel pieces were collected in Traveler’s Choice: From North to South, 1993, and The Manila I Knew, 1997; Adrian Cristobal, whose essays for the Sunday Globe were collected in Pasquinades, 1993; and Gregorio Brillantes, whose nonfiction works have been collected in three volumes: Looking for Jose Rizal in Madrid: Journeys, Latitudes, Perspectives, Destinations, 2005, Chronicles of Interesting Times: Essays, Discourses, Gems of Wisdom, Some Laughs and Other Non-Biodegradable Articles, 2005, and The Cardinal’s Sins, the General’s Cross, the Martyr’s Testimony and Other Affirmations, 2005.

Recto’s last book of essays in English before his death, My Crusade, was published in 1955. It includes the piece “Our Mendicant Foreign Policy,” now a classic nationalist critique of postwar Philippine-American relations. Following in the tradition of political analyses with nationalistic overtones that he and Salvador P. Lopez had borne are Renato Constantino’s The Filipinos in the Philippines, 1966, Insight and Foresight, 1977, and Neocolonial Identity and Counter-Consciousness, 1978; Fr Horacia de la Costa’s The Background of Nationalism, 1965, and Asia and the Philippines, 1967; Petronilo Bn. Daroy’s Against the National Grain, 1966; Jose Ma. Sison’s The Struggle for National Democracy, 1967; Amado Guerrero’s (pseud.) Philippine Society and Revolution, 1971; Amando Doronila’s editorials; Onofre D. Corpuz’s two-volume The Roots of the Filipino Nation, 1989; Vivencio Jose’s scholarly works on the educational system, folklore, and history, like The Rise and Fall of Antonio Luna, 1972; and Luis Teodoro Jr’s The Summer of Our Discontent, 1990.

Covering both the domestic and public spheres were the women columnists. Pura Santillan Castrence’s columns collected in Woman Sense, 1998, and As I See It, 2006, consisted of insightful comments on domestic affairs and current trends. Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil’s Woman Enough and Other Essays, 1963, A Question of Identity, 1973, and The Philippines and the Filipinos, 1977, dealt with Philippine history, culture, and politics. Whatever, 2002, collected her editorial page columns from Philippine dailies from 1987 to 2001 about various people, places, and controversies. Kerima Polotan in Author’s Choice, 1970, and in Adventures in a Forgotten Country, 1975, wrote with acerbic wit about the hypocrisies of press people and politicians, and the varying roles of woman as family driver, mother, and mother-to-be. Her autobiographical essays are collected in The True and the Plain, 2005.

The group Women Writers in Media Now or WOMEN, formed in 1981, provided women writers, many of them essayists and journalists, a platform for their work, publishing Filipina 1, 1984, and Filipina 2, 1985, many of which offer critical perspectives on current events. Some of the writers went on to produce collections of their works. Sylvia Mayuga’s first book, Spy in My Own Country, 1981, records with vivid immediacy the images of the martial law period. Her Earth, Fire and Air, 1992, recounts the end of the Marcos regime and other concerns of the 1980s. Asuncion David-Maramba’s View from the Middle, 1991, begins with “A Call to Closet Nationalists,” triggered by the Aquino assassination, and ranges over a variety of commonplace topics that represent Filipino culture. Ceres Doyo, who specializes in investigative reporting, has collected her works in Journalist in Her Own Country: Articles, Essays, and Photographs, 1980-1992, 1993. Jo-Ann Maglipon merges political analysis with human interest in Primed: Selected Stories, 1972-1992.

There are still other women essayists, many of whom have collected their feature articles, columns, and profiles: Dolores Feria’s The Long Stag Party, 1991, and Red Pencil, Blue Pencil, 1991, consist of travel writing, book reviews, commentaries on the educational system, and feminist studies. Doris Trinidad’s Looking Glass, 1991, and Zeneida Amador’s Exits and Entrances, 1991, are collections of their column pieces, which are insightful pieces on ordinary experiences. Rosario A. Garcellano’s Mean Streets, 1991, consists of travel essays, character sketches, nostalgic pieces, musings about casual encounters, and articles about women and womanhood. Barbara C. Gonzalez’s How Do You Know Your Pearls Are Real?, 1991, is a collection of narrative essays on personal and domestic relationships from a self-sufficient woman’s point of view. The subjects of Neni Sta. Romana Cruz’s essays, a number collected in Sundays of Our Lives, 1995, range from the domestic to the political. Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s The Last Full Moon: Lessons on My Life, 2005, is the author’s celebration of her 75th year, detailing familiar places, beloved people, and the writing life with her signature light hand and humor.

In Filipino, Lilia F. Antonio’s ST: Mga Sanaysay at mga Tula (ST: Essays and Poems), 2003, is a collection of personal narratives meant to compare aspects of Filipino lifestyle, behavior, and culture, with respective Japanese counterparts. Written after her stint as a researcher and academic based in Japan in the early 2000s, the collection includes informal comparative studies that are short guides to dealing with the Japanese. The essays address both similarities and differences between the countries. Also in Filipino, Glecy C. Atienza’s Mukhang Maarte (Looks Fussy), 2003, includes “Liham sa Freshman” (An Open Letter to University Freshmen), a didactic essay on what college freshmen should expect on their first year of university life in the 1980s. Although closely following the tradition of Urbana at Feliza (Urbana and Feliza), 1864, the piece comes to the reader also as historical document, recording familiar circumstances and concerns for students after 20 years.

The journalistic profile is the speciality of Marra PL. Lanot, whose collections of this type include Dream Sketches, 1991; The Trouble with Nick and Other Profiles, 1999; Déjà Vu and Other Essays, 1999; and Darna and Other Idols, 2012. Some of her subjects are presidential daughters, show business personalities, and female models of courage. Specializing in travel and autobiographical writing is Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo, who has compiled her essays about experiences in various countries in the following books: Sojourns, 1984; Korean Sketchbook, 1987; Five Years in a Forgotten Land, 1991; I Remember, 1992; Passages, 2008; and Looking for the Philippines, 2009.

Travel writing merges with autobiography in the “We Know” books published by Anvil Publishing, which include The Manila We Knew, 2006, edited by Erlinda Enriquez Panlilio, The Baguio We Know, 2009, edited by Grace Celeste T. Subido; The Cebu We Know, 2009, edited by Erma M. Cuizon; The Davao We Know, 2011, edited by Lolita Lacuesta; The Dumaguete We Know, 2012, edited by Merlie M. Alunan; and The Naga We Know, 2013, edited by Paz Verdades M. Santos and Kristian Sendon Cordero. The personal histories of the residents or once-residents are a medium by which local customs and histories are explored and critiqued. Writers who have contributed to the series include Cecilia Manguerra Brainard, Lawrence Ypil, Erma M. Cuizon, Hope S. Yu, Erlinda Kintanar-Alburo, Rolando B. Tolentino, Karla P. Delgado, Michael L. Tan, Myrna Peña Reyes, Lakambini A. Sitoy, Alfred A. Yuson, Susan S. Lara, Christine Godinez-Ortega, Marjorie Evasco, Tita Lacambra Ayala, Karl M. Gaspar, Aida Rivera-Ford, and Macario D. Tiu.

The sense of locating the self firmly in the space and time of a home is explored as a common theme in Writing Home: Nineteen Writers Remember Their Hometowns, 2002, with essays from Jose Y. Dalisay Jr, Doreen Fernandez, Cesar Ruiz Aquino, Luisa A. Igloria, Auraeus Solito, Jose F. Lacaba, Eileen R. Tabios, Alfred A. Yuson, Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo, and Gilda Cordero-Fernando, among others. A later collection from de Vera, Connecting Flights: Filipinos Write from Elsewhere, 2010, measures various encounters from locations all over the world against what is familiar to the Filipino’s consciousness. The book features essays from Dean Francis Alfar, Lourd de Veyra, Angelo Lacuesta, Ambeth Ocampo, Charlson Ong, Danilo M. Reyes, Joel M. Toledo, and Jessica Zafra, among others.

Meanwhile, personal narratives from Filipino writers in the diaspora detail their experiences abroad, in transit, and upon returning to the homeland. Some themes present are the negotiation of the traveler’s personal and social identity as part of different communities, and the process of negotiating a unique space for the self. Such are what one finds in Growing into Asia, 2001, by Susan Evangelista, an American married to a Filipino, noting the places where she does or does not “belong” in, and An Isteytsayd Life: Not-So-Random Thoughts from a Pinoy Living in America, 2010, by Lorenzo D. Paran III, who reflects on crossing sociocultural borders in America, connecting with other Filipinos in foreign spaces, and experiencing the restlessness that comes with traveling between two “homelands.”

Food writing has come to constitute a subgenre. Doreen G. Fernandez and Edilberto Alegre have collaborated on Sarap (Pleasure), 1988, a collection of essays on Filipino food and culture; and Kinilaw: A Philippine Cuisine of Freshness, 1991, an exhaustive study of one kind of dish, covering its history, geographical range, types, condiments, and so forth. Alegre went on to write Inuming Pinoy (Filipino Drink), 1994, and Fernandez, Tikim (Taste), 1994, and Palayok (Clay Pot), 2000, both books relating aspects of Philippine food to history and local culture. Savor the Word, 2012, is a collection of the essays of the recipients of the annual Doreen Gamboa Fernandez Food Writing Award instituted after her death in 2002. Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s Philippine Food and Life, 1992, brings to the fore the cuisines of the Luzon provinces in essays about iconic dishes, popular establishments, cooking methods, and important cultural practices. Felice Prudente Sta. Maria’s work in food history is in The Governor-General’s Kitchen: Philippine Culinary Vignettes and Period Recipes, 1521-1935, 2006, and The Foods of Jose Rizal, 2012, and the anthology Slow Food: Philippine Culinary Traditions, 2005, co-edited by Erlinda Enriquez Panlilio.

Filipino culture, society, and politics are the subjects of Arnold Azurin’s essays, collected in Just Vexations, 1990. Resil B. Mojares has done much to sustain Filipino awareness of the history, culture, and literature of the southern Philippines through his columns and his scholarly studies, compiled in House of Memory, 1997, and Isabelo’s Archive, 2012. Streets of Manila, 1977, by Luning Ira and Isagani R. Medina and with photographs from Nik Ricio, illustrates the rich history of the lines and corners familiar to Intramuros, Tondo, Binondo, Quiapo, Sampaloc, and the other districts of Manila, describing the origins of their names and providing commentaries on structures and landmarks.

In 1981, the publishing outfit Gilda Cordero-Fernando (GCF) Books, Manila, began producing coffee-table books featuring personal narratives. Among these was Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s Being Filipino, 1981, collecting pieces from Nicanor G. Tiongson, Lorna Kalaw Tirol, Fernando Nakpil Zialcita, and Virgilio S. Almario, to name a few. The 18-essay anthology collects pieces that reconstruct the Filipina via popular roles she plays, including mother, mistress, lover, lesbian, ex-wife, spinster, and widow. In 1983, GCF Books introduced Household Antiquities and Heirlooms by Felice Sta. Maria and Ben A. Laxina, edited by Gilda Cordero-Fernando, with essays by Belinda Olivares-Cunanan, Alfredo Roces, and Genuine Santos. This exhaustive companion for any antique-hunter is a comprehensive guide to the contents of a typical Philippine townhouse of the 19th and 20th centuries. Performing their chief function as a guide, the accompanying personal essays highlight the users and owners of some featured antiques, lending a deeply personal and nostalgic tone to the entire book. Roces’s contribution, “Serendipity Days in Ermita,” reconstructs the famous district at the height of its local art trade, when the business generated by elite members of the oligarchy invited enterprising fakers to reproduce and pirate one-of-a-kind pieces. Another book on the GCF roster is The History of the Burgis, 1987, by Mariel Nepomuceno Francisco and Fe Maria C. Arriola. Tracing the history of the “burgis” (the bourgeois), the book covers the Spanish occupation up until the abolition of martial law. Arriola and Francisco’s history is enriched by the addition of newspaper articles and satirical cartoons.

Gay liberation has found a representative writer in Tony Perez, whose book Cubao 1980 at Iba Pang mga Katha (Cubao 1980 and Other Works), 1992, meditates among other things on homosexuality and homosexual relationships. J. Neil C. Garcia’s Closet Queeries, 1997, and Danton Remoto’s X-Factor, 1997, tackle issues such as gender stereotyping, sexual health and politics, belief systems in the context of sexual identity, and gay relationships. Ronald Baytan’s The Queen Lives Alone, 2012, expresses the author’s thoughts on being gay in a Chinese-Filipino context. The everyday encounters and colloquialisms present in queer life are handled with humor in Louie Cano’s Pamhinta X: Mga Nagbabagang Sanaysay (Straight Acting: Smoldering Essays), 2012.

A trend that started in the 1990s and continues into the present is the compilations of newspaper or magazine columns. These compilations cover a broad range of subjects—Philippine politics (Conrado de Quiros’s Flowers from the Rubble, 1990, and Dance of the Dunces, 1991), ideology and postcolonialism (F. Sionil Jose’s Why We Are Poor: Heroes in the Attic, Termites in the Sala, 2005, and Why We Are Hungry: Rats in the Kitchen, Carabaos in the Closet, 2008), popular culture (Jessica Zafra’s Twisted series, 1995-2011), arts and literature (Cirilo F. Bautista’s The House of True Desire: Essays on Life and Literature, 2010), the quirks and the ordinariness of life (Alfredo Yuson’s Confessions of a Q. C. House-husband, 1991, and Jose Y. Dalisay Jr’s The Best of Barfly, 1997), personal relationships (Rica Bolipata-Santos’s Lost and Found, 2010), and historical vignettes (Ambeth Ocampo’s Looking Back, 1990, and Rizal without the Overcoat, 1990, among other collections)—and show a variety of writing styles ranging from the satirical to the lyrical.

A series called Youngblood, 1998-2006, derives from a weekly column of the same title, begun in 1994, in the Philippine Daily Inquirer. The columns are chosen from submissions written by children as young as 10 to young adults. The first compilation, The Best of Youngblood, 1998, consists of columns grouped into five themes: identity formation as a Filipino Gen-Xer, relationships, moving into or out of a place or social class, professional life, books and miscellaneous objects representative of a generation’s shared adolescence. Youngblood 2.0, 2000, and Youngblood 3, 2006, seek to capture experiences from a fresh, contemporary perspective and to situate and reveal young writers and their concerns.

The writer’s memoir is an important subgenre of the essay. Bienvenido N. Santos revisits his childhood, adulthood, and career as writer and teacher in Memory’s Fictions: A Personal History, 1993. Paz Marquez Benitez: One Woman’s Life, Letters, and Writings, 1995, is unique in combining extracts from Paz Marquez Benitez’s personal writings and her daughter Virginia Benitez Licuanan’s memories of her. Rene O. Villanueva takes memory as his central concern in his memoir Personal: Mga Sanaysay sa Lupalop ng Gunita (Personal: Essays from the Realm of Remembrance), 1999. Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil’s trilogy of books—Myself, Elsewhere, 2006; Legends and Adventures, 2007; Heroes and Villains, 2010—vividly reconstructs the milieu of Manila from the American colonial period to the Marcos years and beyond while telling her life story, showing the intertwining of personal and social narratives. Gemino Abad situates himself in the different roles of student, teacher, writer, husband, and father in Imagination’s Way: Essays Critical and Personal, 2010.

Episodes in Philippine history provide the framework for some memoirs. Lourdes Montinola’s Breaking the Silence, 1996, and Pacita Pestaño’s Living with the Enemy, 1999, are war memoirs. Nita Umali Berthelsen’s The Tayabas Chronicles, 2002, edited by Karen Berthelsen Cardenas, is based on the recollections, written in Spanish, of Ma. Concepcion Herrera of turn-of-the-century Quezon Province. Subversive Lives, 2012, by Suan Quimpo and Nathan Gilbert Quimpo, is a family history set during martial law.

Women’s narratives are collected in Telling Lives: Essays by Filipino Women, 1992, edited by Elizabeth Lolarga and Anna Leah Sarabia, which shows the sensibilities of Filipino writers as women, shaped by the inspiration of other women. More narratives of both professional and nonprofessional women writers were collected by Lorna Kalaw-Tirol in Coming to Terms, 1994; Women on Fire, 1997; and Primed for Life, 1997, on the subject of midlife.

Essayists after World War II writing in Cebuano included Martin Abellana, whose essay collection is Sentido Komon (Common Sense), 1980; Flaviano Boquecosa; Francisco Candia; and D. M. Estabaya. Notable essayists writing in Cebuano today include Ernesto D. Lariosa, whose ongoing daily SunStar column Tunob sa Dila (Footsteps on the Tongue) unapologetically reveals and celebrates Cebuano humor and wit; Richel Dorotan; and Januar Yap.

Essayists in Cebu found their audience primarily through newspaper columns, also collecting and republishing chosen works as anthologies. Examples include Erma Cuizon’s Time of the Year, 1999, culled from her column in SunStar Weekend, and Vital Flow, 2001, likewise a collection of pieces previously published in her SunStar Sunday column. Revealing the scope of these collections and, in turn, the tractability of the essay form, Cuizon covers a wide range of topics and issues: anecdotes culled from her early life, short profiles about friends and strangers, lyrical descriptions of Cebu and neighboring islands, and critiques of cultural practices. Likewise, poet Simeon Dumdum Jr, who has been regularly publishing short, personal essays for the Cebu Daily News, has produced two essay collections. Dumdum’s first collection, Love in the Time of the Camera: Essays on Various Aspects of a Sad, Funny, Exasperating but Altogether Lovable and Photogenic World, 1998, won the 2002 National Book Award. It collects Dumdum’s musings on space, tiny or everyday objects, and reflections about the city in which he lives and the people who live there with him. This collection is followed by My Pledge of Love Cannot Be Broken and Other Essays on, Alas, More Fragile and Edible Things, 2002.

In Kapampangan are Vicente B. Catacutan’s Ing Pamilyang Cristiana (The Christian Family), and Vedasto D. Ocampo’s Ing Capampangan, Napun, Ngeni, at Bukas (The Kapampangan, Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow).

Some of the Ilocano essayists since World War II are Marcelino Foronda Jr, Hermogenes Belen, Benjamin Pascual, Narciso Gapusan, Juan S. P. Hidalgo Jr, and Paul Zafaralla. In Ilocano, the personal narrative began and has remained firmly within the public sphere, as it finds its audience primarily through widely distributed periodicals. Bannawag was instrumental in establishing a readership for the personal essay. Under the editorship of Dionisio S. Bulong, Bannawag began publishing short personal essays organized in several categories, including the Dakami Met (Letters to the Editor) and Greg Laconsay’s Dap-ayan ti Bannawag ni Manong Greg (Bannawag’s Forum—to Manong Greg), through which he offered advice on personal problems. His columns were markedly humorous, revealing a common sense. Bannawag was also a springboard for writers like Hermilinda L. Bulong, Reynaldo A. Duque, and Clarita Sumahit.

In Ilonggo, an interest in the local language and culture was sustained after World War II by Santiago Alv. Mulato, Conrado J. Norada, Loreto Angayen, Raymundo Defante Sr, and, until his death, Ramon Muzones. Abe S. Gonzales, Inocencio Ferrer, Ariston Echevarria, Antonio H. Joquiño, and Eddy La. Gonzales were some feature writers and columnists. Besides essays, Ernesto Nietes also made up proverbs and epigrams. Columns in Yuhum magazine were Candido J. Oller’s "Palihug," ang "Sinamak" (Pass the Vinegar, Please) and Bel Sobrevega’s Langkay sa Kabuhi (Meat of Life). Since its revival in 1989, Hiligaynon magazine has continued to be a venue for essays in Ilonggo.

In Davao, the Davao Writers Guild, headed by Ricardo M. de Ungria, currently publishes essays in Dagmay, its literary journal. Young writers from Davao have since found opportunities to showcase their works in the quarterly and annual publications, in the Sunday supplement of SunStar Davao, and online through the official site of Dagmay. The Best of Dagmay: 2007-2009, 2010, collects essays from some of the region’s most promising authors.

If its course in the last 20 years is any indication, then the essay will continue to survive and thrive by addressing the needs of its readers, who consume it alongside other forms of literature. The diversity of its writers and the concerns that they address enables the essay to knit together macro or public concerns with private feeling and memory in recording, critiquing, and celebrating the Filipino experience.
