text:
The folk narrative may be any story, tale, account, or reconstruction, told in prose among the people of a cultural group or a national community, based on some past event which is either accepted as fictional or believed to have some historical basis. Passed down from generation to generation, it takes on various functions in the lives of the people in the community. It is called kuwentong bayan in Tagalog, sugilanon in the Visayan languages, sarita in Ilocano, sussur/sutsut/tudtud/appoyaw in Isinay, and tuturan in Batak.

There are three general types of folk narratives: myths, legends, and folktales. Myths are considered to have a validating purpose in society: they are commonly regarded as vehicles of transmitted values, beliefs, and practices, and are therefore held sacred. Legends narrate extraordinary events in a society’s past, and are sometimes believed to have actually happened, because they often serve to explain the origin of objects, places, or phenomena, or educate people about lessons derived from certain human experiences. In contrast, folktales are not regarded as moral dogma or sacred truth requiring belief. The events that folktales narrate may or may not have happened, and generally occur in an indefinite time and place. Furthermore, they are told primarily for entertainment, although they also have instructional value, as in the case of religious and didactic tales, as well as animal fables that play up the conflict between positive and negative values by presenting a world parallel to that of human society. Folktales are almost always idealistic in content and often have a happy ending.

 

Myth

A myth is a prose narrative explaining how the world and people came to be in their present form, as well as recounting the origins of ceremonies and cultural norms and taboos. It is usually associated with theology, religion, and ritual. It is called alamat in Tagalog, gugud or batbat in Bukidnon, and ituan in Mandaya. An origin myth is called babarawon in Mansaka, usulan kissa in Tausug, and tuturan at kagunggurangan in Palawan. A creation myth is called kaawn kisa in Mansaka. An oggood is a mythological narrative about the Bontok culture hero Lumawig. A recited, rather than chanted, narrative in the current Bukidnon idiom about the epic hero Agyu is called mantukaw.

The characters in a myth include beings in the supernatural or spirit world and beings in the world of people. Thus, deities, gods, goddesses, ancestral spirits, male and female culture heroes, sacred animals and objects, and supernatural phenomena may coexist in the world of myth. The early Filipinos believed in one supreme god and in a number of lesser gods, with each ethnolinguistic group having its own version of a supernatural hierarchy and its relationships with the world of human beings. Thus, the “supreme being” is called a variety of names in Philippine mythology: Bathala (Tagalog), Mangetchay (Kapampangan), Gugurang (Bikol), Lumauig or Kabunian (Bontok), Liddum (Ifugao), Mahal Makaako (Mangyan), Laon (Visayan), Magbabaya (Bukidnon), Melu (Blaan), Makalidung (Manobo), Manama (Manuvu), Ampu (Palawan), and Apo Namalyari (Aeta).

Myths about Filipino gods depict them either in conflict or falling in love with each other, or else they are shown descending on the earth to intermarry with mortals. In a Bukidnon myth, a god sends an airship called salimbal to earth in order to bring up his chosen people to the sky world, led by their culture hero Agyu (Sitoy 1937, 445-46, 465-66). A Bikol myth recounts the conflict between the good god Gugurang and the evil god Asuang when the latter attempts to steal fire from the former (Beyer 1923). The Bontok of Mountain Province have a myth that validates the tribe’s pechen (peace pact). It tells of the conflict between the warrior god Chacha and the blacksmith god Ked-yem. After Ked-yem kills Chacha’s sons, the two engage in a fierce battle. Finally, they reconcile and become friends again (Cawed 1972, 51-52).

An idyllic love affair is that between Captan, god of the land breezes, and Maguayan, goddess of the sea breezes. On the spot where Captan and Maguayan consummated their love, a bamboo plant grows, and from it emerge the first man and woman. Another love affair is that between the sun god and a sea nymph, which eventually leads to the creation of the island of Cebu. An Igorot myth recounts how Mayingit, son of the god of thunder, falls in love with a mortal maiden named Bugan, and begets a child with her. He does not stay to live with them, but comes down every now and then when his help is needed, as when Bugan gives birth to their baby, and later when he implants parts of his body into his young son to make the boy practically invincible in war. The mythical epic of the southern Palawan highland group tells how the superhero Kudaman, blest with godly power in love and combat, defeats all his enemies, and woos the 10 loveliest goddesses in the world.

Origin myths explain a great variety of phenomena—the creation of the world, of people, of land and water features, of plants and animals. Philippine myths give three versions of the creation of the world. In some myths, the world was created by a supreme being out of dust and other material. In other myths, the world came to be as a result of conflict between opposing forces, as in the story of the cosmic battle between the sky and the sea, which led to the formation of islands. A third group of myths is more fanciful, such as the Mangyan and Sulod myths which give an account of how the world was formed from the feces of a worm.

The origin of people is also given varying accounts in the myths. One group attributes the creation of man and woman to the work of a supreme being. A second group sees the first man and woman emerging, fully formed, from two internodes of a bamboo split open by the pecking beak of a bird (Visayan), or from two stumps of a banana plant (Igorot), or from two hatching eggs (Mandaya). And a third group of myths tells us that the first inhabitant of the earth actually descended from the sky world. In an Ifugao myth, the first man and woman were children of Kabigat of the sky world. This god had sent his two children to the earth world to populate it.

 

Creation myths contain scattered references that indicate the early Filipinos’ conception of the universe. This universe consists of the sky world, the earth or middle world, and the underworld. To the Kiangan Ifugao, the layer we live on is the earth world luta; the four layers above us constitute the sky world daya; and beneath the one we live on is the underworld dalom, which has an unknown number of layers. The Maranao also believe in a complex universe where the earth and sky are divided into seven layers each. This is similar to the Palawan belief that the universe is a vertical structure of realms, a series of seven ascending and seven descending “plates.” Human beings live in the middle of this structure, in the dunya. The Tboli similarly believe that the sky is composed of seven layers, on the highest of which dwells their god. The Blaan, on the other hand, believe in a nine-layered universe which has the shape of two bowls set rim to rim to form a spherical whole (Casal 1978, 122-23).

Early Filipinos believed that once upon a time, the sky was low, and there are myths to explain how and why the sky went up to where it is now. According to the Bagobo myth, the sky used to be very near the earth’s surface, but it raised itself after the mythical woman, Tuglibong, complained that she kept hitting the sky’s underbelly when she pounded rice (Benedict 1913, 13-63). Philippine mythology has accounts of the great deluge, a universal theme in world folklore. In myths from the Mountain Province, the great flood happens in some distant past, and the survivors are always a brother and sister who find themselves stranded on top of two separate mountains, and who face the task of repopulating the world. In myths from the Visayas and Mindanao, the survivors are couples who become the ancestors of different ethnic groups.

There are also myths about different kinds of natural phenomena. Some myths explain the origin of rain. A Panay myth tells that rain is Tungkung Langit’s tears of longing for his wife Alunsina (Jocano 1959, 38). Among the Ibanag, rain is believed to be the tears shed by people who were imprisoned in the clouds by a powerful giant after they had disobeyed his rule (Bangan 1976, 264-65). There are also myths explaining the rainbow, lightning, thunder, earthquakes, and eclipses.

Myths explaining the origin of geographical features, of plants and animals and their characteristics, employ a variety of motifs. Many of them center on the fate of faithful lovers. A river in Mindoro called Mag-asawang Tubig (literally, “wedded water”), for instance, is said to have miraculously sprung from the graves of a couple who were so devoted to each other they prayed they would be together even after death. A waterfall named Bridal Veil is said to have been formed to commemorate a dramatic event: once, an angry stepmother poured down water on her stepdaughter and her lover while they were sliding down a vine to elope. The coconut tree, meanwhile, sprang from the grave of a young man who was killed and buried by his rival in the garden of his sweetheart.

There are myths explaining the origin of mountains and volcanoes. The bones of people who died in the tribal war that broke out between the Blaan and the Manobo formed the Buntud Tulan (literally, “hill bones”) in South Cotabato (Lutero 1986, 45). Mount Mayon is said to have risen from the grave of the ill-fated lovers Daragang Magayon and Ulap (Espinas 1968, 248-50).

There are myths explaining the origin of technics and cultural practices, such as the discovery of fire. The Manuvu believe that the deity of fire, Pamulingan, taught the people how to make fire (Manuel 1977, 5). The Ilocano say that their hero Lam-ang stole fire from the giants guarding it and brought it to men (Coronel 1967, 178-81). Rituals  and customs are likewise explained by various myths. According to the Bontok Igorot, the practice of head-hunting began when the Moon beheaded the son of the Sun, who was watching her as she was making copper pots. After bringing his son back to life, the Sun told the Moon that because she had beheaded his son, from then on, the people on Earth would cut off each other’s heads (Jenks 1905, 221-22). The Isneg have a myth explaining the religious significance of the art of tattooing. Tattooing enables one’s soul to reach Paradise, as the ferryman of the underworld will only carry the deceased person’s soul if he is tattooed on the right parts of his body (Reynolds and Grant 1973, 315-16). 

The transformation motif is dominant in origin myths. In many myths, animals are said to have been formerly human beings. In most cases, the transformation serves as a punishment for human misdeeds. Thus, the shark was actually once upon a time a rich, greedy, rapacious man who was transformed into a water predator by the god of the sea. The crocodile used to be an evil, four-eyed brother of a sultan who victimized women. The transformation of a human being into a plant also occurs in myth, but here the change often is an act of mercy from God: in answer to a prayer, as in the story of the pine tree and the dama de noche; or to save the heroine from harm, as in the story of the makahiya (sensitive plant). Transformation need not mean a change from one state to another. In the myth of the rice, the staple is said to have been a food solely for the gods in the beginning, but the gods eventually and in varying ways allowed it to be shared with human beings.

 

Legend

This form goes by various terms in the Philippines: alamat (Tagalog), osipon (Bikol), sarita (Ilocano), istorya (Pangasinan), kasugiran or sumatanon (Cebuano), gintunaan (Ilonggo), kissa (Tausug), kabbata (Ivatan), tutul sa pakapoon (Maranao), and so on.

Legends are believed to be truthful accounts of what happened in the recent past. They are often more secular than sacred and the characters are principally human. They are regarded as verbal counterparts of written history. In terms of subject matter, Philippine legends may be classified into the following groups: heroic and historical, religious, supernatural, toponymic, and miscellaneous.

Heroic and historical legends are accounts of episodes in the lives of great women and men: culture heroes, epic heroes, prominent men and women, and individuals possessing extraordinary power or gifts. The Muslim groups of southern Philippines have genealogical narratives tracing the noble descent of certain individuals. These are called tarsila by the Maguindanaon and salsila by the Tausug and the Sama. The Manobo’s historical accounts are called guhud. From the north are culture heroes like Angngalo of the Ilocano, Biuag and Malana of the Ibanag, and Bayun of the Gaddang, none of whom figures in epic narratives and only appear in legends.

There are legends about Jose Rizal which underscore his unusual qualities as a “renaissance man” with multiple callings: painter, doctor, swordsman, scientist, novelist, patriot. In one legend, Rizal was said to possess superhuman feats. A day after he was executed in Luneta, the governor-general ordered his coffin opened so that his body could be searched for an important document. Instead of the hero’s body, what the inspectors found in the coffin was a banana trunk (Angeles 1911, 77). That legend is among several on which is based the popular belief that Rizal is still alive and will return to liberate the country from foreign invaders.

There are also legends about earlier culture heroes, such as Palaris, the leader of a Pangasinan uprising early in the Spanish rule; Datu Sumakwel, who was among the legendary 10 Bornean datus who settled in Panay; and Lapulapu, native chieftain of Mactan whose forces defeated Ferdinand Magellan. Still an object of discussion among social scientists is the historical provenance of Urduja, the woman warrior whom the Pangasinan folk claim as their own and whose image has been perpetuated in local literature as an emblem of feminist consciousness (Nelmida-Flores 2001, 98).

Religious legends recount the miraculous manifestations of God and the Christian saints. The greatest number of legends in this group is those recounting the miracles performed by the Birheng Maria or Mary, followed by the Santo Niño. There are even joint articles performed by Mary and other saints, such as Santa Clara and San Pascual Baylon. In Obando, Mary reigns as a patron saint together with the two, and she is known as Nuestra Señora de Salambao. The miracle for which the trio is famous is that of rewarding kind childless couples with offspring. Legends also record the individual miracles performed by Mary in her various shrines all over the country: Santo Domingo Church (Manila), Antipolo (Rizal), Caysasay (Batangas), Manaoag (Pangasinan), Piat (Cagayan), Naga (Camarines Sur), and Zamboanga. The Santo Niño figures in his own legends: he plays a prank on a fish vendor, he keeps a poor, old dying woman provided with rice, and so on.

There is a wide variety of supernatural beings encountered in Philippine legends. Tradition has led the folk to believe in the existence of “underworld characters,” such as the aswang, kapre (black, hairy giant with a large cigar), duwende (gnome or troll), engkanto (fairy), santelmo (dancing ball of fire), tiyanak (goblin believed to be the spirit of an infant who died unbaptized), tikbalang (witch with a horse’s neck, head, and hoofs), in addition to the devil, ghosts, mermaids, and assorted strange beings. In some of these legendary encounters between human and supernatural beings, no harm comes to the victim beyond fright, but in other cases, the meeting could be fatal. In the legend about Maypajo, a mother loses her daughter to a nuno sa punso, a gnome who dwells in an earth mound. The creature takes a fancy to the girl and abducts her. The mother dies from grief and exhaustion, as she digs away at the earth mound with her bare hands in a futile attempt to retrieve her daughter.

Some engkanto and engkantada (sprites, fairies, enchanted ones) are beneficent creatures, the best known being Mariang Makiling of the Tagalog, Mariang Sinukuan of the Kapampangan, and Maria Cacao of the Visayan. They are female figures who are said to be beautiful and rich, and who prove to be generous in their dealings with human beings. For some reason or other, but mostly because of disillusionment, they withdraw from contact with human society.

A popular form of legend is the toponymic one, or that which explains the origin of names of places. In these legends, folk etymology is seen in the ways of place naming. The first and most common one is naming a place after people, such as lovers and friends. Thus, Mariveles in Bataan is said to have come from the name of a nun named Maria Velez, who eloped with a Franciscan monk, much to the chagrin of the community. Mindoro supposedly comes from the names of two lovers, Mina and Doro, although a legend could have as easily been formed around the plausible theme of a land of gold mines, “mina de oro.” Maria Cristina Falls in Lanao owes its name to two sisters, Maria and Cristina.

A place may also be named after a plant abundant in that area. A town in Quezon may have been actually called Lukban because of the lukban (pomelo) trees growing there, and the succulent fruit that these bore. Miscommunication between native folk and descending or conquering foreigners is another source of place names. The name Calamba, a town in Laguna, is said to have stuck after a Spanish official thought a woman had given him the name of the place; the woman thought she had been asked the name of the jar she was selling. In some instances, the name of a place is merely the shortened form of something somebody is supposed to have uttered to someone else. Tagaytay is said to have been derived from the expression “Taga, Itay!” (Strike, Father!); Marikina, from the phrase “Marikit ka na” (You are now beautiful); and Mindanao, from “Amin danao dini” (There’s a lake here). Sometimes a place name describes a memorable event that is supposed to have occurred in that place. A humorous example is the place name Hinubuan (“stripped of underpants”), given to a river, bridge, and barrio in Marinduque. Legend has it that a girl had once lost part of her clothing while she was trying to free herself from the clutches of a white monkey. This may allude to an actual incident.

There are also legends that center on hidden, mysterious artifacts. Perhaps in recent history, the most famous buried treasure lore is that about the hidden gold of the Japanese general Tomoyuki Yamashita. Until now, the alleged war loot, which is believed to be hidden in underground tunnels and caverns, is the subject of popular speculation.

 

Folktales

Folktales are classified into animal tales or fables, magic tales, humorous tales, novelistic tales, religious and didactic tales. They are called kuwento by the Tagalog, sarita by the Ilocano, sudsud by the Kankanaey, istorya by the Ivatan, dimolat by the Ilongot, oman-oman by the Mandaya, tudtul by the Maguindanaon, nanangen by the Bukidnon, pangumanon or teterema by the Manobo, babatukon or human-human by the Mansaka, tutul by the Maranao, uliran by the Pangasinan, and katakata by the Sama and Tausug.

Fables are short tales that impart a lesson usually in morality and in virtue. Because the fable is a popular folk genre, the ideas contained in it normally reflect the ideas and values of ordinary people about the conduct of life. Among the homely virtues implicit or explicit in the message of fables are loyalty, gratitude, prudence, moderation, resignation, industry, thrift, and the like. The two essential parts of a fable are the narrative text and the normative message. Although the majority of fables are stories about animals, a few are about plants or natural elements, such as the sea, river, sun, and wind; some others are about human beings as well. The Maranao call their fables tutul a pangangayaman and stories about birds and fishes, tutul o manga suda ago papanok.

Many Philippine fables are a retelling or adaptation of Aesop’s fables, which were introduced in colonial times, and became widely circulated through the schools, having become part of children’s literary readings. Among these are the animal fables “The Crab and Its Mother,” in which the mother crab asks its young to walk straight when she herself cannot manage this impossible task; and “The Hawk and the Turtle,” in which a foolish turtle asks to be taken along by the hawk in the latter’s flight, only to be dropped and smashed on the ground. The Boholano plant fable, “The Mango Tree and the Lampakanay Grass,” echoes the fable about the boastful olive tree and the lowly but pliant reed, which teaches that one should bend before the storm in order to survive.

Other fables may have had Asian origins. One of the most loved tales, retold by Jose Rizal in the 19th century, is “The Monkey and the Turtle.” According to the story, a monkey climbs up a banana tree to get a bunch of bananas. He refuses to share the food with the turtle, who forthwith sticks spikes and thorns on the trunk. The monkey slides down the trunk and, howling in pain and anger, it proposes to throw the turtle into the river as a punishment for the prank. The turtle pleads in all earnestness to be punished in any other way but that, so the monkey, relishing revenge, proceeds to do exactly that. This suits the turtle perfectly and the latter swims happily away, having put one over the frustrated monkey. The famous moral derived from this fable has become a classic Tagalog proverb: “Matalino man ang matsing, napaglalalangan din” (The clever monkey can still be tricked).

 

 

Magical tales, also called fairy tales or märchen, are stories of fantasy and wonder, which take place in imaginary settings. Make-believe characters accomplish marvelous feats of heroism and bravery, usually after going through a series of difficulties, misfortunes, and ordeals. Toward the end, these characters succeed in their goal: to win the heart of a loved one, vanquish evil, rescue a kingdom, and live happily ever after in a land that never was. Such tales are told mainly to please and entertain, but they can assume a didactic stance, and therefore also impart a moral, the most universal one perhaps the idea that “love conquers all” or that “good triumphs over evil any time.” The magical tale is melodramatic in tone and in character. The protagonists are archetypes and few in number: male or female hero, friendly helpers or allies, and villain. There is no character development, as the hero is usually good and clever from beginning to end. However, what makes the magical tale exciting is the reversal of fortune in the lives of the characters. Poor but kindhearted persons may find themselves transformed into a prince or princess, king or queen at the end, while the arrogant rich and the oppressive villain might find themselves suddenly powerless. Usually, there would be a foil to the virtuous male or female hero.

The difficulties and tribulations that the leading characters undergo are exemplified by the experiences of the female hero in the Tausug tale “There Was a King,” in which six sisters hate and envy their youngest sister who is the most beautiful of them all. Sometimes, the hero has to confront not a relative or any other human being but a kind of supernatural adversary, such as a dragon in “The Adventures of Fortunato,” a witch in “Pedro and the Witch,” an ogre in “Suac and His Adventures,” or the devil himself in “The Reward of Kindness.”

The hero in the magic tale has to perform tasks, which constitute the central plot of the story. A common type of task is a quest or search for a certain person, place, or precious object. In the Visayan swan maiden story “Magboloto,” the hero goes in quest of his supernatural wife, who has flown back to her abode in the sky world. In “Juan del Mundo,” it is the female hero who goes out in search of her snake-husband who disappears when she breaks a taboo. In “Ang mga Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan” (Juan and His Adventures), the hero looks for his three sisters who have been taken away by a snake charmer, because of some offense committed by their father. He also searches for a lost princess kept captive by a giant. Similarly, “Ang Mahiwagang Singsing” (The Magic Ring) tells of the quest for a beautiful woman who lives in the “seventh gallery of heaven” and for the Goddess of the Sea who has “a star on her forehead and a moon on her neck.”

The accomplishment of tasks becomes a precondition for the satisfaction of the hero’s goals, whether those be marriage to the king’s daughter or preventing the loss of a loved one’s life. All the tasks imposed upon a hero range from the very difficult to the impossible, like spreading sesame seeds on the sand and gathering them up again or fetching a burning stone that a mountain dragon has in its possession. Sometimes, the story invests him with some help through the presence of auxiliary characters, who may be either ordinary human beings, such as a kind old woman or a hermit, or animal helpers or supernatural beings whom the hero wins over to his side. In Philippine tales, animal helpers are of various kinds: a fish who helps the hero recover a ring from the sea; an eagle who flies the hero to the sky world where his wife has been taken away to; a bird who obtains for the hero a ring from a princess; a horse, or even a runaway elephant, who takes care of the hero in the forest. In one story, the animal helpers are the animal brothers-in-law of the hero. Supernatural helpers may be friendly witches, a god or goddess, or a grateful dead man whose voices tell the hero what to do. In still another tale, the friendly helpers in the hero’s quest for his missing wife include the North Wind, South Wind, East Wind, and West Wind.

A magic object, analogous to an amulet or a talisman, is a usual device in magic tales used to create fantastic effects. This is passed on to the male or female hero by a friendly helper to help him or her triumph over danger and misfortune. In a Tagalog Cinderella-type tale, the helper she-crab tells the female hero to bury her shell in the yard, and from this shell a magic lukban wishing tree would grow. A husband, thinking of leaving home to get away from his shrewish wife, meets a hunchback who gives him three objects—a purse, a goat, and a table—which are all stolen from him by a deceitful friend who substitutes counterfeit articles for them. Finally, the hero is given a magic cane with which he beats up the deceitful friend and recovers the missing magic objects. In some tales, the magic object is given in exchange for some favor. In the Ilocano tale “Juan and the Bangar Tree,” a tree spirit gives the hero a magic pot as a reward for his not cutting down a tree that is its home. When the pot is stolen, the spirit gives him a purse, which is also stolen, and finally a drum, which he uses to recover the other objects. Other magic objects found in Philippine fairy tales are a cap that makes the wearer invisible, a pair of flying sandals, a key that opens all doors, a wishing ring, a magic handkerchief, a magic rope, and a magic nail.

Indigenous to Asia is one widespread magical tale, of which there are more than 30 versions all over the country, about a tiny hero. In the Tagalog version, his name is Carancal, deriving from the word dangkal (handspan), which is his height. Little though he may be, his appetite greatly alarms his parents, who try to get rid of him. He survives all attempts on his life and runs away from home. After several adventures through which he becomes wealthy, he reconciles with his parents (Fansler 1921, 17-23).

Humorous tales abound in Philippine folklore. There are generally two subtypes: numskull or noodlehead tales and trickster tales. Numskull tales narrate the funny, comic, absurd, occasionally pathetic, bumbling acts of a foolish person. In these tales, the audience is moved to feel pity or exasperation, or both, over the antihero’s misadventures and stupidities, which rain down disaster upon himself, even as it marvels at how he manages to survive all these. These stories, of which the Philippines seems to have an ample share, have become an endless source of fun and merriment in any gathering where they are told and retold. The most celebrated seems to be Juan Tanga, or Juan the Fool, a less cerebral version of the culture hero (or antihero), Juan Tamad, or Lazy Juan. Juan Tanga commits atrocious blunders. Told by his mother to choose a quiet woman for a wife, he brings home a dead woman. His mother tells him: “Those who smell bad are dead.” His mother farts, and he buries her. Sent to market to buy new earthen pots and some crabs, he punches holes into the pots and strings them up with a rattan vine for easier handling, and he releases the crabs into the water, instructing them to go to his house ahead of him.

Another type of numskull tale is the internationally known one about a gang of numskulls who miscount themselves. A Pangasinan version, “The Seven Crazy Fellows,” describes a madcap series of events. Seven fellows go fishing. When ready to go home, they count themselves, but the counter does not count himself, so they think one of them has drowned. They dive repeatedly for the “missing one.” An old man comes by and corrects them. He brings them along and gives them tasks to do, which they all bungle.

A stock character in numskull tales is the fool who takes things very literally. Told to “watch the palay” drying in the sun, a fool in a Sulu tale does exactly that—just watch, without bothering to drive away the ducks eating up the grains. Asked by his mother to “clear the yard,” a fool in another tale cuts down all the trees, shrubs, and vines in the yard, and burns them in a big heap.

Sometimes a numskull may develop into a clever character, or a trickster. In the story of Juan Tanga, the antihero is expelled from the town by the priest and ordered “never to set foot on the soil of that town again.” Juan buys a cart, fills it with red soil from another barrio, and rides back to town, telling the angry priest that the soil he is standing on is his own and not the soil of the town.

A trickster tale is one that narrates the doings of a central character who deceives or plays clever tricks on other people. The trickster may be a human or an animal. Human trickster heroes, like their animal counterpart, are forever hatching practical jokes on potential victims, or devising ways and means to get around obstacles put before them, usually by persons in authority. In many of these tales, the reader therefore empathizes with the trickster, who puts one over characters symbolizing power. Trickster tales are told mainly for amusement, although many people would hardly consider as amusing some of the tales that depict fatal consequences for the victim. Such humorous tales are called tutul a piya kakuyakayad by the Maranao.

Every region in the Philippines seems to have its own version of the proverbial trickster. The more popular ones are Juan, or Suan, of the Tagalog and Kapampangan, Juan Usong or Osong of the Bikol, Juan Pusong of the Visayan and Sulu, Payo and Bonifacio Bautista of Aklanon, Abunnawas of Sulu, and Pilandok of the Maranao. Being deceitful and dishonest and sometimes very cunning, the Visayan Juan Pusong shows a dark side of the trickster. Sweet talk, subterfuge, substitution, sleight-of-hand: these are a few of the tricks used by the hero for him to come out the winner in every situation. For some offense, Juan is arrested and caged, to be thrown into the sea. Before that day comes, a prince happens to come by. Juan tricks him into taking his place in the cage by saying that the king imprisoned him for refusing to marry the princess, of whom he was not worthy. Seeing his chance, the prince goes into the cage, is thrown into the sea, and drowns. Later, Juan “returns from the sea” and reports to the astonished king that he had seen the latter’s father and other loved ones where he had been. The king asks to be thrown into the sea. He drowns, and Juan becomes king.

Pusong, trickster of Sulu, is unique in that his victim is almost always the sultan, and his exploits almost always consist in having illicit sexual relations with the sultan’s wives, daughters, or close relatives. It seems that through the tricks that Pusong plays on the sultan in the stories, the folk are expressing a subconscious, collective desire to get back at the sultan, who used to reign autocratically over the sultanate.

The trickster Pilandok also enjoys immense popularity among the Maranao. His name is obviously similar to that of the Malaysian trickster Pelandok, except that the Malaysian character is an animal, a mouse-deer, whose animal counterpart in the Philippines is the trickster turtle. Typical tricks that Pilandok plays on his victims include the following: Pilandok tells a victim he is guarding the sultan’s gong. The victim asks to be allowed to beat it. The gong turns out to be a beehive. Bees sting the victim until he passes out. Pilandok tells a victim he is guarding the black belt of the queen. A victim asks to try it on. The belt turns out to be a snake, which coils around the victim, killing him. Then Pilandok ties himself to a tree. A victim, passing by, asks why he has done so. Pilandok says the sky is about to fall and he does not want to panic. The victim asks to be tied also so he could be saved. Pilandok ties the victim to the tree and leaves him to die of hunger and thirst.

In general, the trickster is portrayed as a clever character, but occasionally he lapses into stupidity and behaves like an absolute fool. This happens to Pilandok one time, when he goes out looking for a midwife. He does not know what a midwife looks like. Successively, he fetches a heron, a white male goat, and finally two human-eating giants. His wife is so terrified she gives birth without benefit of a midwife.

Novelistic tales, also called novellas, are a subtype of the folktale, in which the action occurs in the real world with definite time and place, and have characters who represent recognizable types in human society. It differs from the fairy tale by having little or absolutely no magical or supernatural element. Human wit and intelligence, rather than magic powers, win the day for the male or female hero. One popular pattern takes a clever peasant woman as the leading character, pitting her against a king whom she so impresses with her brilliance that he either marries her to his son or marries her himself. A Philippine story of this type is retold by Fansler, 1921, “Si Marcelang Matalino” (Sagacious Marcela). In the story, Marcela, a peasant known for her intelligence, is sent a tiny bird by the king, who asks her to cook 12 dishes out of it. She sends the king a pin and asks him to make 12 spoons out of it. When the king asks Marcela to procure bull’s milk so he could be cured of an illness, she replies that her father has given birth and will need the milk himself. The king realizes that his absurd orders are easily matched by the woman’s clever answers. Marcela’s male counterpart is Lungpigan, a peasant who also vanquishes the king in a contest of wits. The king then takes the humble peasant hero to his palace and marries him to his daughter. Curiously, in stories such as these, princesses, and sometimes princes, become no more than prizes to be won or awarded to people they see for the first time.

The novelistic tale becomes more interesting when it features both clever male and female heroes. In the story “Ang Kapalaran ni Ludovico” (Ludovico’s Fate), the hero’s seemingly strange behavior—opening his umbrella when passing under trees and wearing his shoes when crossing a stream, dividing a chicken by giving the head and neck to the father, the feet to the mother, the wings to the daughter, keeping the rest for himself—is explained and defended by the clever woman, who later marries the man. The enigmatic remark uttered by the hero, “The palay is still being planted but the farmers are already eating it,” is explained by the clever woman to mean that the hungry farmers were eating at home the capital advanced to them by their exploitative landlord. Another admirable character in a tale is the clever wife who uses her beauty and intelligence to remain faithful to her husband and to confound and embarrass her suitors.

Religious and didactic tales, also called miracle tales, are mainly told for the purpose of illustrating the rewards of virtue and the punishment of vice and folly. Hence, their social function is instructional and normative. The strongly religious character of many of these tales calls for not only suspension of disbelief but also a strong spiritual faith. This group of folktales includes exempla or model characters, rational fables, parables, and magic tales of a didactic nature.

In a typical miracle tale, an innocent child, seeing the crucified Christ for the first time, takes pity on the “thin man” hanging on the cross and brings him food. Jesus then peforms a miracle by coming down from the cross, eating with the child, and playing with him. Through this child, a sinful priest is able to atone for his sins and regains the right to heaven. This kind of story echoes the theme of the Spanish miracle story turned into film, Marcelino Pan y Vino (The Miracle of Marcelino). In another religious tale, the Virgin Mary saves a devotee by substituting for her while she is being taken to the demon as payment for his gambling debts. Because of the miracle, the sinful husband repents and becomes a good husband.

Didactic tales underscore many beliefs and values held in folk ethos. A typical didactic tale pattern centers on the theme of unavoidable fate or predestination. In one story, a king dreams that his daughter is going to marry the son of a poor couple who had given him lodging when he got lost once in the forest while hunting. The king orders the commoner child to be killed, but the child survives, grows up, and eventually marries the king’s daughter. In another tale, an old woman prophesies to a rich man that he will marry the dirty little girl he sees selling fish. Fearing the prophecy, the rich man stabs the girl and throws her into the river, but the girl lives and much later marries the man.

Another didactic-tale pattern derives from the lesson that children should love and revere their parents, especially when they are old. A central motif is that of the ungrateful son being indirectly reproached by the ingenuous behavior of his own son. In one tale, an irate man makes a wooden plate for his aged father, because the old man always breaks a plate whenever he eats. Seeing what he has done, the man’s young son takes a piece of wood board and carves plates out of it, saying that they are for his father and mother when they grow old. The man weeps, realizing his error.

Sometimes a didactic tale is told to illustrate a proverb. A Bikol tale, “The Favorite Son,” illustrates the proverb that a crooked tree ought to be straightened out while young, because then it would be difficult to do this when the tree has grown. In the story, an only son is so spoiled by his parents that he becomes very demanding and disrespectful. He comes home one day hungry but does not find any food. He flies into a rage and strikes a person in bed whom he thinks is his father, and flees, thinking he has killed the person. The parents pray that God may forgive their errant son, and that He guide him on his way. Far away, the son reforms, works hard, and becomes rich. Much later, a famine strikes. The father, now reduced to begging, finds his way to the house of this rich young man, whom he does not recognize to be his son. But the son recognizes the old man and takes him in. He tells the old man to straighten out some mature branches of the guava tree, but the old man admits his failure to do so, saying that the branches should have been straightened out while young. The son breaks down, asks for forgiveness, reveals himself, and reproaches his father for not having taught him respect and obedience while he was still a boy. The son takes good care of his father, whose last days become happy.

Thus, didactic tales can be miracle tales. They speak of positive transformations and of good values that can work wonders in the human being.

 

The Survival of Folk Narratives

Despite the impact of Western influences on the cultural life of the Filipinos, particularly on the local literary practice, the folk narratives continue to survive. Orality continues to occupy a prominent position in the lives of the people, and folk narratives enjoy vigorous retellings in modern literary forms. In many cases, these stories are eventually strewn in subsequent artistic forms and are thus able to secure their preservation in popular memory through these adaptations. Some of the metrical romances that gained domination in the local cultural arena from the Spanish up to the American colonial periods were in fact based on popular folktales. An example is Buhay na Pinagdaanan ni Juan Tamad na Anac ni Fabio at ni Sofia sa Caharian nang Portugal (The Life of Lazy Juan, Son of Fabio and Sofia in the Kingdom of Portugal), which is a reimagining of the adventures of Tagalog numskull Juan Tamad.

Severino Reyes’s Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), which first appeared in the pages of Liwayway magazine in the 1920s, features a fictional grandmother whose stories are commonly derived from folk narratives. Lola Basyang has since then been immortalized in the popular imagination. Her stories have subsequently enjoyed reincarnations on radio, film, television, and theater, and have reintroduced folk narratives like “Maryang Makiling” and “Ang Sirena sa Uli-Uli ng Pasig” (The Mermaid at the Eddy of Pasig) to generations of Filipinos already accustomed to Western fairy tales. In his novel Ang Ginto sa Makiling (The Gold in Makiling), 1947, Macario Pineda fused the Mariang Makiling legend and the buried treasure motif to create an allegorical postwar narrative that indicts greed. The Lady of Manaoag appears as an archetype in Pangasinan literature, figuring in the novels of Pangasinan novelist Maria Magsano (Nelmida-Flores 2001, 98).

During the tumultuous 1960s, the resurgence of the nationalist movement spurred vigorous interest among Filipino scholars and academics to study Filipino culture and subsequently to rediscover and preserve ethnic literary traditions. At the same time, creative writers and cultural workers turned to folk material to express social concerns in their artistic practice. In 1974, Frank Rivera wrote Mga Kuwentong Maranao (Maranao Stories), a theatrical piece which derives from several folk stories centering on the Maranao trickster Pilandok to criticize the Marcos dictatorship. In his villanelle eponymously titled “Mariang Makiling,” Jose Lacaba reimagined the mountain nymph of Laguna within the depressing milieu of the martial law years.

Folk narratives continue to find new life on printed page. The supernatural creatures of folktales like the aswang and tikbalang populate the pages of speculative or fantastic fiction and especially of comic books and graphic novels like the Trese Series, whether as villains or heroes, or else they are used as symbols—of otherness or isolation among other conditions—in realistic short stories like Jessica Zafra’s “Manananggal Terrorizes Manila” or Joy T. Dayrit’s “The Walk.” In Ricky Lee’s allegorical novel Si Amapola sa 65 Kabanata (Amapola in 65 Chapters), 2011, the protagonist is a drag queen who is also a manananggal (self-segmenting ghoul).

In literary and cultural criticism, Resil B. Mojares and Nicanor G. Tiongson have revisited the Mariang Makiling legend and the trickster character, respectively. Edgar C. Samar uses the manananggal as a trope for Philippine literature in his study Halos Isang Buhay: Ang Manananggal sa Pagsusulat ng Nobela (Almost a Life: The Self-Segmenting Ghoul in the Writing of Novels), 2012.

Beginning in the 1980s, the crises attending urbanization and improvements in information technology have influenced the formation, shaping, and transmission of new folk narratives. In the same way that myths, legends, and folktales offer insights into indigenous worldview, modern folk narratives such as urban legends and jokes are symptomatic of the Filipinos’ collective subconscious, often on their unarticulated anxieties about society and the times (Tolentino 2007, 42). Tensions that result from such phenomena as urbanization, alienation, wanton consumerism, destruction of the environment, criminality, and industrialization have become instrumental in the creation of modern folklore (Evasco 2000, 69).

While they are still spread orally, digital transmission via e-mail, text messaging, message boards, and social media has become popular, allowing these narratives to retain their “folk” quality—that is, they are authored anonymously and collectively, retold again and again, and constantly amended. This way, the stories circulate, eluding censorship and suppression, subtly or openly commenting on issues of the day or entrenched power structures, institutions, and figures (Tolentino 2007, 40). Modern folk narratives have also retained their didactic quality, as in the cautionary tales of horror, and subversive use of humor, as in jokes and satires.

Modern folk narratives come in the form of urban myths and legends, jokes, and other modern tales. Some characters in urban legends are rooted in indigenous lore but transplanted to a contemporary urban setting, such as tree-dwelling anito who avenge the demolition of their home for the sake of industrial development or the python-twin of a mall magnate’s daughter that murderously lurks in the basement of the shopping mall. Some are rooted in history, such as ghosts of Filipino soldiers from World War II haunting a tunnel of a school in Mandaluyong or the ghost of a dead comfort woman wandering a road in Davao City near what was once a Japanese garrison. Media personalities who loom large in the public imagination, such as politicians and celebrities, also become subjects of modern legends and jokes, such as those imbuing former president Ferdinand Marcos with supernatural powers and those that lampoon actors.

Numskull tales in the tradition of the Tagalog Juan Tamad persist in stories that poke fun at Inday, an archetypal domestic helper; Joseph Estrada, real-life former president; and Manny Pacquiao, a world champion boxer. The jokes featuring Boy Bastos (literally, “vulgar boy”) subvert society’s taboos on morality and sexuality (Samar 2007, 62). These satirical jokes, belong to a long tradition of subversive humor in the country’s folk narratives, of which trickster figures like the Visayan Pusong is part (Chua 2008, 23).

 

Urban Legends

The term “urban legend” was popularized by American folklorist Jan Harold Brunvand of the University of Utah in the 1980s. While the term is a misnomer because the origins of urban legends are not purely urban, it endured because it differentiated these tales from those that are set in the remote past. Their rootedness in everyday reality, he said, distinguished them from myths, while the presence of a discernible plot elevates them from rumors and superstitions. There is a kernel of truth in them, and the retelling is prefaced by the remark that it had come from a “friend of a friend,” a provenance that lends authenticity to and personalizes the story (2001, 423).

In the Philippines, urban legends appear to be born out of collective anxieties related to politics and the various crises brought about by rapid urbanization. In the context of folk narratives, they also marked a shift, in terms of predominant “tactic,” from humor to horror (Tolentino 2007, 49).

Some political urban legends come in the heels of a specific public event but speak of a larger reality. In the 1980s, the construction of the San Juanico Bridge that would link the islands of Samar and Leyte coincided with a spate of unsolved kidnappings in the area, giving rise to stories that the blood of the kidnapped children were being scattered on the foundation of the bridge to strengthen it. On the other hand, the story of a real historical event may persist a few generations later as mere rumor, which may begin with the formulaic line, “It is said that …” For example, it is said that the Manila Film Center is built on top of the remains of construction workers. This event, however, is historically true: the building was being rushed in time for the opening of an international film festival when the semifinished structure collapsed, the workers fell, and there was no time to remove them, dead or alive, from the drying cement. To this day, mourners light candles and leave flowers at the site on All Saints’ Day. Both stories suggest that the monuments of development under Marcos’s rule come at the brutal cost of human lives.

Stories about other members of the Marcos family further attest to this collective effort. According to one legend, Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr was either stabbed to death in a bar brawl in London or executed in the Middle East for having raped and killed a Saudi princess. The Bongbong who walks the halls of the Senate today is a cousin who, at Imelda Marcos’s bidding, underwent plastic surgery to resemble him. The “murder” of Bongbong, even only in the temporal act of the tale’s telling and retelling, fulfills a collective fantasy. As the dictatorship was conjugal, he was seen as next in line, and his death meant the end of the Marcos bloodline.

The second type of urban lore results from the anxieties of people who migrated en masse in the 1980s from rural to urban areas. Their experiences—of industrialization, crime, pollution, and alienation—fuel these tales. For many, life in the city means grinding poverty, overcrowding, and lack of social services; thus, the mode is horror (Evasco 2000, 73). These urban demons are derived from indigenous mythology, a remnant of the successful demonization of indigenous lore by Christianity, which transformed the divinities to malevolent entities, now referred to as masasamang espiritu (evil spirits), kaluluwang ligaw (wandering soul), multo (ghost), aswang, kampon ng kadiliman (disciple of darkness), and yawa (devil). Even so, this link proves the survival of the folk literary tradition and the folk memory amid the physical reconfiguration of the country’s towns and cities (77).

Trees, forests, oceans, and mountains, as repositories of indigenous lore, are afforded sacrality amid the rapid and unbridled march of urbanization. One story features a Taiwanese businessman who wanted to construct a factory in Novaliches. The house on the chosen site was demolished and the trees cut down. Not long after, the factory workers started to see and feel spirits haunting the place, and the factory soon folded. This legend resonates with the plot of some stories in Adelina Gurrea’s Cuentos de Juana (Juana’s Tales), 1943, in which tamao (spirit beings) live in splendid dwellings inside the nonok, or balete, tree and the sambag or sampaloc tree. The hacendero who ordered one of the trees cut down died soon after and his family inherited the tamao’s curse.

 

In a similar story, an enchanted acacia tree some two meters in diameter used to sit in the middle of Loakan Road in Baguio. Plans to cut it down, dating back to the 1950s, had been unsuccessful because anyone who attempted would either get sick or die. Road engineers decided to build around the tree, which finally died in 2002. There are many other stories of spirits who punish acts of disrespect on their habitats. Boys who pee on trees without first seeking permission fall ill. The offended spirits have to be appeased with offerings of food and sometimes liquor.

Mountains, which have become the last refuge for Filipinos who either tried to escape from or fought colonial rule via guerrilla warfare, are also sacred places. Trapped between two great rocks in the mountains of Montalban in present-day Rizal, legendary hero Bernardo Carpio has inspired many retellings, including his appearance in the children’s story “The Adventures of Culas-Culasito,” 1979, by Nick Joaquin. Also popular are the stories set in holy Mount Banahaw and its counterpart “Devil’s Mountain,” Mount Cristobal, both of which straddle the Laguna-Quezon border. In one story, a group of arrogant mountaineers heard the voices of playing children. Continuing their trek, they ended up walking around in circles even as they were following the established route. When they made their way out, they found out that they had been gone for a week. The suggestion is that they had entered a different dimension. The Cebuano-Higaonon novel Batbat hi Udan (Story of Udan), 2009, by Telesforo Sungkit, uses this same phenomenon as a plot complication that prevents the hero from getting to his destination on time, thereby triggering a tribal war.

The Philippines being an archipelago, oceans are an inevitable setting for urban legends. A series of high-profile maritime disasters in the 1980s and 1990s, including the 1987 sinking of the MV Doña Paz in which more than 4,000 people died, have given rise to the idea of a so-called Romblon triangle. Over the past few decades, more than 40 maritime disasters occurred in the area in the Sibuyan Sea. According to the legend, a ghost ship made of gold owned by a Lolo Amang roams the sea every night, illuminating the dark waters. Some passengers of the MV Don Juan, which sank in 1980, say they saw Lolo Amang’s ship just before their vessel collided with another ship.

The golden ship is also the opulent and mythical city of Biringan, found somewhere between Calbayog and Catarman. Believed to be inhabited by engkanto, it exists in a different dimension, although many seafarers have reported seeing the glittering city of light. This golden city that doubles as a ship is a recurring motif in the indigenous mythology of ethnic groups all over the Philippines. After Typhoon Sendong in 2011, there were sightings in Cagayan de Oro of a golden ship flying over bodies floating in the sea and picking up their souls. In another story, a beautiful lady from Catbalogan was driving when, in San Jorge town, near where Biringan is located, she met an accident. The accident was staged by an inhabitant of the mythical city who had taken interest in her. He replaced her body with a log made to look like her corpse.

Urban legends featuring “white ladies,” women dressed in white who accost people, especially drivers, and who turn out to be ghosts, recur in many cultures, where they are depicted as scorned lovers or victims of vehicular accidents. The Philippine white ladies are among the few who are victims of gender-based violence, like rape. Such variants may be read as a cry for justice for real-life victims of rape (Evasco 2000, 83-84). In Talisay, Negros Occidental, a trio of century-old talisay trees is called the “Tres Marias,” after three maidens in white who were on their way to Sunday mass when they were gang-raped by Spanish soldiers.

Also related to criminality with a public-health dimension are stories of the kidnapping of children whose organs are harvested for trafficking. In many areas of southern Luzon and Metro Manila, young girls are said to have been forcibly taken by men in white lab coats into a waiting van. The following day, the children would be found eviscerated and their internal organs sold in the black market. Bundles of money, ostensibly payment, would be left by the perpetrators. So widespread were the stories that some barangays posted warnings and alerted schools to look after their pupils. This anxiety does have a basis in fact: in 2005, the World Health Organization identified the Philippines as a global hotspot for organ trafficking.

Purportedly a reaction to wanton consumerism are the legends about pythons living in the air ducts and basement of shopping malls, slithering into occupied fitting rooms and eating customers and salesladies. The versions in Manila and Davao share many similarities: the pythons are the children of the mall owners, one of twins, satisfying whose appetite for human flesh ensures the success of the mall. The figure of the serpent, which had divine origins in precolonial Filipino and other Asian mythologies, had been turned in the Judeo-Christian tradition into a creature of sin.

While they entertain, these legends also encapsulate Filipinos’ coming to terms with the ironies and mysteries of the forces at play in the city (Evasco 2000, 86).

 

Jokes

Narrative jokes descend from the numskull and trickster tales. With the advent of information technology in the 1990s, jokes now circulate via e-mail, message boards, text messaging, and social media. Like urban legends, nobody “owns” them but everybody knows them. Over time, jokes on certain topics or personalities accrue, and a cult or “legend” surrounding, say, a politician or a celebrity is developed. Beyond the individual jokes, this corpus forms a larger narrative that, like indigenous folk narratives, speaks about that particular period in history.

As in the Tagalog Juan Tamad or the Visayan Pusong, the oblique source of humor in contemporary jokes may be an oppressive reality, social taboos, or authority figures. Mockery is a mode of coping for Filipinos, if not rebellious retaliation. During the Spanish period, Marcelo H. del Pilar satirized the abuses of the clergy by altering the words to Catholic prayers. The “carabao English” of popular komiks hero Kenkoy, introduced in Liwayway in 1929 by Antonio Velasquez, satirized the imposition of English (Reyes 2009, 394).

In the same way, jokes about Marcos in the 1970s and 1980s became the only recourse for many against a powerful dictatorship (Chua 2008, 23). The popularity of political humor rises in proportion to the increasing oppressiveness of authoritarian regimes. Where political dissent and criticism are suppressed, the political joke becomes a vehicle for criticism. While the ruler has nearly unlimited power to arrest, imprison, torture, and execute, the people retain the power to ridicule and laugh at him (Shehata 1992, 75-76).

In the case of Marcos, the jokes that circulated by word of mouth touch on many aspects of the dictatorship, from election rigging to corruption, as the following samples show (Mercado 2010). On his return from the conclave that elected Pope John Paul II, Manila Archbishop Jaime Cardinal Sin told the Commission on Election’s Leonardo Perez, “Leonie, if you had overseen the Conclave, I would have been elected Pope.” During the 1974 Miss Universe pageant at the Folk Arts Theater (FAT), then First Lady Imelda Marcos asked Miss South Africa what her father did for a living. “He’s in the mining business,” the beauty queen said. “That’s a coincidence,” Imelda replied, then sweeping her arms around the lobby of the FAT, added, “I’m in the mining business, too! That’s mine, that’s mine, and that’s mine. In fact, everything you see here is mine!”

While traumatic, the 1983 assassination of opposition senator Benigno Aquino Jr also became the subject of jokes. The event, which was pivotal in the narrative of martial law, became an opportunity for people to poke fun at the Marcosian justice system. Three witnesses were asked to testify. When counsel asked the witnesses to recount what happened, the first said that he was looking up so he did not see who the gunman was. The second said that he was looking down so he did not see who the gunman was. The third said that he was looking straight ahead so he did not see who the gunman was either. The judge concluded that Aquino must have committed suicide.

Ninoy Aquino’s funeral took a full 12 hours, with two million people attending. Expressing the popular opinion on who masterminded the assassination, those who walked behind the truck would swear the following day that it bore the sign: “Government project. Don’t delay.”

After Marcos, all presidents became the subject of jokes, but none more so than Joseph “Erap” Estrada, whose election in 1998 was “foretold by jokes, and, indeed, so was his ouster” three years later (Coronel 2005). Estrada, a former actor and college dropout, was extremely popular among the masses, who relate to him via the poor characters he has portrayed, even though in real life Estrada belongs to the oligarchical elite. He made political capital of his perceived dimness, mocked by political rivals in so-called Erap jokes. He published a compilation of such jokes, titled ERAPtion: How to Speak English without Really Trial, 1994. Through the book, he presented his flawed English as evidence of his humble social standing and himself an alternative to the intelligent but corrupt English-speaking elite.

A descendant of numskull tales, Erap jokes initially poked fun at Estrada’s poor English but soon became more critical, hitting his political decisions and well-known vices. His ouster from power, following an aborted impeachment trial in 2001, was also captured in jokes, which in part became instrumental in shifting popular opinion against him (Jurado and German 1994, 18, 20). In an interview, the reporter asks Erap, “I understand that, as a child, you were asthmatic?” Erap replies, “No, that’s not true. I’ve always been a Catholic.” In another joke, Erap calls out to the rebel group Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), “Surrender now!” The MILF shouts back, “We won’t surrender if you can’t spell ‘ceasefire’!” After a pause, Erap hollers, “On with the war!”

While not all individual Erap jokes present a clear plot, overall they chart the trajectory of Estrada’s political career and, more importantly, the evolution of public sentiment about his persona, from harmless amusement to mild discontent to seething anger. The technological dimension is also sharply demonstrated, in the shift in the mode of transmission from e-mail to message boards to, finally, swift and portable text messaging. By the time public opinion had swelled against him, “within hours, even minutes, of a major news event, some joker somewhere [had] already forwarded to all in his or her address book a polished gem of humor” (Coronel 2005, ix). Although an Erap joke could be told orally, it was just as enjoyable when read on a computer or cellular phone monitor.

Aside from politicians, celebrities became the subject of jokes, creating modern legends about them. Faulty English remained a popular object of ridicule, reflecting a collective discomfort about our relationship with the colonial language (Chua 2008, 38-39). Actors Vilma Santos and Alma Moreno, beauty queen Melanie Marquez, and athlete Manny Pacquiao all gained notoriety for their English-related gaffes. The jokes may originate in an actual quote, around which narratives are then built. In some cases, gaffes attributed to one celebrity get attributed to another over time and with some changes in details.

“Melanisms” are malapropisms attributed to Melanie Marquez. These began to circulate almost immediately after the interview portion of the 1979 Miss International competition. Asked if she would insure her legs for a million dollars like American actress Angie Dickinson, she quipped: “I won’t change my legs, because I’m contented with my long-legged.” She won the title. Stories, made up or factual, about her misuse of English quickly circulated. Defending her brother Joey Marquez from accusations of battery, she exclaimed, “Don’t judge my brother; he is not a book.”

Examples of jokes about Alma Moreno’s English are the following: An interviewer asks Alma Moreno, “What can you say about this product, more or less?” After much thought, Alma answers, “More.” When the studio audience begins to laugh, Alma takes back her answer. “I’m sorry, I mean, less.” At a restaurant, Alma Moreno orders a burger. The waiter says, “With pleasure, ma’am.” Shaking her head, she says, “No, with ketchup.”

Jokes about Manny Pacquiao poke fun not only at the boxer’s flawed English but also at his thick Visayan accent and rural roots. The punch lines are a jab at his pronunciation. A reporter asks him to comment on the “peace-and-order situation” in General Santos. Pacquio replies, “Ah, we have a lot of fish in Gen San but we don’t have a lot of orders!”

 

Aside from celebrity-inspired jokes, also popular are made-up characters, like Inday, whose name has come to signify a female household help, and Boy Bastos, a mischievous boy given to vulgar, scandalous sexual quips.

The Inday jokes, which are a hodgepodge of all past faux pas by celebrities, come in two threads, one in which she mangles English grammar and misuses idioms, and another in which she is too well versed in the language. An example of the first type is a “found letter,” in which she narrates her love story. Here is its happy ending:

Now we’re so in love! Mute and epidemic na ang past. I’m still in a state of shocked. Kasi mantakin mo naman, when its rain, it’s really fours talaga! Love is a many splendor, di ba? Kaya—I advised you. You can never can tell. Just burn the bridge when you get there. Life is shorts. If you make a mistake, well, just pray for the internal and external repose of your soul. I second emotion.

The other strand of Inday jokes imagines the housekeeper as overly clever and articulate.

The juxtaposition of the lowly station of helpers with the status afforded to English is meant to jar. In this letter to her mother, Inday sounds more like Jane Eyre or Elizabeth Bennet:

Dear Mom,

Junior has become a little monster. Remember the head accident? As if it wasn’t enough, he was summoned by the principal of his shabbily run school. Oh, what a bunch of baboons! I never thought being a governess is such strenuous employ!

Your daughter,

Inday

In other jokes, Inday casually dishes out philosophical musings about mundane things: reprimanded by her employer for ruining the microwave, she replies: “Success is often the result of taking a misstep in the right direction. Show me a person who has never made a mistake and I’ll show you somebody who has never achieved much.” Today’s punch line is tomorrow’s aphorism.

With many jokes related to the use or abuse of English, Boy Bastos stands unique in his engagement with sexuality for material. The Boy Bastos cycle follows him all the way from conception (Boy Bastos as a sperm cell) to birth, infancy, childhood, adolescence, and adulthood. The jokes are set at home, in school, on a jeepney, at the mall, and even abroad. As in other universes of jokes, the details vary and different versions of the same joke exist. Always, however, the source of the humor is the vulgarity, challenging notions of tact, politeness, and socially acceptable behavior (Samar 2007, 65).

In the jokes, Boy Bastos and his family embody societal taboos (Samar 2007, 62). They talk openly about incest, infidelity, menstruation, and less “traditional” forms of sex. Although his ancestry may be traced to the trickster Pusong of old, Boy Bastos is a product of the 21st century, in which all the senses are bombarded with graphic detail and the rules of censorship have been relaxed.

The call center industry that has spread since the turn of the present century has given rise to jokes related to the job. Because call center employees are mostly young and highly tech-savvy, the jokes quickly circulate. Embedded in these gems of clever humor are the frustrations springing from the potentially abusive dynamic between a Filipino agent and an American customer. There is also a preponderance of jokes related to the use of English; occasionally they end with the agent pulling one on the customer. As jobs in the call center industry are notorious for being highly stressful, the jokes again function as catharsis and retaliation. Unable to talk back to an irate customer, the agent salvages some measure of momentary victory during the jokes’ telling and retelling.

Like urban legends, jokes are not literally true but possess essential truths. By its nature, a joke’s self-presentation as not true grants it permission to expose a truth, no matter how uncomfortable or potentially subversive it is, as is the case in political jokes. Also similar to the folk appeal of urban legends, “a new joke acts almost like an event of universal interest: it is passed from one person to another like the news of the latest victory” (Freud 1960, 15).

 

Conclusion

The presence of folk narratives in contemporary literary forms and in everyday discourse cannot be overestimated. The dispersal of these stories affirms how the folk narrative tradition continues to endure the tempests of modernity in the Filipino society. Among indigenous communities, folk narratives continue to occupy a significant position in the life of the people, reflecting contemporary social concerns such as the growing military presence in their lands and their collective impetus to fight for ancestral domain. Even in urban zones where the force of Westernization is undoubtedly stronger, the production and reproduction of folk narratives, through oral and electronic transmission, remain alive. Indeed, the enduring presence of the folk narrative tradition continues to affirm how the workings of the popular imagination creatively respond to the social, economic, and political currents and upheavals that shape Philippine society.  Written by Damiana Eugenio, updated by Glenn Diaz and Laurence Marvin Castillo

article.value: There are three general types of folk narratives: myths, legends, and folktales. Myths are considered to have a validating purpose in society: they are commonly regarded as vehicles of transmitted values, beliefs, and practices, and are therefore held sacred. Legends narrate extraordinary events in a society’s past, and are sometimes believed to have actually happened, because they often serve to explain the origin of objects, places, or phenomena, or educate people about lessons derived from certain human experiences. In contrast, folktales are not regarded as moral dogma or sacred truth requiring belief. The events that folktales narrate may or may not have happened, and generally occur in an indefinite time and place. Furthermore, they are told primarily for entertainment, although they also have instructional value, as in the case of religious and didactic tales, as well as animal fables that play up the conflict between positive and negative values by presenting a world parallel to that of human society. Folktales are almost always idealistic in content and often have a happy ending.
Myth

A myth is a prose narrative explaining how the world and people came to be in their present form, as well as recounting the origins of ceremonies and cultural norms and taboos. It is usually associated with theology, religion, and ritual. It is called alamat in Tagalog, gugud or batbat in Bukidnon, and ituan in Mandaya. An origin myth is called babarawon in Mansaka, usulan kissa in Tausug, and tuturan at kagunggurangan in Palawan. A creation myth is called kaawn kisa in Mansaka. An oggood is a mythological narrative about the Bontok culture hero Lumawig. A recited, rather than chanted, narrative in the current Bukidnon idiom about the epic hero Agyu is called mantukaw.

The characters in a myth include beings in the supernatural or spirit world and beings in the world of people. Thus, deities, gods, goddesses, ancestral spirits, male and female culture heroes, sacred animals and objects, and supernatural phenomena may coexist in the world of myth. The early Filipinos believed in one supreme god and in a number of lesser gods, with each ethnolinguistic group having its own version of a supernatural hierarchy and its relationships with the world of human beings. Thus, the “supreme being” is called a variety of names in Philippine mythology: Bathala (Tagalog), Mangetchay (Kapampangan), Gugurang (Bikol), Lumauig or Kabunian (Bontok), Liddum (Ifugao), Mahal Makaako (Mangyan), Laon (Visayan), Magbabaya (Bukidnon), Melu (Blaan), Makalidung (Manobo), Manama (Manuvu), Ampu (Palawan), and Apo Namalyari (Aeta).

Myths about Filipino gods depict them either in conflict or falling in love with each other, or else they are shown descending on the earth to intermarry with mortals. In a Bukidnon myth, a god sends an airship called salimbal to earth in order to bring up his chosen people to the sky world, led by their culture hero Agyu (Sitoy 1937, 445-46, 465-66). A Bikol myth recounts the conflict between the good god Gugurang and the evil god Asuang when the latter attempts to steal fire from the former (Beyer 1923). The Bontok of Mountain Province have a myth that validates the tribe’s pechen (peace pact). It tells of the conflict between the warrior god Chacha and the blacksmith god Ked-yem. After Ked-yem kills Chacha’s sons, the two engage in a fierce battle. Finally, they reconcile and become friends again (Cawed 1972, 51-52).

An idyllic love affair is that between Captan, god of the land breezes, and Maguayan, goddess of the sea breezes. On the spot where Captan and Maguayan consummated their love, a bamboo plant grows, and from it emerge the first man and woman. Another love affair is that between the sun god and a sea nymph, which eventually leads to the creation of the island of Cebu. An Igorot myth recounts how Mayingit, son of the god of thunder, falls in love with a mortal maiden named Bugan, and begets a child with her. He does not stay to live with them, but comes down every now and then when his help is needed, as when Bugan gives birth to their baby, and later when he implants parts of his body into his young son to make the boy practically invincible in war. The mythical epic of the southern Palawan highland group tells how the superhero Kudaman, blest with godly power in love and combat, defeats all his enemies, and woos the 10 loveliest goddesses in the world.

Origin myths explain a great variety of phenomena—the creation of the world, of people, of land and water features, of plants and animals. Philippine myths give three versions of the creation of the world. In some myths, the world was created by a supreme being out of dust and other material. In other myths, the world came to be as a result of conflict between opposing forces, as in the story of the cosmic battle between the sky and the sea, which led to the formation of islands. A third group of myths is more fanciful, such as the Mangyan and Sulod myths which give an account of how the world was formed from the feces of a worm.

The origin of people is also given varying accounts in the myths. One group attributes the creation of man and woman to the work of a supreme being. A second group sees the first man and woman emerging, fully formed, from two internodes of a bamboo split open by the pecking beak of a bird (Visayan), or from two stumps of a banana plant (Igorot), or from two hatching eggs (Mandaya). And a third group of myths tells us that the first inhabitant of the earth actually descended from the sky world. In an Ifugao myth, the first man and woman were children of Kabigat of the sky world. This god had sent his two children to the earth world to populate it.
