text:
Folk poetry refers to poems belonging to an oral tradition that dates back to centuries during the precolonial period and continued to develop through the colonial period up to the modern age of technology and globalization. Among the early poetic forms of the indigenous Filipinos were riddles, proverbs, short poems, and poetic exchanges or jousts. Riddles, proverbs, and short poems, like the Tagalog tanaga and Mangyan ambahan, are the simplest forms of primordial oral literature, centered on the talinghaga, “a single metaphor which establishes an analogy between human experience and an aspect of [a person’s] environment” (Lumbera 1986, 12). Collectively, riddles, and proverbs are known as folk speech—a spoken code utilizing images, symbols, and ideas, as distinguished from plain, everyday social and private communication. The main distinction lies in the purpose of communication; the manner, mood, or medium of conveyance; and the structure, style, and substance of the message. Many, if not most, riddles and proverbs are conveyed in verse form, and so they are also considered as among the earliest types of folk poetry.      

 

Riddles

A riddle is a description of objects in terms intended to suggest something entirely different, or a question stated so as to exercise one’s ingenuity in answering it or discovering its meaning. Riddling is a universal art, and Filipinos share with other peoples a fondness for riddling. Practically every ethnolinguistic group in the country has its riddles, which are known by various names: patototdon among the Bikol, tigmo among the Cebuano, burburtia among the Ilocano, paktakon among the Ilonggo, bugtong among the Kapampangan and Tagalog, pabitla or bonikew among the Pangasinan, patitgo-on among the Waray, patugmahanon among the Capiznon, palluvuh among the Ibanag, lohmo or lakmo among the Isinay, lallagunut among the Gaddang, kabbuni among the Ivatan, antuka or paakenala among the Maguindanaon, antuka among the Bukidnon and the Maranao, igom among the Palawan, paigumun among the Batak, atukon among the Manobo, tutukanon among the Mansaka, untukan among the Yakan, and tigum-tigum or tukud-tukud among the Tausug.

Riddling is a pleasant pastime, whether one is at work or at leisure. It may be done at any time of the day or night. However, there are cases where the time for riddling matters. Riddling is not favored at nighttime among the majority of the Manobo group, who usually devote their nights to communal activities like storytelling and epic singing. For the Ata Manobo subgroup, however, riddling is generally held during wakes for the dead; it is considered disrespectful of tradition for one to exchange riddles outside of wakes (Bajo 2004, 150). Among the Isneg, of Northern Luzon, a riddle about the riddle itself mentions the appropriate time for this activity: “It is that which we cannot say, except at the time of harvest” (Eugenio 2005, xvii).

While riddles can take almost anything as a subject, the Mandaya and Mansaka hesitate to mention spirits and supernatural creatures in their riddles. They believe that riddling about spirits is sacrilegious and may bring bad luck, poor harvest, sickness, and even death (Fuentes and de la Cruz 1980, 14).

While being a pastime, riddling also sharpens one’s sensitivity to daily experience (Noceda and Sanlucar [1754] 1860). It invites critical thinking and challenges one’s memory. Most riddles are marked by the qualities “brevity, wit, and felicitous phrasing” in imparting folk knowledge and wisdom to the next generations (Eugenio 2005, xiii).

Riddles mainly describe objects that are familiar to their audience, such as objects in their immediate environment or parts of their own anatomy. The central image may be a household item like the mat, dipper or ladle, kerosene lamp, candle, pot, or stone grinder:

Cebuano:

Naghimo akog balay giuna ko ang taliwala;

Naglibug ang panday kay ang bungbongan midapat sa yuta. (Bukag)

(I made a house, I began with the middle;

The carpenter was confused because the walls touched the ground.) (Basket)

Plants and animals around the farmhouse, such as the bamboo, banana, jackfruit, coconut, corn, ginger, guava, and the cat, dog, ant, chicken, or pig, are favorite subjects:

Ilonggo:

Ang puno buko-buko

Dahon daw abaniko,

Bunga daw parasko,

Perdigones ang liso. (Kapayas)

(The trunk is full of nodes,

Leaves like fans,

Fruits like large wine bottles,

Pellets are the seeds.) (Papaya)

Some riddles describe parts of the human body:

Ata Manobo:

Diyanan ka bawobato agad pila no bobo

Nganan og sa ulion do. (Mata)

(Two men walking return home immediately

Even if traversing ten mountains.) (Eyes)

Riddles all over the archipelago are very similar in subject matter, and only the language and sometimes the structure differ. Thus, we find versions of the same riddle in most ethnolinguistic groups.

The following riddles may be translated this way: “A bamboo tube by day; a sea by night.” The answer is a mat.

Tagalog:

Bongbong con liuanag con gabi ay dagat. (Banig)

Ilocano:

No aldao tubong

no rabii dadali. (Icamen)

Pangasinan:

Tubong na agew

Tabla no labi. (Icamen)

Igorot:

Mo madsem maannaannawa

mo pay mapat-a ngumadan si tubong. (Abek)

Isneg:

Bolo na alxaw tanap no xabi. (Aba)

Subanon:

Sa’ gebii, lelanit

Sa’ gendaw, sumpitan. (Gikam)

However, the specific cultural moorings of riddles deserve attention (Eugenio 2005). Some riddles from Muslim groups, for example, refer to Allah:

Maranao:

Antona-a inaden o Allah a

Ilelib sa keleb a mata-id a di seka? (Orak a manok)

(What is this creation of Allah

That is found behind beautiful walls?) (Chicken egg)

Tausug:

Piyaawn sin Tuhan

Liyawa’ sin manusiya. (Lawa)

(It was created by Allah,

[But] disposed of by man.) (Spider)

What is immediately striking about many Philippine riddles is that they are structured as verse. While there are nonrhyming, declarative or interrogatory riddles, many riddles take the form of the assonanced couplet. When they are not cast in verse form, riddles remain enigmatic descriptions of objects or phenomena whose actual identities are to be guessed.

Ilocano:

Umon-una nga aganak sa agbugui. (Pagay)

(First it gives birth before becoming pregnant.) (Rice plant)

Sometimes the riddle is given in the form of a question. Occasionally, the riddle opens with a formulaic phrase to introduce the question, such as the Ilocano “Ania ti pinarsua ti Dios … ?” (What did God create that … ?), the Kalinga “Appukedt …” (Guess …), the Ivatan “Buñi mo buñi ko aya” (Guess my riddle …), the Subanon “Naa, antuk niu …” (Now, guess this …), or the Badjao “Daing-daing ai … ?” (What kind of fish … ?). It may end with another formulaic phrase, like the Cebuano “Unsa man?” (What is it?) and “Karon tag-ana kini” (Now guess this one), or the Waray “Takay tigo” (Guess what it is) and its condensed form, “Tigo-a.” The Mandaya begin a riddle with the phrase “Tuok sang tutukanon ko” (Guess what it is), as the following example shows.

Mandaya:

Tuok sang tutukanon ko

Tagbi na dadalaga-ay

Matigam mana-i sang kasigullman. (Ligwan)

(Guess what it is

Only a small girl

Yet knows how to spin in the dark.) (Honey bee)

Some riddles go beyond the common couplet form and become rhyming quatrains or are even longer than those. They are elaborate metaphorical constructions of the puzzle to be solved.

Ilonggo:

May diotay nga kaban-kaban,

Naga abri kag naga sira man.

Ang solod puro tul-an,

Kun kaisa nadudunlan. (Ba-ba)

(There is a small chest

That opens and closes by itself.

The contents are all bone,

Sometimes it chokes.) (Mouth)

Tagalog:

Kahit ka na dalubhasa’t pantas

At alam ang dunong sa lahat.

Aling bapor kaya sa sangmaliwanag

Ang sa patag ay naglalayag? (Plantsa)

(Though you be expert and wise

And possess all knowledge of the race:

What ship in the whole wide world

Sails upon a dry surface?) (Flat iron)

Sometimes the combination of images can be very unusual.

Cebuano:

Sudlayng maanindot giniring-giringan paglibut;

Bantug man kay magatiyabao pagabirig-birigan man diay sa kabao. (Intusan)

(A beautiful comb with serrated edges

It flirtatiously dances whenever a carabao goes around.) (Sugarcane mill)

Much of the charm of riddles lies mainly in the startling beauty of imagery that the native mind is capable of inventing and expressing. It is perhaps the metaphorical riddles, with their fanciful imagery that are also apt clues to the solution that are easily remembered. The metaphors used reveal a poetic sensibility keenly aware of and responsive to the environment.

Ilonggo:

Prinsisang ambungan

Nag lingkod sa kopa. (Kasoy)

(A beautiful princess

Sitting on a cup.) (Cashew)

Tboli:

Sowu no te Metutung

hitayen fetu sefuhen. (Kitay)

(The python at Mount Petutung

rests its tail on the opposite side.) (Bridge)

The enjoyment one gets from riddles derives from the challenge of having to guess the answer. The riddle can be made more difficult—and the challenge thus enhanced—by the use of various stylistic devices. Balance and parallelism are seen in the following example.

Cebuano:

Tubig ang gihukot, Tubig ang gihuktan, Tubig mohobad. (Asin)

(Tied with water, Tied to water,

Untied by water.) (Salt)

Paradox and personification, respectively, are the techniques used in the next two riddles.

Maguindanaon:

Magagayan a malambeg,

Mababa den o edtindeg. (Aso)

(Tall when sitting,

Short when standing.) (Dog)

Manuvu:

Labbut ni Kaitoman

Dilotan ni Kapuypuy. (Kuron uwoy apoy)

(The anus of Kaitoman

Is licked by Kapuypoy.) (Pot and fire)

One of the sources of fun in riddling is the double entendre or double meaning. Riddles may use the sex organs or the sex act as the clue, using colorful language and the appropriate naughtiness of tone. The answers usually turn out to be commonplace objects.

Cebuano:

Sa ibabao, balucagon

Pagcabucaha ko mapulahon. (Sapran)

(Its surface is full of hair

I open it and it is red.) (Achuete)

Gaddang:

Congonan nu usin y amam

Maggirawa pay sila y inam. (Campana)

(If you pull your daddy’s penis

Your mommy’s vagina, too, screams.) (Bell)

There are riddles, however, the answers to which are indeed sexual. Riddling appears to an activity where sexual and social inhibitions and taboos are relaxed.

The use of nonsense words is another device that riddlers use. In some riddles, nonsense words seem to have been coined mainly to meet the needs of rhyme, rhythm, and meter, as well as for onomatopoeic effect. Sometimes the words are terms referring to persons, places, or animals in folklore.

Mansaka:

Padi ni Kiding-kiding

Di pagabuslan. (Ollaipan)

(Knife of Kiding-kiding

No one can borrow.) (Centipede)

Aside from riddles from different languages in the Philippines, there are riddles in Chabacano, a Spanish creole, gathered by researchers in Cavite and Zamboanga. Here are two examples (Gervacio 2011, xvi):

Dos puerta de vidrio

Abre cierra sin ruido. (Ojos)

(Two mirror doors,

That open and shut without noise.) (Eyes)

Tiene lang un diente mi lola.

Ta of todo el gente, si ele ta grita. (Campana)

(My grandmother has only one tooth,

But when she shouts, it will be heard by the entire village.) (Bell)

There are also riddles that while being “about” commonplace things, nonetheless express folk responses or attitudes to colonial institutions or traditions (Villareal 1997, 61):

Buto ka Kastila

Ginlubong sa lupa. (Rabanos)

(Penis of a Spaniard

Buried in the ground.) (Raddish)

Balay ni San Pablo

May alkansya kada kwarto. (Kawayan)

(House of Saint Paul

Contains money box in each room.) (Bamboo)

The tradition of riddling has survived, adapting and responding to cultural, historical, political, and social exigencies. The indicators of modern living are treated in these riddles, the last humorously so (Gervacio 2011):

Tumapak ako sa impyerno;

Maya-maya, nasa langit na ako. (Escalator)

(I stepped in hell;

Later on, I was already in heaven.) (Escalator)

Hinihimas ko’t kinukutusan,

Inalok sa pusa, ayaw naman. (Computer mouse)

(I am touching and snapping it,

When I offered it to a cat, it declined.) (Computer mouse)

Sa bahay ni Sangko Henry,

Piyesta araw-araw, gabi-gabi. (Megamall)

(In the house of Brother Henry,

There’s always a feast every day and every night.) (Megamall)

These riddles criticize the state, the government, presidents, and the ruling institutions (Gervacio 2011):

Patok sa takilya,

Hindi naman pelikula,

Pinipilahan ng gutom na masa. (NFA rice)

(Even though not a film,

It is blockbuster

Where the hungry masses form a queue.) (NFA rice)

In those examples, the traditional characteristics of the riddle have undergone transformation, but the talinghaga survives as an essential element. As important, the riddle continues to display the folk’s wit and imagination and to be a vehicle for them to amuse themselves, to pass on received knowledge, and to criticize.

 

Proverbs

A proverb is a terse didactic statement which carries the force of tradition, the effect of moral authority, and the mark of timelessness. As “popular saying,” it has been handed down from generation to generation, containing the folk wisdom of the ages, with the validity and impact of moral precepts based on folklore, custom, worldview, belief or value system.

Filipinos have always acknowledged the instructional value of proverbs in their social life, and have invoked these in just about any imaginable situation requiring the imparting of advice, admonition to the young, exchange of ideas and opinions, as well as in philosophical and literary writings. As Villareal observes, several korido (metrical romances), like Bernardo Carpio and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), contain aphoristic passages, and even Jose Rizal quotes proverbs in his letter to the women of Malolos (1997, 65-65). In the 1930s, magazines, which began to emerge all over the country, continued the proverb tradition. The stories published in Hiligaynon magazine, for example, usually used short proverbs as epigraphs. These only affirm that proverb, as an indigenous form, is a continuing tradition that is still popular up to the contemporary period.

Like riddles, proverbs are known in practically all ethnolinguistic groups in the Philippines, and dwell on universal themes. Most of the native terms for proverbs have the meaning of “wise, old sayings,” such as aramiga or sasabihan among the Bikol, panultihon or pagya among the Cebuano, humbaton or hurobaton among the Ilonggo and Capiznon, pagsasao among the Ilocano, kasebian among the Kapampangan, diparan among the Pangasinan, salawikain/sawikain/kasabihan among the Tagalog, dayhuan/puplongan/patitgo-on among the Waray, hueobaton for proverb and bilisad-on for maxim among the Aklanon, unoni among the Ibanag, pananahan among the Ivatan, memos an baba/oloran/tongong among the Isinay, lalenut among the Gaddang, basahan among the Bukidnon, panonggelengan among the Manobo, pananaroon among the Maranao, and masaalaa (proverb) and pituwa (maxim) among the Tausug. Another form of folk speech sacred to the Tausug is the hadith, consisting of sayings handed down by the prophet Muhammad, and written in Arabic.

Filipino elders are fond of quoting proverbs to inculcate virtues and desirable attitudes among the young; to encourage them when they lose heart; to rebuke, warn, or correct them when they do wrong; or simply to drive home a lesson or truth. Proverbs teach the people custom law, good conduct among themselves, and the art of relating to one another in a harmonious society.

The proverb is distinctly poetic in structure. It is commonly expressed as a rhyme couplet containing two elements or images, which become meaningful when they are brought together. Such are the images of the cart and the carabao in the following proverb.

Gaddang:

Mena dam si mappalungu

Yo daleday mah so daffug.

(The cart does not precede the water buffalo.)

In general, the lessons and images of metaphorical proverbs are derived from the common everyday life and occupations of the folk. Plants and animals in the backyard and farm may be used to refer to human character:

Bikol:

Daing maniwang na manok sa nagugutom na butbot.

(There is no bony chicken to a hungry owl.)

Southern Leyte:

Patay na ang dahon, apan ang baho mao lang sa gihapon.

(The leaf has withered but the scent lingers.)

Processes associated with common objects in and around the house may stand for the development of character:

Aklanon:

Nano rondayang higot nga nag aeangot

Ko ugsarang it tanang kabaeayan.

(What cord is this that connects the

Doorsteps of every home.)

Hiligaynon:

Pag agui sa hagdanan

Kon mana-ug ikaw sa balay,

Kon bu-ot ikawindi mabali.

(Pass by the stairs

When you go down from a house,

If you do not want to be broken.)

One gleans the ways, practices, and manners of the common people in proverbs such as these.

Kapampangan:

Ing pamaquiasawa e anting susubung nasi,

iyapsa nung mapali.

(Marriage is not like rice that is eaten,

it cannot be spat out if it is too hot.)

Maguindanaon:

Kapatay pan sa kauyag duwa ba lang a betad,

Da isa duwa lon i dilon makanggumakaed.

(Death and the sun are two things

Which no man can outdo or outshine.)

Customs, beliefs, and traditions peculiar to a certain group are seen in some proverbs. The Maguindanaon, for example, have proverbs that use the bolo while the Tausug have proverbs that refer to the gong. Below are some examples.

Maguindanaon:

Apia matubpul su bolo

Aya temo sa bolo a di-ibpamunday.

(A dull bolo is better,

Than a sharp bolo which is not being used.)

Tausug:

Minsan mabagbag na in agung matanug,

Mabantug mayan.

(Even if a resounding gong becomes broken,

It will be renowned.)

Proverbs, like riddles, use many stylistic devices. Balance and parallelism are seen in a simple statement with two elements, which are either similar or contrasting:

Ilonggo:

Kon diin ang luto, didto ang sunggo; Kon diin ang hilaw, didto ang likaw.

(Where everything is cooked, all gather;

where everything is raw, all evade.)

Mandaya:

Dato sangkilid nang butay sang kabagsukan,

Yagaapyang eng kallatagan nang kayamukan.

(Behind the mountain of sacrifices,

Lies the valley of success.)

Personification may invest inanimate objects, vegetation, and animals with lively human qualities. The following proverb also illustrates the process by which the favorite Ilocano vegetable dish called pinakbet is cooked:

       Ilocano:

Dipay naluto ni paria, simmagpaw ni carabasa.

(Before the bitter melon was cooked, squash jumped in.)

Hyperbole is an effective device for emphatically driving home a moral point, as this Boholano riddle shows:

Masbale mapilde ang ginharian dili ang gicasabutan.

(Rather lose a kingdom than break your heart.)

Analogy illustrates how objects in nature mirror human behavior.

Kapampangan:

Panga matni ya ing tuquil, ala yang laman.

(If a bamboo tube sounds loudly, it is empty.)

Other stylistic devices occasionally used in the Philippine proverbs are alliteration, certain rhetorical and syntactical patterns, and clever wordplay.

According to intent and subject matter, Philippine proverbs may be grouped as follows: those that express general attitude toward life, ethical proverbs or those that recommend certain virtues and condemn certain vices, those that express a system of values, and those that express general truths and observations about life and human nature.

The proverbs often reveal a view of life as arduous, full of challenges to be met and hurdled. It is also uncertain, transient, and fragile.

Cebuano:

Ang dalan sa langit, wala bakbakig kabulukan.

(The road to heaven is not paved with roses.)

Blaan:

Nang gu kaftaga kabag.

(Do not let the fruit mature according to what the bat wants.)

This view of life leads one, by reflection, to the conclusion that life must be led carefully, prudently, and with maximum good to be accomplished. However, it also necessarily leads one to consider other aspects of life in proper perspective, such as justice, the value of which in the proverbs is expressed in simple, unequivocal, harsh terms.

Ivatan:

Masonusonung a capayhaus nu bac du duduyan by dayem canu catayo su marajet a pinaren.

(It is easier for a cow to pass through the eye of a needle than to hide a crime.)

Zambal:

Hay baboy ya main luway amo

Ay mati nin bitil.

(A pig with two masters,

Will die of hunger.)

Proverbs inculcating the virtues that Filipinos hold dear may also be called ethical proverbs. These virtues include industry, thrift, patience and perseverance, humility, prudence with words and in one’s actions, care and caution, respect and courtesy, forethought and planning, charity and gratitude, family solidarity and harmony, hospitality, and many others. These virtues are expressed in the following proverbs.

Aklanon:

Ro kahugod tuboran it kahamungayaan.

(Industry conquers all hardships.)

Kapampangan:

Nung sasali ka qng e mu cailangan

e lumuat pisali nin in quecang cailangan

(If you buy things that you don’t need,

you will soon sell those that you do need.)

Bikol:

An gapo na matagas, sa tinuturo-turo nin tubig malalagas

(The hardest stone is eroded by constant dropping of water.)

Bukidnon:

Ecacampat mo anga ba ecacampat no ho yan.

(Disregard your winsome beauty, for it will only lead you to immorality.)

Ibanag:

Y sira makanna ta simu na.

(Fish are caught by their mouth, people by their words.)

Pangasinan:

No agmo labay so nadangdang, agka onaasingger ed apoy.

(One who plays with fire gets burned.)

Ilonggo:

Wa’y kinahanglan ang pagsunod sa kabilin sa kabahandianon

Basta makasunod sa kabilin sa maayong pamatasan

(They need not inherit wealth who inherit good manners.)

Bikol:

Ubos-ubos biyaya, pagkaobos tinganga.

(Give away everything wastefully and afterward you will find yourself in want.)

Ivatan:

Anu nangatus ca su cartos ammacalo a capagan, as nu mapia a dadakay am capagan ava.

(Financial indebtedness is easily paid but not a debt of kindness.)

Tagalog:

Sakit ng kalingkingan, damdam ng buong katawan.

(The pain of the little finger is felt by the whole body.)

Proverbs also express a value system, or a way of judging the relative weights and merits of things or conditions that people live with. An object, idea, or condition used as an image in a riddle may be open to two contrasting interpretations or valuations. For instance, wealth is a desirable commodity, because with it come power, prestige, comfort, and security. However, wealth is not the most important thing in life; goodness, honor, sound judgment and discretion, wisdom and intelligence and talent, good name, peace of mind, family and friends, are all considered more valuable than material possessions. This duality of perception is expressed in proverbs such as the following.

Tausug:

In baung-baung makaloon kasunangan biya da astana.

(A hut may hold peace as well as a palace.)

Proverbs make a general statement about life and human nature, in the form of a pragmatic observation distilled from long experience. It is in these observations or reflections on life that the depth and range of folk wisdom is seen. Some proverbs of this category are expressed as self-evident and even literal truisms, with philosophical and social implications, or else are cast in vivid metaphorical language.

Ivatan:

Mapipia anu sumavat ka a maysaosaod su sagap as canu caviden mu du calawangan a manalamad su among.

(It is better to go home and weave a net than to stay on the beach and watch the fish.)

Maranao:

Aia bo penayaon a rominarinao

So ig na masokat a layagan

A Botowanen so lansa.

(We will wait until the

Water is calm

Then we sail.)

While many Philippine proverbs have been transmitted through generations intact, still echoing the age-old folk wisdom of ancestors, historical events and conditions have had a hand in the creation of new proverbs, thus adding to the general trove of oral tradition. The English language has crept into some of them, as in this Cebuano example:

Bisa’g saging, basta labing.

(It does not matter if we have nothing but bananas to eat, as long as there is loving.)

At present, proverbs have also been used to describe contemporary situations. They are not as metaphorical as the traditional proverbs, but there is still wordplay involved. A variety appropriates foreign proverbs to depict local realities, usually by twisting the proverbs’ conclusions:

When it rains … it floods.

Birds of the same feather make a good feather duster.

There are proverbs that have sexual undertones and allusions. Rather than affirming the customs of a society as traditional proverbs do, they interrogate the morals and mores of society. The following example adds a queer spin to a Tagalog proverb; where the original reads, “Walang matinong lalaki sa malanding kumare” (A gentleman is powerless against a flirty woman), the revised version is:

Walang matinong lalaki sa malanding kumpare.

(A well-behaved man is no match for a flirty buddy.)

Some proverbs comment on contemporary social realities, like this Tagalog proverb’s cynical take on the country’s dire economic situation:

Maralita, mayaman, at pamahalaan,

Lahat ay nagkakautang.

(The poor, the rich, and the government

All get into debt.)

Philippine senator Miriam Defensor Santiago collected and popularized a range of satirical proverbs on her social media sites and in a book titled Stupid Is Forever, 2014. The proverbs are about politics, relationships, and other aspects of Filipino life: “The brain of a Filipino politician has two sides: the left has nothing right in it, the right has nothing left in it.”

The following Tagalog examples pour traditional proverbs into cynical molds to forge trenchant criticism of different forms of government corruption, such as patronage (Landicho 2011):

Nasa Diyos ang awa, nasa tao ang gawa,
nasa mga heneral ang biyaya.

(On God is mercy, on man is action,
but on the generals are the blessings.)

Kapag may tiyaga, may nilaga.
Kapag may endorsement, may appointment.

(If you have perseverance, you will get a reward.
If you have an endorsement, you will get an

appointment.)

These political proverbs are not only sayings that provide instruction and insight; they are venues for expressing discontent and for challenging the status quo.

 

Short Poems

Short poems, which are or used to be chanted, may refer to those pieces exceeding two lines, generally quatrains with 5-12 syllables per line. Some types of short poetry are the Tagalog bulong, Ilonggo or Karay-a tara, and Cebuano harito, which are invocations to environmental spirits or animals believed to possess magic powers; children’s nonsense rhymes; the Tagalog tanaga and the dalit; Mangyan ambahan; Ivatan laji; the Bukidnon idangdang and extended basahanan; the Palawan karang; and the Tausug pintasan. Short love poems are the Maguindanaon tubud-tubud or Maranao tubad-tubad. Lyric poems are the Maguindanaon bayok; the Bikol rawitdawit/orog-orog/susuman, consisting of four to eight full or alternating lines per stanza, with six to eight syllables per line; and the Bukidnon limbay and sala. Literary historian Santiago Mulato defines and provides examples of the various types of the folk poetry of Panay. In his study, he identifies the archaic language of the Panayanon as Hiniraya, which was the root of Ilonggo, Kinaray-a, Aklanon, and Capiznon.

Filipinos believe that environmental spirits and some animals with magic powers must be propitiated through invocations. This invocation in Ilocano is addressed to spirits in the tree that one is about to cut down (Yabes 1936, 11):

Bari, bari!

Dika agung-unget pari,

Ta pumukankami Iti pabakirda kadakami.

(Bari, bari

Don’t you get angry, comrade,

And we shall fell some trees

We were told to fell.)

Binabaylan are ceremonious poems, performed in public and led by the babaylan, spiritual leader and value-keeper of the public’s sentiments (Quindoza-Santiago 1997, 144). The Karay-a tara is chanted by the babaylan when one is about to build a house or cultivate a piece of land (Mulato 1989, 18). In a bugyaw (exorcism ritual), the babaylan invokes the spirit guardian of the person possessed by an evil spirit (Villareal 1997, 41). A modern poem written in the mode of binabaylan poetry is Joi Barrios’s “Pagpaslang” (Killing), which is declamatory and calls for a revolution against the repressively masculinist nationalism (Tadiar 2009, 95).

There were many types of babaylan in Panay according to their functions; hence, there were at least as many types of prayers addressed to the diwata (spirits), such as thanksgiving, healing, pleas for a newborn’s good life, pleas for a diwata’s blessing, and so on. The batak-dungan, for example, prays that an infant may grow with intelligence and a fine nature. It was believed that the god of newborns, Andungon, must pull the soul of the infant upward for it to grow wise and good. One whose soul is not pulled upward is believed to grow foolish and useless (Mulato 1989, 16).

One Tagalog bulong is addressed to a duwende (earth spirit) living in an earth mound; another, to a mouse being asked to replace a fallen milktooth (Abueg, Bisa, and Cruz 1981, 4).

Children’s nonsense rhymes, called tulang pambata in Tagalog and ida-ida a rata in Maguindanaon, are sung or recited in a singsong voice, together with finger and hand gestures. Known in the various regions of the country are those that begin with the lines “Pen pen de sarapen” and “Tong tong tong pakitong-kitong.” Here are two other examples (Maramba 1971, 113; Abueg, Bisa, and Cruz 1981, 3):

Biyabu-biyabo

Umakyat ka sa mabolo

At tanawin mo si Piro

Kung may hilang kabayo.

(Biyabu-biyabo

Climb up the mabolo

See if Piro

Is tugging a horse with him.)

Putak, putak!

Batang duwag!

Matapang ka’t nasa pugad!

(Putak, putak!

Little coward!

You’re brave now that you’re in your nest!)

Tulansangan (a portmanteau of tula or poem and lansangan or street coined by Michael Francis C. Andrada) are contemporary forms of children’s poems, recited as they play street games. Influenced by urbanization, this poetic form articulates the city folk’s present condition and is characterized by pastiche, mimicry, and biting humor. One example begins with the opening line of a traditional children’s poem about fruit picking, “Leron, Leron Sinta” (Leron, Leron Beloved), but progresses to using lewd language (Andrada 2007, 55).

Literary historian Bienvenido Lumbera (1986, 12-15) describes the earliest written samples of the tanaga found in Vocabulario de la Lengua Tagala (Vocabulary of the Tagalog Language), 1754, by Juan de Noceda and Pedro de Sanlucar. It was a heptasyllabic, monorhyming quatrain, composed of meditative verses containing observations on life. The quatrain was often a combination of two couplets that could stand alone as aphoristic statements, but sometimes consisted of one cluster of ideas or images that evoked deep feelings or evinced profound thought. As described by Noceda and Sanlucar, the tanaga was an “elevated” form of Tagalog poetry which was “full of metaphors.” The talinghaga in the tanaga was described in the Vocabulario as associated with “mystery, obscurity, and parabolic speech” (Lumbera 1986, 12). The fact that one may take apart a tanaga and produce two couplets does not mean that the poem lacks organic unity. In fact, the tanaga actually consists of only one sentence, either a complex or compound one: if complex, “the subordinate clause takes up the first two lines and the main clause takes up the last two”; and if compound, “the subject of the second independent clause is understood to be the subject of the first.”

 

Anthropologist E. Arsenio Manuel, 1972, surmises that, based on his study of another poetic folk form, the Mangyan ambahan, the fixed stanza form seems to have emerged only during the Spanish colonial period. The ancient native poets may have appropriated some elements of Spanish poetry and combined them with indigenous poetry to produce what have come down to us as the tanaga and the dalit. The tanaga has often been referred to as proverb-like in tone and theme. While this may be true, because both proverb and tanaga apparently are observations on human relationships and life situations, the tanaga exhibits more intense emotions and deeper insight, aside from more poetic lyricism. Furthermore, the tanaga, as it is known now, hews to a strict form, while the proverb is more flexible in structure. The example below shows the tanaga’s characteristics (Lumbera 1986, 14-15):

Ang tubig ma,i, malalim

malilirip cung libdin

itong burhing magaling

maliuag paghanapin.

Though the stream be deep,

it can be fathomed by one who tries;

it is a person’s good heart

that is difficult to discern.

The tanaga has been used by some modern poets to express a modern sensibility or to describe current issues. The following examples of the contemporary tanaga with variations in rhyme schemes are by Rogelio G. Mangahas, 1967; Jose F. Lacaba, 1979; Marra PL. Lanot, 1993; and an anonymous Ilonggo poet of the political “underground” movement, 1982, respectively:

sa batis, yaong buwa’y

sanghiwang pakwang-hapon;

gandang nakatatakam

ay di ko mapupukol.

(on the stream, the moon

is a slice of yellow watermelon;

such a tempting vision

I cannot stone.)

…

Tinirador na maya

ang iniwan sa lupa.

Marahang gumagapang

ang rosaryo ng langgam.

(Sparrow felled by a slingshot,

left on the ground.

Slowly creeping

is a rosary of ants.)

…

Bote ng alitaptap

ang gabay ko sa daan.

Ngayo’y nag-aapuhap

sa dilim ng tahanan.

(Jar of fireflies

is my guide on the road.

Now I am groping

In the darkness of my house.)

…

Indi ka magsalig

Barotong wa’y katig,

Kay Marcos nga promisa

Nga may apid nga bala!

(Do not rely

On a boat without a sail,

Nor on Marcos’s promises

That come with bullets!)

Modern technology has been used to collect and publish tanaga. Textanaga, launched by the National Committee on the Literary Arts of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, uses short message service or SMS to record contemporary tanaga (Nadera 2005), like this one by Mark John Abeleda:

Nang ako’y nag-aabang

Ng tala’t bulalakaw

Bigla kang napadaan

At ako’y tinamaan.

(While I looked up

For a star and a meteor

You walked past

And I was smitten.)

Contemporary tanaga has also been published on social media platforms like Twitter. Tweetanaga delimits the tanaga to 140 characters or less (Go 2013), as this tweetanaga from Jian Yumol exemplifies:

Pagmasdan mo ang araw

Hindi upang mabulag.

Bagkus upang masilaw,

Mapayukó’t mahabag.

(Look at the sun

Not to be blinded

But to be dazzled,

To bow and commiserate.)

In Noceda and Sanlucar’s Vocabulario, the dalit is mentioned as one of the poetic forms used by the ancient Filipinos, together with the tanaga and pamatbat. It was mentioned as a type of awit or song, and identified with the Spanish copla, which was a traditional Spanish ballad or sung poem (Lumbera 1986, 32). The dalit was originally a native oral poem, but most recorded examples we have date to the colonial period. As used by the missionary poets in the late 17th and early 18th centuries, the dalit took the form of a monorhyming quatrain with octosyllabic lines. A number of poems in this form in the Vocabulario appear to be genuine remnants of the dalit. There is not much difference between the tanaga and the dalit in theme and form, except for the number of syllables per line, as the following example from the Vocabulario, quoted by Lumbera (1986, 16), would show:

Ang sugat ay cun tinangap,

di daramdamin ang antac

ang aayao, at di mayag

galos lamang magnanacnac.

(When one submits to a wound,

one does not feel the pain;

to one who resists it,

a mere scratch becomes a sore.)

Fr Gaspar de San Agustin in his El Compendio del Arte de la Lengua Tagala (A Compendium of the Grammar of the Tagalog Language), 1703, described the dalit as being “solemn and sententious,” and compared it to what the Greeks and Romans would have considered as epic dithyrambs. The missionary poets were quick to use the form of the dalit as a religious poem, as exemplified by Fr Pedro de Herrera’s 185-quatrain Meditaciones, cun manga Mahal na Pagninilay na Sadia sa Santong Pag Eexercicios (Meditations, or Holy Reflections Proper to the Spiritual Exercises), 1645. During the 1890s, however, Marcelo H. del Pilar wrote his poem “Dalit” to depict the sufferings of the people in the hands of the Spanish friars.

The dalit, as it is now sung in wakes, consists of solo and choral parts sung alternately:

Solo: Ako’y nagtanim ng saging,

sa pilapil ko itinanim:

kaya ko do’n itinanim,

silungan ng manananim.

Chorus: Sa Diyos natin ialay

Kaluluwa ng namatay:

Patawari’t kaawaan

sa nagawang kasalanan.

(Solo: I planted a banana tree,

I planted it on the dike:

I planted it there so that

The planters can rest in its shade.

(Chorus: To God let us offer

The soul of the one who has died:

Forgive and have mercy

For any sin committed.)

The Mangyan ambahan has been defined by Antoon Postma (1972, 1) as a poem with seven syllables per line, with a rhyme scheme. It is chanted with no definite musical pitch nor musical accompaniment. It presents a human experience or a situation by means of metaphor.

In its present poetic form, the ambahan is known to exist only among the Hanunuo Mangyan of southern Oriental Mindoro. The poetry of Mangyan actually possess qualities of other types of poetry, such as the urukay, which is usually chanted with the accompaniment of a homemade guitar. The ambahan, however, is distinctive because of its structure and its social function. It differs from other indigenous forms of poetry because it is closer to recitative verse rather than to song. Another distinctive feature of the Mangyan ambahan is that it employs a language different from that which is used in ordinary conversation. Thus, it has equivalents for common words, such as bansay for amang (father), suyong for inang (mother), kagnan for danom (water), labag for balay (house), and the like.

Above all, the Mangyan use the ambahan as a form of personal expression and social communication, using plants, animals, and nature symbols in an allegorical way to convey their thoughts and emotions. Thus, the ambahan reveals two kinds of relationships: human beings communicating with each other, and human beings keeping in close touch with their natural environment by drawing inspired thoughts from it.

There are different ambahan for different age groups. The uses of the ambahan are as varied as social functions and human relationships. The ambahan is “used by parents in educating their children, by young people in courting each other, by a visitor in asking for food, by a relative bidding goodbye or farewell,” among other uses (Postma 1972, 9). It has been preserved by the Hanunuo Mangyan not only as a poetic form of personal communication, but also as a communal means of celebration. There are often verbal contests among Mangyan gathered for a feast during reburials of the departed. Thus, the ambahan is also a vehicle for social entertainment, and a means for stimulating the creative and expressive skills of a people in harmony with one another and with nature.

The limbay of Bukidnon are upbeat and lively, sung in drinking sessions often to caution against inebriation and forgetting one’s manners in the company of others. The oyayi, also called panlibay hu bata, are short poems that express undying love of a mother to her baby and soothe it from crying (Unabia 1996, 10-12).

Lyrics that are not sung include bayuk-bayuk and dasang (literally, “to talk with a loud voice”), or dinatu (literally, “the way of the datu”). Performed when welcoming visitors, the dasang are a song-speech performed by datus to express political views and boast about their personal qualities and achievements (Brandeis 2008, 77).

The basahanan or proverbs are extended verse forms. These are recited during a kaamulan (public gathering), or a kagun, the occasion when a young man’s family officially asks for the hand in marriage of a young woman. A basahanan may be anecdotal to drive home a moral, it may be a piece of advice, or it may be allegorical. The following is an example (Opeña 1972, 7):

Hari kag layun ta layun

Ta panglit-aga sa layun

Mampa si Oto sa malangkaw ha nakabulubangkaw

Nagapun daw napagun

Iyan ka mangka sa bun kababa ha bugha.

(Don’t ever go to the other side of the river

For the other side is a trapping ground

Oto, himself a man with a spear and a tall person

Was caught and met his doom

How much more for a short person like you.

You are a girl, what would happen to you?)

Like the basahanan, the daraida and the daragilon of Panay are didactic poems. The daraida uses a central metaphor to impart a bit of wisdom or a practical lesson (Mulato 1989, 26). The daragilon is a didactic quatrain with an alternate rhyme scheme and a central metaphor. This daragilon teaches the value of hard work (Mulato 1989, 27):

Sa panggas nga tinuruan kang balhas

manamit nga uyas ang maani nimo

pay sa bunga kang tinagilhas

malas-ay ang maburaw mo.

(From seeds sown with one’s sweat,

delicious are the grains you will harvest;

but from seeds carelessly planted,

Tasteless are their hastily gathered fruit.)

Three other types of Karay-a or Panay lyric poetry are the gaday, which describes a situation or feeling; the udoy, which soothes, consoles, or calms an angry or sad person; and the tinigbakanon, a quatrain that is assumed to have a meaning that must be deciphered. The gaday was recited in community gatherings, such as those marking the various phases of the agricultural cycle. The people would take turns reciting a gaday; thus, it was also called garaygaray. This excerpt of a garaygaray expresses the people’s economic needs (Mulato 1989, 28):

Nasaog ko ang dulod kang ilog,

nasuba ko ang dulos kang nagaynay,

wara ako it natimbad nga sili—

wara it nasalapuan nga balanak;

nalipat ako sa pagpanigaon

nga ayaay gali kato ang bulan

bisan ang mga dadu kag ubog

maiwat salunuan.

(I followed the river flow

I carefully waded against the current

But there was no eel I could catch with my spear,

no balanak I could find;

I had forgotten to mark the season,

that it was not a month of plenty;

Even the fish in the river

were hardly to be found.)

The tinigbakanon is a quatrain with rhyme, and requires interpretation other than its literal meaning (Mulato 1989, 54):

Kon mapagsik pa ang pakpak

wala sing hinulu sa paglupad,

apang kon lapyu kag kulang kuyos

mapabilin lang sa pugad.

(When the wings are still swift

One can fly ceaselessly

But if weak and lacking feathers

It will stay in the nest.)

The udoy tries to restore a person’s good mood by reminding them of the virtue of self-restraint (Mulato 1989, 54-55):

Wala gid man kita sing makuha

kon ang tagdiutay atong sapakon;

nakatabinas lang ang baba—

nakadalang lang ang dila

kon malulu kita sadto ngaa man

nga aton bungkagon?

pabalikon naton ang nag-agi—

bag-uhon ang dumaan.

(We really don’t gain anything

if we take notice of every trivial thing

Our mouth would only act on impulse—

our tongue would slip;

If we were gentle before,

why destroy what we had?

Let us bring back the past—

change our course.)

The earliest source of information on Cebuano poetry is Arte de la Lengua Zebuana (Grammar of the Cebuano Language), 1801, by the Augustinian Francisco Encina (1715-60). Encina observes that Cebuano poems are assonantal. Verses are structured as couplets or quatrains, with each line consisting of 5-12 but usually 7 syllables and using what he called enigma or tanghaga (Mojares 1993, xiii). The Cebuano word for poem, balak, literally means “intention” and “foregrounds the notion of human intentionality (of speech that issues from a determinate point in the world), of purpose and relation (of someone speaking to someone else)” (Mojares 1998, 302).

The first published Cebuano poem is “Soneto sa Pagdayeg can Santa Maria Gihapon Virgen” (Sonnet in Praise of Saint Mary Ever Virgin) by the Spanish Recollect Tomas de San Geronimo, although precolonial poems in Cebuano, however largely oral, may have already been printed as the inhabitants of the islands already had the capability at the time.

For the Cebuano, the balac (or balak) is an elevated form of poetry, whereas the garay, of which the following is an example, is the more informal type (Alburo et al 1988, 18):

Ako nahikatulog

Sa punoag bayabas;

Akong himat-an

Ang mga kasikas;

Abi ko kadto halas,

Si Inday man diay

Nagsagadsad sa sinilas.

(I fell asleep

’Neath the guava tree

And awoke

To the rustling sound

Of a snake, I thought.

’Twas Inday

Shuffling on her slippers.)

A contemporary garay is found in the chapbook of Cebuano poems Minugbo Alang sa Mugbo og Kalipay (Shorts for the Shortjoyed), 2009, by Adonis Durado. He describes a sound through a catalog of images:

Ang imong hagok:

Trak nga gadahunog sa layo.

Dugdog nga giatakes hubak.

Gabukal nga takore, hapit hubsi.

Yawyaw sa higanteng gangis

Phono nga pudpod og dagom.

Kanta sa bunging nga gabas

(Your snore:

A cargo truck roaring in the distance

Thunder having an asthma attack.

Kettle, nearly whistling itself to dryness

Grumblings of a gigantic cicada.

Phono player with a dulled needle.

Song of a buck-toothed saw.)

The earliest record of the Leytenhon-Samarnon siday is in Fr Ignacio Francisco Alcina’s Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas (History of the Islands and Indios of Visayas), 1668, and there it is described as being sung by a paid ambulant group (Alcina [1668] 1960, 31-33). Today, however, the word siday generally refers to forms of verses in Waray (Javines 1992, 203). The literature of Eastern Visayas was reinvented during the Spanish and American colonization, sometimes taking new names and imbibing new influences but retaining its traditional form (Sugbo 2011). Samar-Leyte writers at the turn of the 20th century, such as the poets Eduardo Makabenta Sr, Iluminado Lucente, and Casiano Trinchera, “wrote in rhymed quatrains, the lines balanced in strict syllabic measure by a caesura” (Alunan 2014). Moreover, because the strength of the language lies in its aural qualities, the tone is declamatory. A poem like “Pag Bangon, Pepe!” (Rise Up, Pepe!), written in 1909 by Lucente, has the aformentioned qualities, as this excerpt from it shows:

Waray pa gad kabug-os an am kahimayaan

Nga an tuman nasalidsid nga imo binayaan

Buhat, pag bangon anay dida ha imo lubnganan

Kadi-a kami panubsa han amon kakurian

(We have not fully realized our glory

Which you seem to have almost deserted

Rise up! Rise up from the grave

Save us from our destitution.)

Contemporary writers of siday have avoided rhyme and meter but retain a strong sense of place, as found in Voltaire Oyzon’s “Hi Uday” (Uday):

[Hi Uday] pinamutos na an mga panapton

“Nadiri ak’ hin langsa …

Nadiri ak’ hin lusak …

An salog han Himanglos?

An dagat han Carigara?

An bukid han Biliran?

Si ahh! Di ko pag-iiliwon,

di ko pamimilngon,

di ko paglilioton.

Didto han tuna nga iya kinadto,

nasunit hiya. Nagsaklang han lubi

agud makita an isla han Leyte.

([Uday] has packed up all her clothes

“I hate the stench of fish …

I don’t like the mud …

And what about Himanglos River?

Carigara Bay?

The mountain of Biliran?

Si ahh, I won’t miss them,

I won’t long for them.”

One day in the new land where she’d gone,

she felt a piercing pain.

She climbed a coconut tree

To catch a glimmer of the isle of Leyte.)

Subanon poems use imagery through agglutinative language and often, like the example below, mention place-names to narrate “deeply humanized, historicized landscape” (Mojares 2013, 66):

Dumelinaw, mipenglaw

Pelanduk, gumindaw

Lumegem, pilebu’an

Lubetis, pinegyaan.

(Dumelinaw became a lonely stream

Pelanduk asked where all had gone

Lumegem was humbled by a frightful plague

Lubetis suffered unutterable shame.)

In the anthologies Sikami’n Lumad (We Are the Indigenous People), 2006, and A Voice from Mt. Apo: Oral and Written Essays on the Culture and World View of the Manobo, 2005, is “Tonggapow kos Ginawa Ku” (Accept My Love), a poem by Retchor Umpan that is a continuation of Manobo poetic tradition.

The Gaddang lallao, which is also usually sung, is a versatile poetic form. It may impart a moral or a piece of advice, express a sentiment, or confirm the communal spirit (Lumicao-Lora 1984, 81).

The Ivatan’s lyric poem is the laji, which is also sung. It consists of 14-syllable unrhymed lines, with the 4th, 7th, 10th, and 14th syllable of each line being stressed. The subject matter of the laji reveals the Ivatan’s concern with social standing, virtue, character, and social relationships. Some of the words used may be archaic, or if ordinary, the meanings may be deliberately hidden with the use of poetic embellishments. At social events like courtship and betrothal ceremonies, rituals, drinking sessions, and funeral wakes, the Ivatan play at guessing the meaning of the poem (Hornedo 1979).

The Tausug poems, tarasul, aim to impart a lesson as they entertain. “Although they are often written down, these poems are meant to be recited since one’s enjoyment of them derives less from their content as from the sound of their words, rhymes, and cadence” (Rixhon 2010, 352). Websites dedicated to tarasul by young writers, like tarasulnet.com, publish poems that use rhyme.

 

Poetic Jousts

A contest of wit and verse improvisation is the poetic joust. The Cebuano and Aklanon balitao is a flirtatious impromptu debate. The banggianay of Panay is a contest between two objects personified, which argue about which is the better one. The Ilonggo siday sa pamalaye, Cebuano pamalaye, or Karay-a hungaw is an exchange between the spokespersons of two families who are conducting marriage negotiations; the Ilocano dallot, which developed in the 19th century into the arikenken, is a chanting joust between a man and a woman. The Isneg’s poetic debate is called the anenas; among the Tausug, it is the daman. The ancient Bikol kangsin or abatayo, and in recent times called tigsik, is a toast competition during a drinking session.

The Bikol tigsik consists of “a series of toasts offered during [drinking] bouts” (Espinas, Altarejos, and Gegantoca 1983, 68). Each participant, before taking a sip of tuba, recites a four-line stanza, and then passes on the glass of tuba to the next person. The didactic character of the proverb is also found in the tigsik.

The tigsik may also take the form of a puzzle (Realubit 1983, 99):

Anom na sawa marara sa limang bobon,

Pano na an aagihan kan lambang saro dai magdoot sa manarosaro?

(Six snakes will drink in five ponds,

How will they manage not to touch each other?)

One banggianay is an exchange between the morning star and the evening star, each presenting arguments why one is superior to the other. One banggianay is between the buri and the lubi (coconut tree), arguing about which of them is more useful. The buri boasts that its trunk can be made into a beam, a floor, or a rafter for the house, whereas the lubi contends that its leaf, fruit, stalk, and fiber all have uses (Mulato 1989, 14).

The Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Karay-a siday sa pamalaye begins when the young man’s family and their spokesman call on the woman’s family, who, forewarned of their coming, have pulled up the ladder to the house. After the preliminary greetings, recited in verse, the woman’s family lowers the ladder and their spokeswoman bids them enter. They initially reject the proposal by making up some unattractive qualities they claim she possesses. The man presses his suit by asserting that she was a lovely sight when he saw her at the brook. When she denies this, he insists (Mulato 1989, 87).

In the 19th century, the indigenous poetic joust evolved into a folk game sometimes involving a man and a woman, sometimes a group of men and a group of women. The Tagalog duplo/dupluhan involves role-playing, with the men playing the belyako (male rogue), the women the belyaka (female rogue), and one leader playing the “king” or punong halamanan. Variations are the luwa in Kinaray-a and Ilonggo, and the karagatan or bulaklakan in Kapampangan.

The luwa (or loa) of Western Visayas is performed by young men and women during wakes to entertain the grieving family. Its origin cannot be ascertained and recitations differ in each region. Luwa commonly consists of rhyming quatrains. The meter varies but is usually iambic or anapestic (Villareal 1997, 103-7). When one fails to rhyme, the participants cry out, “Estangko!” and the poet has to quickly change the lines to correct that lapse.

Blog sites, such as Luwa of Western Visayas, maintained by Melchor F. Cichon, solicits contemporized versions and puts the mainly oral form in print. The poems retain the rhyming scheme and the jest attendant to the form, but the medium renders the actual exchange between two poet-participants impossible.

The secular folk poetry of Southern Leyte includes balitao and kulilisi. The balitao (or balitaw), which grew most popular in Cebu, dates back to precolonial Visayas but it flourished in the Spanish colonial era. Antiphonal in structure, the poetic courtship dialogues are accompanied by a song and dance (Go-Saga 2010, 106-7). Below is an excerpt from “Kita Karon ang Nagasaibay” (We Are Now Pacing):

Lalaki:

Ako, Inday, ang mangasawa

Ako ikaw ang pagapanggaon,

Palingkoron ko ikaw sa siya

Witikwitikan sa akong agwa

Babaye:

Ako, Iyo, ang magatore

Kong husto ikaw nga lalaki

Kuhaon ang akong silaw

Kon masidlak na ang adlaw.

(Man:

I, Inday, will marry

You, I will take care,

I will seat you on a chair,

I’ll spray you with my perfume.

Woman:

I, Iyo, will stay at the tower,

If you are the right man

Fetch my rays

When the sun shines.)

The kulilisi (or kulalisi), like the luwa in Western Visayas, is performed during wakes to entertain the bereaved family. There are two types: the courtship dialogues between groups of men and women, and a court hearing that involves the poetic debate between the berdugo (prosecutor) and the defensor (defense counsel).

In the 20th century, the Tagalog duplo gave birth to the balagtasan in the 1920s. Named after the 19th-century Tagalog poet Francisco Balagtas Baltazar, this formal debate in verse tackled set topics; for example, which is more important—labor or capital, the woman of yesterday or the woman of today, gold or steel. This contest of wit requires protagonists to prepare beforehand their arguments in dodecasyllabic quatrains with monorhyme. A Lakandiwa acts as mediator and judge. The first balagtasan was staged in 1924. Later, there were balagtasan in Ilocano called bukanegan and in Kapampangan called crissotan.

Rap battles are considered by some academics as the modern balagtasan, although some Filipino rappers reject the connection (Angeles 2014). Following hip-hop and alternative rap, this form of American-influenced verbal joust uses internal and offbeat rhymes. Rap battles have attracted many fans, many of them the youth, who follow such competitions live or online. FlipTop, which began in 2010, is the first Filipino rap battle league. In rap, a “flip” refers to the act of returning an insult; the object of a FlipTop battle, with which rap battles in the country have been identified, appears to be for one to “top” the opponent’s insult with a worse one (“FlipTop”).

 

A rap battle usually consists of three rounds. There is a moderator, and the outcome is decided on by a panel of judges. Competitors use obscenities and make disparaging remarks about the opponent’s physical appearance, social background, gender, or rapping abilities. The rap battles may be said to be an index of what contemporary society consider undesirable or ridiculous. Primarily a male activity, insults take the form of arousing patriarchal anxieties; rappers often resort to questioning their opponents’s masculinity or to declaring that their opponents have been cheated on by their girlfriends.

In Zamboanga, rap battles are called encuentro. This example has a rapper making fun of his opponent’s physical appearance:

Kulang ang sampung minuto para laitin ka

Pero kulang din ang sampung taon para papogiin ka.

…

Ganyan pala pag galing sa Pluto

Eto ’yong alien na nagbebenta ng puto

Magbenta ka na lang ng sigarilyo sa town

Tapos suutin mo rin ’yong paborito mong gown.

 

(Ten minutes are not enough for me to mock you

But neither are ten years for me to groom you.

…

So that’s how those from Pluto are

This is the alien who sells rice cakes

Just sell cigarettes in town

Don’t forget to wear your favorite gown.)

His opponent replies in Chabacano:

Ta abla bo comigo kay di mi diente bulok

Ya confesa yo con Castigo

Ya abla yo de bo nobya

Kami dos ya man tulipan.

(You said my teeth were rotten

I’ve already let you know

I’ve already told you about your girl

The two of us made out.)

Conclusion

Folk poetry, as part of the Philippine ethnic tradition, has not disappeared. It continues to be responsive to current events, which are depicted sometimes with a gentle, wry humor, at other times with a melancholic tone. It is perhaps its very topicality that has made it endure through hundreds of years of Spanish and American colonialism.  Written by Damiana Eugenio, Edgardo Maranan, and Rosario Cruz-Lucero, updated by Jay Jomar F. Quintos and Julian de la Cerna
