article.value: Kenkoy started as a filler composed of only four frames, but by the end of the year, the adventures of Kenkoy and his friends—Talakitok, Nanong Pandak, Rosing, Ponyang Halobaybay, Sarhento (later Medyor) Dikyam, Mang Terong—occupied a full page of the magazine. The series was so popular that it was translated into Cebuano, Hiligaynon, and Ilocano (Jurilla 2008, 134); the word kenkoy has come to mean “clownish” in colloquial Tagalog; and at least two characters—Ponyang Halobaybay and Nanong Pandak—became the stars of their own, eponymously titled, comic strips. Kenkoy would survive World War II and last until the late 1980s.

In the 1930s, the comics section of Liwayway grew to include the adventures of Deo Gonzales’s Saryong Albularyo (from herbolario, a village doctor who works with herbs and other traditional medicine); Goyo and Kikay, an amiable couple whose names typify the local folk; Jose Zabala Santos’s Lukas Malakas, a big-muscled, civic-spirited, clean-living, and good-looking fellow who helps people in distress; Huapelo, a stock figure of ridicule with racial undertones; and other characters whose zany antics tickled the readers’s funny bone. The language used was Manila-based Tagalog.

The primary goal of these comic strips was to purvey fun and laughter by regaling the readers of Liwayway with accounts of mistaken identities, coincidences, foibles, and fumbles—situations that inevitably led to browbeating, fistfights, and battles of wit. The artwork was also cartoony. Thus, they were the equivalent of the “funnies” or cartoon strips of American newspapers.

Kulafu, written by Pedrito Reyes and illustrated by Francisco Reyes, is the first comic strip that was not a cartoon. Published in Liwayway beginning in 1933 and ending in 1941, Kulafu was derived from the phenomenally successful character created by Edgar Rice Burroughs, Tarzan. Set in precolonial times in the jungles of southern Philippines, Kulafu features a boy raised by apes, fighting numerous battles with people and nature. Kulafu offered readers another kind of entertainment—the heroic action tale that was to become a staple of the comic book.
After World War II, comic strips, like Francisco Coching’s Hagibis, which was similar in theme to Kulafu, continued to appear in Liwayway and other periodicals.
Rise of the Komiks (1946-90)

While comic strips continued to be published on the pages of Liwayway, the independent comic book came into existence after World War II. The earliest venture, which proved to be short-lived, was Halakhak Komiks, 1946, published by Jaime Lucas. Humorous cartoons, serialized novels, stories, historical vignettes and folklore, as well as crossword puzzles, song lyrics, and even sociopolitical editorials were the contents of each 42-page issue (Jurilla 2008, 134). Although it attracted the fledgling industry’s biggest names, such as Francisco Reyes, Francisco Coching, Jose Zabala Santos, Malang Santos, and Larry Alcala, it folded up after its 10th issue. Nonetheless, it gave birth to the komiks and would “set the pattern in terms of appearance and content that many publications would follow” (135).

Given its format, komiks had the freedom to go beyond laughter and parody, to transcend the limitations on material and theme imposed on comic strips by their being a mere supplement of a magazine. There was now room for other experiences: family conflicts, fantasy and adventure, romance, oppression and class conflict, sports, crime, and other aspects of actual as well as imagined lives. The form taken could be that of the funny cartoon filler for the first and last pages of a komiks; a short story called wakasan, with a wakas or ending, for those who wanted the stories completed in one issue; a serialized novel; or an ongoing series that tells a complete story with every issue.

Undaunted by the failure of Halakhak, Ramon Roces decided to go into comic book publishing and established Ace Publications in 1947 for that purpose. In Jun 1947, he published Pilipino Komiks, with Velasquez as editor. After the initial success of this venture, three other Ace publications came out: Tagalog Klasiks, 1949; Hiwaga Komiks, 1950; and Espesyal Komiks, 1952. These comprised the highly successful quartet of Ace Publications komiks, which featured the country’s leading writers and illustrators. In addition to those mentioned above, there were Clodualdo del Mundo Sr, Mars Ravelo, Pablo S. Gomez, Nestor Redondo, Ben Alcantara, and Jim Fernandez. The illustrators were Elpidio Torres, Jesse Santos, Ading Gonzalez, Federico Javinal, Tony Henson, among others. In many cases, the writers were themselves the illustrators, exerting complete control over their material, or drew for their peers.

In 1962, with Ace Publications suffering from labor problems, Roces established Graphic Arts Services Inc (GASI). It published new titles: Kislap Komiks, Aliwan Komiks, Pioneer Komiks, Pinoy Klasiks, and Holiday Komiks. Two years later, Roces set up Pilipino Komiks Inc (PKI), which revived the Ace Publications komiks. It would be renamed Atlas Publishing Corporation and become “the most prestigious of comic book publishers in the Philippines” (Jurilla 2008, 139).

The success of the Ace comic books encouraged other publishers to join the field. The 1950s saw the emergence of Extra Komiks, Romansa Komiks, Manila Klasiks, and Bulaklak Express, and in the 1960s, the heyday of the komiks, of Filipino Thriller Komiks, Romantic Klasiks Magasin, Dalisay Komiks, Pag-ibig Komiks, Sindak Komiks, Teen-Age Komiks, Diamante Komiks, Ditektib Komiks, Fantasia Komiks, Lagim Komiks, Ligaya Komiks, Sweethearts Komiks, Wakasan Komiks, United Komiks, Universal Komiks, Kidlat Komiks, Continental Komiks, Redondo Komiks Magasin, Alcala Fight Komix Magasin, Bolniks, Lindelmel Komiks, among others. The titles suggest the scope that the komiks amassed at its peak: humor, romance, fantasy, horror, mystery, sports. In 1965, there were over 50 komiks in circulation, nine of which were Roces-owned (Jurilla 2008, 140). None of the 39 komiks, however, survived the competition offered by the Roces-owned komiks, whose dominance would continue until the decline of the komiks industry.

The 1950s saw movie producers turning to komiks, in some cases, catapulting unknown actors and actresses to stardom: Tessie Agana in Roberta, 1951; Lolita Rodriguez and Dolphy in Jack and Jill, 1954; Rosa del Rosario in Darna, 1951, and Darna at ang Babaing Lawin (Darna and the Hawkwoman), 1952; and Edna Luna in Dyesebel, 1953. “Kenkoy” was adapted for the screen in 1951. The komiks would prove to be a reliable source for box-office material throughout the decades. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, however, a reverse process was observable, the movies infiltrating the komiks. Bondying Weekly Movie Specials, Ravelo Komiks, Kampeon Komiks, and Nora Aunor Entertainment Magazine combined illustrated stories with articles on show business. Stars appeared on the magazine covers; columns focusing on the goings-on in the film industry formed an important section of the komiks. Nora Aunor Entertainment Magazine, later renamed Superstar Entertainment Magazine, was an obvious attempt to attract the fans of Nora Aunor, the first actress in the country’s movie history to be accorded “superstar” status.

The changing mores in the early 1970s gave birth to the sexually explicit komiks. Simultaneous with the rise of the so-called bomba or bold movies, a number of komiks magazines, not produced by the established komiks publishers, came out and presented a new view of sex and sexuality. The stories in these magazines, with sexually suggestive titles such as Seksee, Barako, Bikini, and Toro, featured themes dealing with love licit and illicit, seduction and adultery, prostitution, and various forms of sexual aberration.

This new breed of komiks seemed to duplicate what films featuring Stella Suarez, Merle Fernandez, and other “bomba stars,” dared to make explicit on-screen—the pleasures and sensations of sexual love. In the older komiks, sexual love was depicted by a kiss, sometimes accompanied by speech balloons indicating moaning; or more euphemistically, by a view of waves lapping at the shore on a moonlit night; or silhouettes of the partners in bed covered in sheets. The bomba komiks, however, showed a lot of flesh in various postures of sexual struggle or bliss.

This revised view of love invariably generated widespread outrage, not the least from the legitimate publishers whose share of profits was decreasing. In 1972, Ferdinand Marcos declared martial law; and in its wake, the Kapisanan ng mga Publisista at Patnugot ng mga Komiks-Magasin sa Pilipino (KPPKP) was established by komiks publishers and editors as an act of self-censorship and as a response to the directive from the government-controlled press bureau. The KPPKP guidelines prohibited the use of cuss words and depictions of nudity, sex orgies, political corruption, crooked cops, clerics in love, among other sensitive subjects.

Such KPPKP guidelines were based on the code of ethics of the Association of Editors of Philippine Comic Magazines, established in 1955, but the KPPKP went further by expanding its guidelines to make them align with the goals of the Marcos government (Lent 1998, 241). In direct or subtle ways, the komiks was used to push the developmental goals of the state, a practice that goes back to the immediate postwar years. In the 1950s, the komiks promoted the government’s anti-insurgency campaign especially in areas where the Huks (anti-Japanese guerrillas) were quite strong. In the 1960s and 1970s, the form was used by a number of government institutions, such as the Department of Health and the Population Center. During the martial law period, the komiks became the means for the government to sell the ideas of the Green Revolution, birth control, the beautification of the “City of Man,” the decongestion of Metro Manila. The komiks was also used “to warn against pollution and drug taking and to promote nuclear power” and “to explain the roles of elected officials and to propagandize the services offered to communists who surrender” (243). After martial law, the komiks were used to explain to the people the whys and wherefores of the country’s staggering debt to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, and the horrendous implications of such indebtedness.

However, this developmental thrust could not be sustained given a venture as commercial as the komiks. Writers ignored the guidelines, and eventually, the komiks took the public into a world of mayhem, blood and gore, fantasy, thrill, and the many forms of vicarious pleasure. The code discouraged the depiction of “horrifying creatures,” but writers and illustrators invented such oddities as “the moving skeletal hand, the flying elephant boy, the woman with two demonic creatures on her breasts, the villains with snakes on their heads, the three-headed girl, and more” (Lent 1998, 242).

The bomba komiks also made a dramatic comeback in the 1980s. This time around, more magazines emerged and flourished with such naughty titles as Hayop, Bold, Lagablab, Boobs, and Sakdal-Erotic. The last mentioned was a revival of a 1950s magazine that contained highly suggestive illustrations to accompany the spicy, often explicit text describing purported “true-life” police stories about sexual crimes, such as rape and adultery. Alongside this revival, however, was the appearance of Gospel Komiks, 1980, which, as its title suggests, was for religious purposes.

A comic book for children was created by Islas Filipinas Publishing, another Roces-owned firm. Titled Pilipino Funny Komiks, 1978, it consisted of humorous series, cartoons, complete stories, and educational sections. Among the memorable series in the komiks were Velasquez’s “Tsikiting Gubat,” Tonton Young’s “Lilit Bulilit,” Alcala’s “Bing Bam Boom,” Roni Santiago’s “Planet Opdi Eyps,” Leandro S. Martinez’s “Superkat,” and Pat Reyes’s “Niknok.” Two other komiks for children were published in the 1980s: Bata Batuta Komiks and For Children Only Komiks.

At the end of the Marcos regime, the komiks industry seemed to have reached another peak: there were 10 firms publishing 47 mainstream titles, with a collective circulation of 2.5 million and an estimated readership of 15-18 million (del Mundo 1986, 183-84).

This state of affairs was not to last long. The very popularity of the komiks triggered the decline in the quality of the form; it fell prey to commercial interests. The increasing demand meant that writers and illustrators would eventually overstretch themselves: Elena Patron, Nerissa Cabral, and Gilda Olvidado were churning out 14 novel installments per week; Mar T. Santana was drawing for 17 series, including four of his own (del Mundo 1986, 180). At one time, Carlo J. Caparas was writing 36 series a week. Relying on volume to earn, some illustrators took on five to eight titles a week (Lent 1998, 242-45). Economic pressures, including relatively low pay, led to the exodus of the better writers and illustrators, either to the United States or to other industries like the movies or television, and consequently to the stultification of the komiks (Lent 2014, 60-61).

Then, to break the Roces monopoly, rival publishers lowered cost by hiring lesser-known artists and using cheaper materials, further diminishing the quality of the komiks (del Mundo 1986, 185). As the quality of the komiks declined, the appeal of rival entertainment media rose. In the 1990s, the komiks was eclipsed by television as the preferred source of entertainment by the masa, or the common people, which had formed the core readership of the komiks (Jurilla 2008, 158). In the absence of competition, the industry died when the Roces monopoly folded up (Lent 2014, 61).
Types of Komiks Content

The contents of the komiks fell into several broad categories. Among them were those that dealt with humor, usually titled after their main protagonists, like Alcala’s Kalabog en Bosyo (Kalabog and Bosyo), ca. 1949, originally titled Ang Kalabog (Thud), about a duo of bumbling detectives; the first comics strip to use corrupt Spanish, English, and Tagalog, Tipin, ca. 1951, subtitled “Yur Peborit Tin-edyer” (Your Favorite Teenager) and appropriately about the entanglements of teenage life; Asiong Aksaya (Wasteful Asiong), 1976; Pablo Gomez’s Susanang Daldal (Susan the Chatterbox), ca. 1962, whose gossip mongering gets her and others into scrapes; Bert Sarile and Polly Rallanca’s Barok, 1973, the first comic strip to be set in the Stone Age; and Sarile’s other creations like Max ’n Jess, a tall-and-short pairing patterned after the American comic strip Mutt and Jeff, Ping at Pong (Ping and Pong), about two friends who sport Elvis-like hairstyle, and Tartan, a bastardization of Tarzan. A number of these humorous strips have inspired movies, and barok has come to mean fractured Tagalog, after the way the characters in the series speak.

Some of these humorous series, in hindsight, provided more than just fun. Ravelo’s Buhay Pilipino (Philippine Life) offered insights into local family life in the 1940s and 1950s. The humor in some series could actually be disturbing in their assumption and endorsement of a potentially repressive normativity. Pablo Gomez’s Kurdapya (Screwball) and Ravelo’s Baby Bubut, in their respective eponymously titled series, were women afflicted with a “handicap”—one was not pretty by popular standards, the other simply refused to grow up (bubut means “a stunted fruit”). Similarly, Bondying and Fefita Fofonggay were male characters with “aberrations”—the one an overgrown boy dressed in mameluco or children’s attire, the other an effeminate homosexual. Both are finally transformed into “normal” males when their heterosexual feelings are roused. Jack and Jill by Ravelo likewise uses love to rectify the protagonists sexual identities. The male and female characters in these series were depicted as the butt of society’s jokes, the ridicule and humiliation ending only when the “right” man or woman came along.

The second category of komiks series was the fantastic, which can be further subdivided. In such series, sirens and nymphs fall in love with mortals; barrio lasses and village blacksmiths are given supernatural powers; horses and roosters talk; magic bilao (winnowing tray), fountain pens, swords, and pushcarts fly; mysterious hands stalk and murder innocent victims; vampires and other preternatural creatures haunt and hunt prey; satyrs and other creatures sow terror. Harimanok (King Rooster), Petrang Kabayo (Petra the Horse), Darko, Silveria, Pungkuy and the Magic Bilao (Pungkuy and the Magic Winnowing Tray), Karina Kariton (Karina the Pushcart Girl), Diyosa (Goddess), Super Balulang, Ada, The Hands, Mambo Dyambo (Mumbo Jumbo) were some of these creatures.

Of the supernatural creatures, Ravelo’s Dyesebel and Jim Fernandez’s Zuma are probably the most memorable. Dyesebel, the protagonist of her own series, is a mermaid born of a human mother and a merman father. She falls in love with a human, but tormented by a jealous mermaid under the sea and abused by humans on land, Dyesebel’s path to happiness is tempest-tossed. Zuma, who had first appeared in the series Aztec before starring in a series of his own, is the son of the ancient Aztec god of snakes and has a double-headed snake on his shoulders. He sows terror when he is revived in the present world, unstoppable but for Galema, his daughter, and Dino, his son, monsters both. Both Dyesebel and Zuma have been reincarnated in the movies and on television various times. So popular was Zuma that it even spawned prequels and sequels: Anak ni Zuma (Child of Zuma) was 500-episode long and ran for over a decade in Aliwan (Lent 1998, 244).

The fantastic need not always involve supernatural creatures. Ravelo’s Maruja was built on the idea of reincarnation: a pair of lovers separated during the Spanish colonial period are reunited a hundred years later. Patron’s Blusang Itim (Black Blouse) used the ugly duckling motif: the homely Jessa is transformed into a beautiful woman when she puts on a magic black blouse.

One branch of the fantastic was the historical adventure fantasy, which became popular in the early years of the Philippine comics. These series drew on the imagined past and the world of the metrical romances. Del Mundo and Coching appeared to be the pioneers of such colorful narratives of love and adventure, of handsome princes and beautiful damsels in distress, of indios (Christianized native) courageously fighting conquistadores. Such were del Mundo’s Prinsipe Paris (Prince Paris), Prinsipe Adonis (Prince Adonis), and Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante); and Coching’s Sabas: Ang Barbaro (Sabas: The Barbarian), El Indio (The Native), and Lapu-Lapu. From one perspective, these tales by the first generation of Philippine comics writers were a “way of asserting the continued relevance of the past” to a population that had become immersed in Western culture (Reyes 2009, 405-6).

The superhero series are modeled after American superhero comic books. Of the type, Ravelo was probably the master. For decades since the 1950s, he created such heroes as Darna, after Wonder Woman; Captain Barbel, after Captain Marvel; and Lastikman, after Plastic Man. Other superheroes that Ravelo created include Kapitan Boom, Tiny Tony, Flash Bomba, and Dragonna. Outside of Ravelo’s universe is Caparas’s enduring Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), created in the 1970s. A humble blacksmith named Flavio makes a dagger out of the metal from a meteor and a churchbell. The dagger turns into a sword powerful enough to cut through anything. With it, Flavio disperses the forces of evil.

In the superhero genre, the hero is usually a person of humble or ordinary origin with a physical affliction. He or she miraculously receives a magical gift, which could be a charm or an amulet, that endows him or her with supernatural powers. The charm is given on the condition that it be used to defend the weak and the downtrodden. In some cases, it is a chemical explosion or interspecies mutation that enables unassuming men and women to become their superhero alter egos. The heroes fight all kinds of enemies—criminals, the forces of nature, animals, creatures from Philippine folklore, and even beings from outer space. The last indicates the influence of science fiction on the Philippine comics. The main character of Jim Fernandez and Hal Santiago’s Zarbot, for example, is a robot made from pieces of an asteroid. Komiks readers were also introduced to characters like del Mundo’s Zarex, Santiago’s Astrobal, and Jeric, the boy from Mars.

A third broad category of komiks content was the melodrama. The focus is on the individual and immediate family, the forces that conspire to bring about estrangement, suffering, and even death. Ravelo’s tale of the persecuted child in Roberta is a clear indication of this very powerful trend in the komiks: the preoccupation with the pain and suffering of an innocent victim of cruelty and greed. This interest in situations revolving around family conflicts has been given numerous expressions. The plot can show the depth of a mother’s love as in Del Mundo’s Malvarosa or Patron’s Kapatid Ko ang Aking Ina (I Am My Mother’s Sister), or Ravelo’s Wanted: Perfect Mother; a young woman’s struggle to eke out a living, as in Gomez’s Eva Fonda: 16 or Gilda; the ebb and flow of romantic love as in Ravelo’s Bitter Sweet, Caparas’s Somewhere, Olvidado’s Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear); the plight of an unwanted child, as in Ravelo’s Trudis Liit (Little Trudis) and Gomez’s Nobody’s Child; or a serious issue, such as homosexuality and its effects on the members of a family, as in Ravelo’s Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold) and Orlando Nadres’s Ang Tatay Kong Nanay (My Father the Mother).

Although a popular genre from the very beginning, the melodrama attracted more readers in the 1970s with the entry into the scene of some of the most creative female writers: Elena Patron, Nerissa Cabral, and Gilda Olvidado. If the likes of Caparas and Fernandez celebrate manhood and all the traits associated with the Filipino macho ideals, the female novelists focus on women as central characters: the faithful wife, the suffering mother, the torch singer, the grateful daughter, the other woman, and the experiences these women undergo in the process of defining themselves. In such series as Olvidado’s Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You) and Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?) or Cabral’s Bukas Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel) and Paano Ba ang Mangarap? (How Does One Dream?) or Patron’s Lord, Give Me a Lover, the writers explore the complexities of familial and romantic relationships and delineate intensely powerful emotions that grip the different characters, particularly their desire for a person or their quest for something. Cabral’s “Tinik sa Dibdib” (Thorn in the Chest) is one of the best examples of a contemporary melodrama. The protagonist Lorna confronts life’s many challenges, living with a deaf-mute sister, an uncaring mother, and a cruel stepfather in the already demeaning condition of material poverty. By the 1980s, the melodramas of these authors were being made into commercially successful movies.

Aside from the comic, fantastic, and melodramatic, a fourth category was the action stories. Such series had the male or female hero fighting a horde of enemies. Included in this category were mystery stories such as Damy Velasquez’s DI-13, the local version of Dick Tracy; adventure stories such as Nestor Redondo’s Alyas Palos (Alias Palos); and sports stories such as Carlo J. Caparas’s Mong, Magic 5, and Juan Tornado (Reyes 2009, 410).

In the first decades of the komiks, the action stories penned by Coching, Francisco Reyes, and del Mundo presented heroes that were ideally good. Over time, however, the nature of the protagonists gradually changed. Action stories highlighted people on the wrong side of the law, fugitives rebelling against, or escaping, an unjust and oppressive system.

Long treated as a medium suited to inferior intellects for its gross simplification, falsification, or distortion of reality, the komiks assumed the role of social critic in such stories as Dirty Politician, Sumpain Ka Nawa! (A Curse on You!), El Vibora (The Viper), Magnong Mandurukot (Magno the Thief), Tulisan (Bandit), Totoy Bato (Totoy the Rock), Angela Markado (Angela the Marked One), among others, in which the writers succeed in reflecting the more sordid aspects of society. Featured are corrupt politicians, ruthless landlords, criminal syndicates, mulcting policemen, petty thieves, and the arrogant rich, all of whom use power to victimize the slum dweller, job hunter, vendor, the innocent and provincial woman, the lowly employee, or the defenseless tenant. What stares the reader in the face is weakness and gloom as the characters continue to lead miserable lives in a decaying city or war-ravaged barrio. These stories are a dramatic foil to the resplendence and charm of fantastic tales and lugubrious romances. The delineation of the victim of social injustice seems to be the forte of a number of writers that include Caparas, Gomez, and Ramon Marcelino.
Comic Strips

Although the comic strip antedated the komiks by almost two decades, it was only in the 1970s that it flourished. Some of the comic strips that originated before the 1970s were Pol Galvez’s Sanoy; Edgar Soller’s Sablo, Islaw Palitaw, Congressman Kalog, and Mang Ambo; and Nonoy Marcelo’s Tisoy. The increase in the number of tabloids in the 1970s made room for comic strips. Meanwhile, newspapers like the Philippines Daily Express, Times Journal, and Bulletin Today devoted a page each to the comic strips (Lent 1998, 245-46).

Some of the popular and long-running titles that either emerged or were revived and flourished during this time were Alcala’s Siopawman, Roni Santiago’s Baltic and Co., Tito Milambilang’s Kustyo at Buyok (Kustyo and Buyok), and Marcelo’s Ikabod. The last was also a social commentary. It depicts the goings-on in the imaginary land of mice called Dagalandia—literally, “Land of Mice”—which parallel those in actual society, including the repressive deeds of “big fat cats” (Lent 1998, 246).

A distinction may be made between the comic strips in the national broadsheets and those in the tabloids. Those in the broadsheets were either local versions of popular American cartoon strips like Garfield, Peanuts, and Calvin and Hobbes or were socially satirical strips that took on the important issues of the day; whereas those in tablwoids often contained sexual elements.

An example of the first type, started during the post-martial law years, is A. Lipin, 1985, by Jess Abrera, the title a pun on alipin, meaning “slave.” This strip does not contain an ongoing story. Rather, its characters, often represented by the carabao mascot of the newspaper where it is published, crack jokes about current events and public figures. Pugad Baboy by Pol Medina Jr, which appeared in the Philippine Daily Inquirer from 1988 to 2013, when it migrated to the online website Rappler after an editorial dispute, is also a satirical comic strip that skewers the absurdities not only of the political class, but of Philippine society too. The characters come from the middle class and they have conversations about the state of affairs. From time to time, the comic strip employs story arcs, especially when it is dealing with a controversial issue.

On the other hand, tabloids such as Tiktik, Abante, Toro, and Bulgar contain long-running strips focusing on half-naked women and muscled men, over-the-top action sequences, and extended love scenes. Some strips only have one or two panels instead of the usual three to four used in the broadsheets. To a certain degree, these strips mirrored the eruption of titillating films, mostly produced by Seiko Films, in the 1990s, not to mention the prevalence of sex-advice columns and supposedly true sexual confessions that populated the pages of these tabloids.

There were about 20 comic strips in broadsheets in the 1990s, including holdovers from the 1970s. As the new millennium began, more comic strips were created, but very few of these would actually last long.

The popularity of certain comic strips has encouraged their creators to compile them as book collections. Pugad Baboy, for instance, has already released 26 collections, while Manix Abrera’s Kiko Machine, which deals with the issues that university students face, has its own shelf in bookstores. A compilation of A. Lipin has also been published.

The readership of these later comic strips was different from that of the komiks or the earlier strips published in Liwayway. Those had been intended for the masses, but these, published in English-language broadsheets, were for a middle-class readership. Many of the characters, like those depicted in Pugad Baboy, were also from the urban middle class. The shift will also be reflected in the comic book scene.
From Komiks to Comics and the Graphic Novel

The 1990s finally sounded the death knell for the komiks industry. Gone are the days when they were sold at street corners or rented at market stalls and barbershops. From komiks, working class Filipinos turned to romance pocketbooks and other forms of entertainment. The masses still enjoyed the comic strips found in the tabloids, and television shows and film still regularly adapt material originally for komiks, such as Darna and Captain Barbell, but the mainstream comics started catering to the middle and upper classes.

Concurrently, a new generation of comics creators entered the picture, many of whom grew up reading American superhero comic books and graphic novels and, later, Japanese manga. These artists, often of middle-class background, would make around a hundred copies of their comics by photocopy and sell them in universities or at comic book conventions. In this manner, many of them developed a loyal fan base who would follow them when commercial publishers took up their work. It was the success of a Filipino superhero artist in the United States that would galvanize these sporadic efforts and usher in a new chapter in komiks history.

Whilce Portacio found international fame as the artist on Marvel Comics’ most popular title, The Uncanny X-Men. He then became part of a group of celebrity artists including Rob Liefeld, Jim Lee, and Todd MacFarlane that left Marvel to form an independent comics publishing company, Image Comics. Portacio inspired a number of Filipino creators, some dissatisfied with the local komiks industry, to produce their own independent work.

In 1994, creators including Carlo Vergara and David Hontiveros released Flashpoint, considered to be the first of the modern independent komiks. Written in English, the superhero book was heavily influenced by American team comics such as The X-Men and Justice League International. Other titles, such as the Image Comics-inspired Exodus, followed soon enough.

It was not only superhero books that were influential to Filipino creators in the 1990s. Neil Gaiman’s The Sandman took horror and fantasy comics to literary heights. Filipino creators David Hontiveros, Dave Uy, and Dino Ignacio produced Memento Mori, a book that featured moody fantasy stories set in New York and France.

With these new independently produced komiks, certain creators went on to suggest a distinction between komiks, the Filipino-language komiks magazine from the 1940s onward, and comics, the more American-influenced English-language titles. In 1994, Whilce Portacio came to the Philippines and met with these “new” creators. Portacio suggested that the creators band together to form a Filipino alternative to imported American comics whose popularity was growing immensely. Creators such as Budjette Tan, Arnold Arre, Gerry Alanguilan, and Oliver Palumbarit formed the group called Alamat, the Tagalog word for legend. Originally, Alamat comics were noncommercial in nature. They could be construed as the equivalent of the indie films. They catered to a select readership and the artists made little to no profit. The comic books that these artists produced cost more to make, used English as the main language, and featured content removed from the concerns of the lower classes. They were outside the economic range of the lower classes that was the primary readership of the komiks. Comics thus slowly pulled away from its original readers with more complex plots and with underlying messages about the state of the country and its people.

Alamat served mostly as a promotional vehicle for comic book creators. Artists and creators would promote each other’s works, and they would hold events to minimize costs and maximize exposure. Alamat also allowed artists to meet writers and forge collaboration. The group, however, eventually lost its founding members with the rise of publishing houses like Visprint, which allowed for a wider distribution of comic books.

article.value: From 2000 onward, the comic books and, later, graphic novels of these writers and artists, which had started out as an independent movement, would become mainstream publications with a wide readership among the middle class.

While there might have been attempts to create graphic novels before, the first commercially successful one was Pirata, 1995, by Pugad Baboy creator Pol Medina Jr. Pirata heavily features Polgas—the talking anthropomorphic dog of the Sungcal family—and his friendship with a Muslim pirate named Khaled. Unlike his previous collections which contained his strips from the Philippine Daily Inquirer, this contained a complete story, which also sheds some light on the origins of Polgas.

American comics were not the only influential pop cultural force in the 1990s. Japanese manga and anime spread overseas, including the Philippines. In 2000, the first issue of Culture Crash was released and it signaled a new phase for komiks. Sporting artwork heavily influenced by manga, the full-color anthology also featured articles on film, animation, and music, mostly on Japanese properties. However, the stories such as “Cat’s Trail” by Elmer Damaso and “Pasig” by Melvin Calingo were written in Filipino and proved to be quite popular. Culture Crash was so popular that it was able to hold the first comic convention in the country in 2002, the Culture Crash Comics Convention or C3 Con.

Even after Culture Crash ended in 2004, numerous independently produced manga titles have been released throughout the years; and while the more Western superhero and komiks have attracted mostly male readers, Pinoy manga, such as Love Is in the Bag by Ace Vitangcol and Jed Siroy, has garnered a sizable female readership, echoing the audience diversity of manga in Japan.

Given the unique look of manga, a number of critics stated that the Filipino creators were merely copying a foreign art style instead of developing a more Filipino style. The counter argument was that komiks were heavily influenced by American art styles and that the Japanese tradition was just as valid an influence.

The next important graphic novel was The Mythology Class, 1999, by Arnold Arre. The self-published miniseries came out with four issues and marked an inward turn for comics, as it explored indigenous lore for material. The story revolves around an anthropology student, Nicole, and her companions as they attempt to capture engkanto or magical creatures who are creating trouble in the human world. This graphic novel won from the Manila Critics Circle a National Book Award in 2000, and a collected edition was released by Adarna House, a major publisher of children’s books, in 2005.

Perhaps, as a reaction to the dysfunctionality of the governments that came after martial law, many of the new wave of comics fall into two categories: the satires and parodies, and the superhero stories set in dystopian Philippines.
The satires and parodies depict a society overrun by malaise and corruption where citizens recourse to laughter.

In the superhero comic books, ordinary individuals are called on to fight threats, which may come in the form of monsters and supervillains, who are often greedy and corrupt, perhaps a broadside against corrupt politicians. The protagonists follow in the tradition of the reluctant heroes whose goodness is their main strength. Their powers are gifts from forgotten gods or alien life forms. They are often haunted by at least one tragedy, which serves as both fuel and fire for their heroic missions.

Although patterned after Western models, the superheroes are given local characteristics. For instance, in the Filipino Heroes League by Paolo Fabregas, the heroes ride a pedicab during missions; at the same time they try their very best to copy the costumes popularized by Western heroes (spandex, gloves, masks).

There is a heavy emphasis on fantastical elements in the new comic books. Divinities and creatures from Philippine folklore and mythology, like Alunsina and Mariang Makiling, are often in these new comic books as observers or active participants. In some comic books, the supernatural is used to comment on the real world. Trese, written by Budjette Tan and illustrated by Kajo Baldisimo, presents a dystopic world where mysterious blackouts, the demolition and burning of shantytowns so that malls can be built, and corruption in government institutions are the order of the day. The supernatural creatures that inhabit it are often representations of the different types of people in our society: the manananggal (self-segmenting ghoul) are scavengers, often fighting over unclaimed bodies in morgues or are engaged in gang wars; the tikbalang (half-human and half-horse creature) and higante (giant) are the owners of multinational corporations who engage in friendly games of football and car racing. They have human forms, but they transform into their old selves when provoked or when necessary.

Strong word of mouth, especially online, catapulted Trese into mainstream success. The trend of using Philippine mythology for material continued with Skyworld by Mervin Ignacio and Ian Sta. Ana, another independent release, which was picked up by National Book Store and released as a compilation in 2007. The success of Trese and Skyworld, in addition to that of The Mythology Class, demonstrates the appeal of the country’s own myths and legends. In their collected editions, these titles showed the viability of graphic novels as outlets of creative expression and commercial products. As separate issues, the titles also demonstrate how grassroots efforts can produce exciting komiks.

A graphic novel that truly deserves the label of groundbreaking because of its mass appeal, in part because it is written in Filipino, and successful translation into other media is Carlo Vergara’s Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah (The Amazing Adventures of Zsazsa Zaturnnah), 2002, which revisits the Darna plot. An effeminate male homosexual named Ada struggles to fit in in a small town. His life is changed when he finds a rock from outer space which gives him superpowers. He uses his newfound powers to fight off an invasion of Amazon-like women named after the country’s much-beloved superstars. This is the only graphic novel by a Filipino artist that has been transformed into a movie and a musical. In 2003, it was given a National Book Award by the Manila Critics Circle. It is currently used in some universities as source material for gender studies.

It may be argued, then, that the new wave of comics has been a vehicle for the exploration of personal and social issues. Elmer, a graphic novel by Gerry Alanguilan, tackles prejudice. A chicken named Jake Gallo inherits his father Elmer’s diary. It recounts how humans dealt with intelligent chickens. Jake himself has to battle his own prejudices against humans as he was born in a world where humans and chickens lived as equals, whereas his parents had lived in a world where chickens were just meat. Originally written in Tagalog and published between 2006 and 2008 by Komikero Publishing, it was published in English and attained international success. It has been translated to French.

While many of the new comic books are influenced by manga, like Arnold Arre’s After Eden, 2004, the creators of the new comic books continue to explore new ways of storytelling. Manix Abrera’s 12 and 14 are wordless comics. 12 is a collection of a dozen stories. Instead of using words, Abrera used either facial expressions or the distortion of human forms in order to tell his stories. 14 is also in this style, but it employs a narrative structure similar to the one used in Chaucer’s The Canterbury Tales: several stories are held together by a single narrative arc. It remains to be seen, though, if this style will signal a new trend, or is simply the visual and narrative signature of the artist.

With the developments in digital technology in the 21st century, the production of self-made and self-published komiks has become even easier for the aspiring creator. With desktop publishing services available, writers and artists need not worry about spending so much on printing. While mini-comics were produced in the 1990s, new technology has allowed creators to go beyond black-and-white photocopies. Komiks with full-color glossy covers and even color interiors have become possible. However, distribution remains a problem, with few venues for creators to sell their “indie” komiks.

One response is the comic convention. Up until the early 2000s, there was no real industry or mechanism for the community. In 2005, at the University of the Philippines in Diliman, cartoonists Lyndon Gregorio, creator of Beerkada, and Sherry Baet, of Carpool, and others organized the first Philippine Komiks Convention (Komikon), the Filipino version of Comic Con, or comic convention, in the United States. While American and Japanese comics were still sold, Komikon encouraged grassroots creators through its “indie tiangge” (indie flea market) section where aspiring creators could display and sell their self-produced work. Titles such as Ang Maskot by Macoy and Crime-Fighting Call Center Agents by Noel Pascual and A. J. Bernardo found popularity through Komikon.

Komikon proved to be so successful that in 2009, another convention, Komikon Summer Fiesta, was added. Komikon would regularly feature veteran creators, such as Tony DeZuniga, popular comic strip creators like Pol Medina of Pugad Baboy and Manix Abrera of Kikomachine, and superstar Marvel artists such as Leinil Yu. Aside from komiks creators from the past and present, recent Komikon events featured guests such as the cast and crew of the film Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles, creators from Singapore, and even international comics writer Mark Millar. In 2012, a third convention was organized, an all-indie event called Indie Ket, short for Indie Market. This latest development shows how vibrant the current komiks scene has become.
Conclusion

The comics has served many purposes and appealed to different publics. For most people, it is an entertainment fare that provides the reader temporary relief from the unbearable monotony or oppressiveness of life. But it has other uses. In the case of the komiks, one proof of its usefulness is that, so komiks writers have argued, because of the tremendous popularity of these colorful magazines, Filipinos from Aparri to Tawi-Tawi have learned the national language or a version of it. The Tagalog used in the komiks is the simple language of the marketplace, of the streets, of the home, not the formal, elaborate language of Francisco Balagtas Baltazar and Lope K. Santos.

The komiks is a foil to more formal texts in English perceived as the language of the ruling class. Where the upper and middle classes have their higher-priced, imported reading fare or Philippine texts in English, the lower classes have their ubiquitous komiks answering their various needs, whether emotional, psychological, and cultural.

The new wave of comics seems to be an attempt to appropriate a foreign concept and form and give them a local flavor. Despite, in most cases, the use of a foreign language to tell stories, the new comic book remains a medium through which society can be examined and its ills brought into the light, whether through the use of humor, fantasy, or myth.
An art form that has entertained and educated millions since the 1920s promises to attract more readers and creators that will transform it as the times change.
Sources
Written by Soledad Reyes,

text:
Metrical romances—known as awit or korido in Tagalog; as corrido in Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Bikol; kuriru in Kapampangan; biag or panagbiag in Ilocano; impanbilay in Pangasinan; corrido, awit, vida, historia or cabuhi/kinabuhi, or just plain sugilanon in the Ilonggo context—are long verse narratives with chivalric-heroic, legendary, religious, and folkloric themes. Legacies of Spanish colonial culture, they flourished in the Philippines throughout the 19th and well into the 20th century. In subject matter, form, and intention, they come closest to the metrical romances of European literature, which are defined as “stories of adventure in which the chief parts are played by knights, famous kings, or distressed ladies, acting most often under the impulse of love, religious faith or in many, the mere desire for adventure” (Thrall and Hibbard 1962, 278).

Korido is the generic term for the Philippine metrical romance. The term is derived from the Spanish corrido, which is defined as “a metrical story, usually sung to the accompaniment of a guitar, in fandango style” (Fansler 1916, 204). In Trinidad H. Pardo de Tavera’s view, the word was derived from the Spanish word occurrido, which means “events” or “happenings.” Among the Tagalog, the term korido is applied only to metrical romances written in octosyllabic verse called hakira, as distinguished from the term awit, which is used for romances written in dodecasyllabic verse called plosa. Aside from the length of the verses, there is no basic distinction between the two. Both are read for the story they tell, as much as for their imaginative devices and beauty of expression.

Even the distinction in syllabic count holds true only among the Tagalog. The Kapampangan kuriru uses both the dodecasyllabic and octosyllabic verse forms. The Ilocano panagbiag or biag (life), and Pangasinan impanbilay have no fixed syllable count in any one romance. Verses in the same romance may have 6-18 syllables to a line as in the Ilocano Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird) and the Pangasinan Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Sons of Lara). Ilonggo romances employ both hakira and plosa, with the 12-syllable line predominating and some lines having 13 or 14 syllables. The opening page of Enepe’s Historia ni Hipolitin cag sang Bulac sang Pangabuhi nga Tacus Maila-an (Story of Hipolitin and the Flower of Life That is Worthy of Envy), 1922, shows how fluid the terminology is. Although it is written in dodecasyllabic lines, its author refers to it as corrido, awit, historia, and vida (Locsin-Nava 2001, 170-71). Similarly, the Kapampangan writer Modesto Lanuza calls his work Corrido at Buhay na Pinagdaanan ng Mag-asawang Haring Bidoke at Reyna Tenoza sa Cahariang Antiokia at ng Kanilang Anak na Princesa Condensada (Corrido and Life Experienced by the Couple King Bidoke and Queen Tenoza in the Kingdom of Antiokia and Their Daughter Princess Condensada), although it is written in dodecasyllabic lines.

Whatever the length of their verses, all Philippine metrical romances have a uniform stanza pattern—monorhyming or assonant quatrain.

Aside from the difference in syllabic verse count, the two forms are distinguishable from their titles. The title of an awit generally begins with “Buhay na Pinagdaanan ni” (Life Experienced by) or “Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan ni” (History and Life Experienced by). The title of a korido always begins with the word “corrido,” as in Corrido at Pinagdaanang Buhay nang Principe Baldovino (Corrido and Life Experienced by Prince Baldovino). However, as previous examples show, some romances titled “corrido” are not really korido but awit, since they are in dodecasyllabic lines.

The awit is the more dominant form of metrical romance. Of the 229 Tagalog metrical romances recorded, 96 percent are awit and only 4 percent are korido. The best known are Bernardo Carpio, Doce Pares de Francia (Twelve Peers of France), Rodrigo de Villas, Gonzalo de Cordoba, Siete Infantes de Lara, Juan Tiñoso, and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura). Among the korido, the all-time favorites are Ibong Adarna, Florentina, Juan at Maria (Juan and Maria), Baldovino, and Orontis at Talestris (Orontis and Talestris), the last featuring a legendary Amazon queen as its hero.

In length, the romances vary from a few hundred to several thousand lines. The shortest corrido is the Kapampangan Metung a Culubasa at 260 lines, and the longest, with its frequent authorial intrusions and many complications, is the Kapampangan version of Doce Pares de Francia, which come in two versions: Infante Floripe and Doce Pares at 7,264 lines (Gosioco 1974, 49). Marta Jalandoni has an eight-volume Ang Aswang sa Madrid (Aswang in Madrid), 1916, with each volume averaging 32-36 pages, each page consisting of 36 lines (Locsin-Nava 2008, 67).

Romances have been printed since 1815 in small booklets or chapbooks, one romance to a volume, and sold for a few centavos by vendors after holy mass. It is not known exactly when and how metrical romances were introduced into the country. They could have been brought here early in the conquest—as Vicente Barrantes suggests—by the soldiers of Legazpi, in the form of romances and popular tales of Spain. Other kinds of Spanish lore and literature, in written form, followed: ballad collections (such as the Romancero General [General Ballads]), Spanish chronicles and histories, fiction, drama, and poetry. The affinities between the content of these materials and that of Philippine romances are striking, and direct influence, even derivation, can be the only explanation. Like their European counterparts, Philippine metrical romances recount stories from the traditional romances of France (Doce Pares, Conde Irlos [Count Irlos]), Britain (Tablante de Ricamonte), and classical Greece (Troya); from noncyclic romances (Alejandre at Luis [Alejandre and Luis], Erastro, Doncella Teodora, Florentina); from Spanish history and legend (Bernardo Carpio, Siete Infantes de Lara, Rodrigo de Villas, Gonzalo de Cordoba) and books of chivalry (Oliveros at Artos [Oliveros and Artos]; from folktales (Maria Alimango [Maria the Crab], Eliseo at Feliza [Eliseo and Feliza], Ibong Adarna); and from religious sources, such as the Bible (Saul at David [Saul and David]) and lives of the saints (Santa Margarita de Cortona [Saint Margaret of Cortona] and Sta. Maria Magdalena [Saint Mary Magdalene]).

 
 
 

 

The authorship of majority of Philippine metrical romances is unknown, especially of the older and more popular ones, like Gonzalo de Cordoba, Juan Tiñoso, and Siete Infantes de Lara. Occasionally, the authors gave their initials in the closing lines of the poem. Literary historians have identified three important Tagalog poets who wrote metrical romances, and attributed certain works to them. Jose de la Cruz, popularly known as Huseng Sisiw, is believed to have written Bernardo Carpio and Rodrigo de Villas. Francisco Baltazar, or Balagtas, wrote Florante at Laura. Ananias Zorilla wrote Dama Ines (Lady Ines) and Principe Florinio (Prince Florinio). Among the authors who later put their names to their romance works were Nemesio Magboo, Franz Molteni (pseud. of Meliton Fernandez), Cleto Ignacio, Joaquin Mañibo, Joaquin Tuazon, Feliciano and Jacinto Castillo, and Pedro and Simeon Aranas.

Like Jose de la Cruz, the Bikol migrant to Iloilo, Mariano Perfecto, who wrote more in Ilonggo than in Bikol (Realubit 1998, 127), is credited with the translation of the more popular romances like Principe Don Juan Tiñoso, Doce Pares de Francia, and Siete Infantes de Lara, aside from novenas, saints’s lives, and other devotional literature, into these two languages. Hence, together with Casimiro Perfecto and Nicolasa Ponte Perfecto he appears to be the reason why 31 of 53 metrical romances in Hiligaynon have versions in Bikol (Locsin-Nava 2008, 66).

As in the Tagalog context, well-known Ilonggo writers of romances, like the Perfectos mentioned, generally signed their works with their initials, their nicknames or anagrams (“Yorim” for Casimiro Perfecto), or place of origin (“Camarisnon” for “one from Camarines”). The author of Ang Hada Paribanu (The Fairy Paribanu) signed herself/himself as “Isa ca Bagonhon” (one coming from the city of Bago, Negros Occidental); the writer of Ang Nagsibu nga Damguhanon ni Vidavid cag ni Dama de Noche (The Matching Dreams of Vidavid and Dama de Noche) identified himself/herself as “Isa ka Baisnon” (one who comes from Bais, Negros Oriental); Marta Jalandoni up until her last work, Kasingkasing sa Botelya (Heart in a Bottle), in which she reveals her identity, generally signed her works “Isa ca Carloteña,” after the city intersecting the barrio where she comes from.

The author of Ang Lahog nga Pulos Milagro ni Cente cag ni Manong Tonio nga Bata sang Duha ca Babaye nga Pulos Francisca (The Joke Full of Miracles of Cente and Brother Tonio Who Are Children of Two Women Named Francisca), 1928, enigmatically identified herself as “Isa ca Curiosa.” A host of less shy writers, however, like Nemesio Ledesma, B. J. Jimenez, Ruperto Javier, and Bernardo Belonio, acknowledged authorship of their works and signed their names in full. A singular exception, however, was Republic Cultural Heritage Awardee Magdalena Jalandoni. She acknowledged authorship of only three out of the six she wrote because she found them inferior to her poetry (Nite 1977, 140-44).

Jalandoni’s disavowal is a telling reminder that at the turn of the century, serious writers like Hiligaynon critic Augurio Abeto and polymath nationalist poet, novelist, and sarsuwela writer Serapion Torre looked down upon the metrical romance as a debased form.

An interesting feature of Philippine metrical romances is their titles, which essentially identify the person or persons whose life and adventures are to be narrated. Often, the title gives the names of the two central characters and their kingdom of origin, as in Pinagdaanang Buhay nina Florante at Laura sa Kahariang Albania (Life Experienced by Florante and Laura in the Kingdom of Albania) or Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan ni Don Rodrigo de Villas at ni Doña Jimena sa Kaharian ng Espanya (History and Life Experienced by Don Rodrigo de Villas and Doña Jimena in the Kingdom of Spain). Some titles identify not only the central characters but also the names of their parents and their parents’s kingdom, as in Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan nang Tatlong Principeng Magkakapatid na Anak nang Haring Fernando at nang Reina Valeriana sa Kahariang Berbania (History and Life Experienced by Three Princes Brothers Who Are Sons of King Fernando and Queen Valeriana in the Kingdom of Berbania). Probably to catch the interest of prospective readers or buyers of the romances, authors added qualifying, emotion-laden adjectives in the titles, as in Salita at Buhay na Kahabaghabag na Pinagdaanan ng Pitong Infantes de Lara at ng Kaabaabang Kanilang Ama sa Reynong Espanya (History and Pitiful Life Experienced by the Seven Princes of Lara and by Their Miserable Father in the Kingdom of Spain). A noteworthy feature of some romances is the very long title, which practically summarizes the plot of the romance, by giving the names of the major characters, the main action, and the ending of the tale, as in Salita at Buhay nang Doce Pares sa Francia na Kampon ng Emperador Carlo Magno hangga nang Ipagkanulo ni Galalon na Nangapatay sa Roncesvalles (History and Life of the Twelve Peers of France, Followers of Emperor Charlemagne, until They Were Betrayed by Galalon and Killed in Roncesvalles). The use of affective language to attract attention gains an added fillip in a Hiligaynon anti-abortion corrido: Corrido nga Makapamudlo sang mga Mata sang Babae nga Mabuot Apang indi Con Panalabiton sang Isa ca Bata nga Wala Mabunyagan cay Hungod sang Iloy nga Matunaw cag Mahulog (Corrido Designed to Widen the Eyes of a Woman Who Appears Good but Isn’t or the Lamentations of a Child to Her Shameless Mother).

 

 

Long after the Spaniards had left, metrical romances continued to enjoy immense popularity. Fansler, writing in 1916, noted an ever increasing output of printed editions of the most popular romances, in at least six major Philippine languages. Leading the list were Rodrigo de Villas, Doce Pares, Bernardo Carpio, and Siete Infantes de Lara. A recent compilation of these romances, by no means complete, contains 229 titles in Tagalog, 89 in Bikol, 66 in Hiligaynon, 65 in Kapampangan, 48 in Ilocano, and 5 in Pangasinan. All these have survived to the present.

 
 

Awit and korido employ a stereotyped narrative technique. The standard pattern may be briefly described as consisting of a conventional opening, which is either a religious invocation or apology; a narration of the story in strict chronological order; and a conventional ending consisting usually of a moralizing passage followed by an apology and sometimes also by the initials of the author. Complexity of plot is a quality that authors of metrical romances strive for. When the romances are derived from short pieces like ballads, the tendency is for the poet to take several ballads and combine them into one romance. Thus, in the korido Baldovino, all the ballads about Baldovino and the Marquis of Mantua are brought together in one story. Romances derived from folktales seldom limit themselves to the basic, original story or to one story. The folktale is usually expanded by adding an introductory episode as in Don Juan, Ang Haring Patay (Don Juan the Dead King), or a concluding episode as in Doncella Teodora. Often two or more tales are combined to form one romance, as in Ibong Adarna and Palmarin. There are many repetitions both in situation and narration, which add to the length of the romance. The writers also observe a variety of conventions, or “formulaic writing.” There is an accepted, de rigeur chronology of situation, action, and resolution, which would roughly take the following pattern: description of the male hero and the heroine, the sending of emissaries and their presentation of demands from either contending party or kingdom, the response of the characters addressed, the description of the ensuing battles, the terms of surrender, the conversion of the vanquished enemy, the wedding of the male hero and heroine with the accompanying seven-day or nine-day feast, and the coronation of the hero with which most of the romances inevitably end.

In Philippine metrical romances, three elements stand out: the romantic or love relationships, the religious-moralistic, and the magical or marvelous. Love is the motivating force in most of the tales. It is introduced into a story when the original does not have this element. In Siete Infantes de Lara, the love between Busto de Lara and the Moorish princess Hismena is made almost as important as the adventures of the hero Morada Gonzalo. Religious didacticism is an equally prominent element in both awit and korido. This is seen not only in the religious invocation but in the story itself. All the heroes are portrayed as being very religious. Most of them happen to be devotees of the Blessed Virgin Mary. The holiness of the Catholic sacraments is constantly emphasized, such being made key events in the story. Baptism, matrimony, penance, and the Holy Eucharist predominate. Above all, the religious element is evident in the numerous miracles that occur in the romances. Voices from heaven and the miraculous power of prayer come a very close second to love at first sight as the motif with the greatest frequency in the romances. Religion and romance are, however, inextricably bound together. Conversion to Christianity—indeed the triumph of the Christian faith over that of the heathen—invariably occurs in the stories.

 
 

 

Side by side with the devout and devotional element in the romance is the didactic. The moralizing conclusions of the romances give one a good idea of the moral precepts which the authors, products of their own religious culture, try to inculcate through their romances: filial piety, purity in maidens, constancy of lovers, and devoted service to God. The magical and the marvelous are closely intertwined with the religious element, with authors trying hard to reconcile the two. God and His saints are sometimes made to play the role ordinarily played by friendly witches and magicians, like furnishing the hero with magic objects, as in Jaime del Prado or with extraordinary companions, as in Palmarin. Occurrences obviously magical are attributed to the power of religion. In Eliseo at Feliza (Eliseo and Feliza), for instance, the friendly monkey assures the hero that the wealth it acquired for him by deceiving the witch and by using the power of the witch’s magic ring, came from God.

While it is true that most of the metrical romances were derived from European sources, many were indigenized—that is, took on a local flavor, by gradually losing their foreign aspect and being situated in a native setting. In Palmarin, a story supposedly set in Marseilles, France, the strong man Carguin Cargon is depicted as moving a mountain from Candaba to Arayat when the hero meets him for the first time. Similarly, Bernardo Carpio, a hero in Spanish folklore, was adopted as a folk hero of the Tagalog, and the mountains between which he was supposed to have been trapped and imprisoned have always been associated with the mountains of San Mateo, Rizal. Heroines are often portrayed as though they were Philippine country maidens.

Likewise in Vida ni Principe Alfredo cag ni Blanca Nieves sa Ginharian sang Babiera (Life of Prince Alfredo and Snow White in the Kingdom of Babiera), 1912, the wicked stepmother offers to delouse the heroine like a Filipino barrio girl using a fine-tooth comb called sulod in Ilonggo. Later when she disguises herself as a fruit vendor she brings apples, oranges, pears, grapes as well as Philippine fruits like lanzones, chicos, mangoes, and pomelos to entice the girl (Locsin-Nava 2008, 18).

Many of these stories were altered to make them conform to Philippine customs and moral standards. Courtship scenes are typically Filipino, with the male suitor making long sentimental declarations of love, which almost always end with a threat to stab himself if his love be rejected. Lovers’s trysts are altered in description to conform to local romantic norms of conduct. The value attached to virginal chastity and the strong disapproval of intimate relations between the sexes before marriage are upheld. Filipino lowland culture is basically monogamous, and the romances were altered to suit this culture. Doña Sancha, therefore, in Siete Infantes, had to die after giving birth to the seven princes in order that Busto de Lara may be free to marry the Moorish princess Hismena and make the hero legitimate. Illegitimacy is considered a stain on one’s character, so that all bastard heroes (Morada Gonzalo, Bernardo Carpio, and Rodrigo de Villas) had to be made legitimate. The religious nature of Filipinos infused the romances with a humane quality which was often lacking in their sources. In Baldovino, the cruelty of the punishment meted out to Carloto is greatly toned down. He is not sentenced to be dragged by wild horses, beheaded, and quartered, as in the Spanish ballad, but merely hanged and exposed to public view, after which monks come and bury him in the churchyard.

The Filipino fondness for allegorical and figurative language manifests itself in the romances. Morada Gonzalo in Siete Infantes presents his grievances before King Almanzor by speaking of a plant, the seven flowers of which have fallen prematurely because of treachery. But the traitor, he declares, has failed to uproot the plant and now its roots, having sprouted, will avenge the death of the seven flowers. In the romances, feasts are celebrated in characteristic Philippine fashion, with arches across every street, houses hung with damask, bands parading through the town, cannons booming, exhibition jousts or tournaments and games of all kinds ongoing, and the staging of the indispensable komedya, the theatrical spectacle depicting the wars between Christians and Moors, in which the Moors are inevitably defeated and converted to Catholicism. This last one presents a rather complex picture of the genre: a metrical romance (awit or korido) containing another genre (komedya) which in substance, in color, and in purpose resembles the art form in which it is contained, and which it possibly even influenced in the first place.

By the late 19th century, the metrical romance had become so much a part of the Philippine literary tradition that it produced a masterpiece that could be read as an expression of protest against the repressive character of Spanish rule, Francisco Baltazar’s Florante at Laura, written ca. 1838. Certainly passages abound in the poem that could be read as allegorical descriptions of Philippine social conditions of the time. Furthermore, Balagtas defied the Moro-versus-Christian stereotype that was a fixed convention of the genre by making his Moro characters, Aladin and Flerida, good people who come to the rescue of Florante and Laura. This awit had an impact on Jose Rizal and his generation, who read it as a nationalist tract. Belonging to this tradition of the metrical romance as political allegory is Sa Dakong Silangan (In the East), 1928, by Jose Corazon de Jesus. It continues the anticlerical theme begun by the Reformists of the Spanish colonial period, but focuses its attack on American colonialism. The characters’s allegorical names—Haring Felipo, Reyna Malaya, Haring lberio, Prinsipe Dolar, and Duke Democrito—signify the country’s transfer from the Spanish to the American colonial master. Through the character of the treacherous Prinsipe Dolar and the foreshadowing device of the eagle, this awit exposes the US government’s twin instruments of colonial rule: repression and capital.

 

The metrical romances reigned supreme for three centuries lasting up to the early part of the 20th century with some 300 of them circulated nationally. They lasted longer than that in the Ilonggo context: corridos were published by La Panayana as late as the 1960s (Locsin-Nava 2001, 42). The case seems to be true of the Ilocano metrical romance, too, as the existence of these works attests: Comedia a Biag ni Principe Atamante iti Reyno Verona (The Comedia of the Life of Prince Atamante in the Kingdom of Verona), 1958; Biag Daguiti Aggayyem D. Alejandre iti Reyno a Moscobia Quen ni D. Luis iti Reyno a Francia (Life of Two Friends Don Alejandre of the Kingdom of Moscow and Don Luis of the Kingdom of France), 1964; and Historia a Pacasaritaan ti Panagbiag ni Principe Jayme del Prado nga Anac da Ari D. Enrico (The Story of the Life of Prince Jayme del Prado, Son of King Enrico and Lady Isabela of the Kingdom of Hungary), 1964.

 

Alternative Metrical Romances

Like the Tagalog, the Ilonggo also used the metrical romances as an instrument against repressive colonial rule. However, where the Tagalog turned to political allegory, the Ilonggo turned to satire and parody, diverging from the traditional by violating expectations set by dominant conventions and ideologies. Thus, these works explode the standard concept of romance hero or heroine, tackle taboo subjects like defecation and abortion, invert power relationships, and expose oppressive binary oppositions like foreign/native, civilized/primitive, oppressor/oppressed, in which the powerless can triumph over the powerful.

Where typical romances feature attractive, fair, highborn and refined Caucasian protagonists from exotic kingdoms in Europe, Masadianga Vida ni Capiñahan cag ni Bulan-bulan sa Barrio nga Malapit sa Madyaas (The Happy Life of Capiñahan and Bulan-bulan in a Barrio near Madyaas), 1930, transgresses the social snobbery of the form by featuring Bulan-bulan as hero, a short, dark, ugly dimwitted young farmer from Sibalom, Antique, while the heroine is a lusty, sexually liberated Aeta from a barrio in Madyaas, who engineers her own wooing by slyly providing her suitor the answers to three riddling questions her father poses to enable him to win her hand.

Casimiro Perfecto’s Ang Lahog nga Pulos Milagro ni Cente cag ni Manong Tonio nga Bata sang Duha ca Babaye nga Pulos Francisca (The Joke Full of Miracles of Cente and Brother Tonio who are Children of Two Women Named Francisca) turns the saint’s life or vida into a picaresque tale. The prepubescent saints Vincent and Anthony are depicted as precocious rapscallions who play tricks on the mentors they dislike.

The anonymous Paghigugma-anay sang Pispis nga Bucao cag Maya, Pagcapatay si Punay Naman ang Nahagugma (The Love Affair of the Owl and the Maya; After Her Death Punay Supplanted Her as Love Object) parodies not only the romantic concept of everlasting love and its emotional extravagance but also romance literature’s pretentious erudition and linguistic bombast. An anthropomorphic, pompous, and sententious owl woos a maya in Hiligaynon heavily interlarded often with wrong Spanish terms, a practice among corrido writers that linguistic purist Serapion Torre satirized in his play Mga Anak ni Sisa (The Children of Sisa), 1926. A member of the reformist Academia Bisaya, an organization established by writers and journalists in 1901 to counteract the widespread adulteration of Hiligaynon with Spanish and English loan words, Torre coined terms like hatud-dulus for telegram, hunghungan for telephone, sakayan usbong for steamship, luthang paarak for machine gun in his search for the authentic Hiligaynon word (Locsin-Nava 2008, 61-62; Locsin-Nava 2001, 48-49) rather than use a foreign loan word.

Showing mastery of both form and content, Casimiro Perfecto in Masadia nga Vida ni Princesa Azucena nga anac ni Don Diego del Dia cag Dama de Noche sa Guinharian sang Florefortuna (Happy Life of Princess Azucena, Daughter of Don Diego del Dia and Dama de Noche, in the Kingdom of Florefortuna), 1926, mocks the authorial practice of killing off unimportant characters in a tale that puts a new spin to the romantic concept of dying for love. The poet abbreviates the death of 24 bridegrooms in four lines. Gimaya cag Calisud ni Liberato nga Villano nga Nagpangasawa cay Librada cag cay Princesa Estelita sang Reino sang Francia (Joy and Sorrow of the Villager Liberato who Married Librada and Princess Estelita of the Kingdom of France), 1930, draws the reader in as it mocks its own prolixity.

Such romances subvert form and content in the process of “writing back” to colonizers by standing conventions on their head. Ang Guintago nga Magayon nga Dalagang si Mileguas nga Napanga-sawa ni Principe Melindres sang Roncesvalles (The Kept Maiden Mileguas Whom Prince Melindres of Roncesvalles Married), 1915, turns the tables on our colonizers by satirizing the uselessness of the heroine’s Western education which fails to prevent her from getting pregnant on her first encounter with a man. Ang Nagsagad Caon Santo Inga Gintubol (The One Who Overate Santol and Got Constipated), 1918, satirizes the pernicious effects of American pragmatism with marriage contracts being informed by crass materialism and calculation.

Although studies on the metrical romance across regions (Burgos 1924; Carpio 1959; Ronquillo 1953; Gosioco 1974; Eugenio 1987) have focused exclusively on the traditional type, Lanuza’s case and the many translations into Bikol by the Perfectos show subversive corridos are not exclusive to Hiligaynon literature.

Unlike in other ethnolinguistic groups, corridos did not die out in the Ilonggo context. Rather, they got transformed into the composo. The composo (from the Spanish word composicion) is a ballad in dodecasyllabic lines sung to a preset melody (Tan 1981, 52). Tan’s contention that the Ilonggo’s desire for something shorter, more realistic, and easier to memorize may have motivated them to modify the Hiligaynon corrido into the composo bears some thought in view of two hybrid corridos that capture this transition: one described by its author Nemesio Ledesma as novela nga binalaybay (novel in verse) titled Si Valing cag si Minong, based on a real-life domestic tragedy that gave rise to a composo by the same title; and Ang Cabuhini Pedro Tabios cag ni Manuela Lilay sa Imperiong Roma (The Life of Pedro Tabios and Manuela Lilay in Imperial Rome), 1912, where instead of the standard address to the reader or opening prayer, the corrido plunges straight into Pedro Tabios’s story by identifying the character and the setting very much in the manner of the composo.

Dismissed by critics like Pardo de Tavera and Leopoldo Yabes as “lengthy, exaggerated, puerile, absurd in the extreme” and “outlandish,” the metrical romances have been rescued from ignominy by scholars like Resil Mojares, who describes them as the vehicle by which the aesthetic tendency in the novel came into greater play. Probably the most influential of all foreign literary genres introduced by our colonizers whose impact transcends their literary importance, the metrical romances have shaped not only our tastes but also Philippine attitudes and worldview. Proof of their durability is the tenacity with which komedya, its dramatic counterpart, has survived not only in depressed backwoods like Barangay San Antonio, Barbaza, Antique, but in the eternal love triangle, black-and-white characters, and overelaborate plotlines (Reyes 1994, 26-31) that characterized vernacular novels serialized in weekly publications like Hiligaynon and Bisaya and continue to inform Philippine formula films and soap operas today.  Written by Damiana Eugenio, updated by Ma. Cecilia Locsin-Nava
