article.value: Korido is the generic term for the Philippine metrical romance. The term is derived from the Spanish corrido, which is defined as “a metrical story, usually sung to the accompaniment of a guitar, in fandango style” (Fansler 1916, 204). In Trinidad H. Pardo de Tavera’s view, the word was derived from the Spanish word occurrido, which means “events” or “happenings.” Among the Tagalog, the term korido is applied only to metrical romances written in octosyllabic verse called hakira, as distinguished from the term awit, which is used for romances written in dodecasyllabic verse called plosa. Aside from the length of the verses, there is no basic distinction between the two. Both are read for the story they tell, as much as for their imaginative devices and beauty of expression.

Even the distinction in syllabic count holds true only among the Tagalog. The Kapampangan kuriru uses both the dodecasyllabic and octosyllabic verse forms. The Ilocano panagbiag or biag (life), and Pangasinan impanbilay have no fixed syllable count in any one romance. Verses in the same romance may have 6-18 syllables to a line as in the Ilocano Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird) and the Pangasinan Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Sons of Lara). Ilonggo romances employ both hakira and plosa, with the 12-syllable line predominating and some lines having 13 or 14 syllables. The opening page of Enepe’s Historia ni Hipolitin cag sang Bulac sang Pangabuhi nga Tacus Maila-an (Story of Hipolitin and the Flower of Life That is Worthy of Envy), 1922, shows how fluid the terminology is. Although it is written in dodecasyllabic lines, its author refers to it as corrido, awit, historia, and vida (Locsin-Nava 2001, 170-71). Similarly, the Kapampangan writer Modesto Lanuza calls his work Corrido at Buhay na Pinagdaanan ng Mag-asawang Haring Bidoke at Reyna Tenoza sa Cahariang Antiokia at ng Kanilang Anak na Princesa Condensada (Corrido and Life Experienced by the Couple King Bidoke and Queen Tenoza in the Kingdom of Antiokia and Their Daughter Princess Condensada), although it is written in dodecasyllabic lines.
Whatever the length of their verses, all Philippine metrical romances have a uniform stanza pattern—monorhyming or assonant quatrain.

Aside from the difference in syllabic verse count, the two forms are distinguishable from their titles. The title of an awit generally begins with “Buhay na Pinagdaanan ni” (Life Experienced by) or “Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan ni” (History and Life Experienced by). The title of a korido always begins with the word “corrido,” as in Corrido at Pinagdaanang Buhay nang Principe Baldovino (Corrido and Life Experienced by Prince Baldovino). However, as previous examples show, some romances titled “corrido” are not really korido but awit, since they are in dodecasyllabic lines.

The awit is the more dominant form of metrical romance. Of the 229 Tagalog metrical romances recorded, 96 percent are awit and only 4 percent are korido. The best known are Bernardo Carpio, Doce Pares de Francia (Twelve Peers of France), Rodrigo de Villas, Gonzalo de Cordoba, Siete Infantes de Lara, Juan Tiñoso, and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura). Among the korido, the all-time favorites are Ibong Adarna, Florentina, Juan at Maria (Juan and Maria), Baldovino, and Orontis at Talestris (Orontis and Talestris), the last featuring a legendary Amazon queen as its hero.

In length, the romances vary from a few hundred to several thousand lines. The shortest corrido is the Kapampangan Metung a Culubasa at 260 lines, and the longest, with its frequent authorial intrusions and many complications, is the Kapampangan version of Doce Pares de Francia, which come in two versions: Infante Floripe and Doce Pares at 7,264 lines (Gosioco 1974, 49). Marta Jalandoni has an eight-volume Ang Aswang sa Madrid (Aswang in Madrid), 1916, with each volume averaging 32-36 pages, each page consisting of 36 lines (Locsin-Nava 2008, 67).

Romances have been printed since 1815 in small booklets or chapbooks, one romance to a volume, and sold for a few centavos by vendors after holy mass. It is not known exactly when and how metrical romances were introduced into the country. They could have been brought here early in the conquest—as Vicente Barrantes suggests—by the soldiers of Legazpi, in the form of romances and popular tales of Spain. Other kinds of Spanish lore and literature, in written form, followed: ballad collections (such as the Romancero General [General Ballads]), Spanish chronicles and histories, fiction, drama, and poetry. The affinities between the content of these materials and that of Philippine romances are striking, and direct influence, even derivation, can be the only explanation. Like their European counterparts, Philippine metrical romances recount stories from the traditional romances of France (Doce Pares, Conde Irlos [Count Irlos]), Britain (Tablante de Ricamonte), and classical Greece (Troya); from noncyclic romances (Alejandre at Luis [Alejandre and Luis], Erastro, Doncella Teodora, Florentina); from Spanish history and legend (Bernardo Carpio, Siete Infantes de Lara, Rodrigo de Villas, Gonzalo de Cordoba) and books of chivalry (Oliveros at Artos [Oliveros and Artos]; from folktales (Maria Alimango [Maria the Crab], Eliseo at Feliza [Eliseo and Feliza], Ibong Adarna); and from religious sources, such as the Bible (Saul at David [Saul and David]) and lives of the saints (Santa Margarita de Cortona [Saint Margaret of Cortona] and Sta. Maria Magdalena [Saint Mary Magdalene]).

article.value: The authorship of majority of Philippine metrical romances is unknown, especially of the older and more popular ones, like Gonzalo de Cordoba, Juan Tiñoso, and Siete Infantes de Lara. Occasionally, the authors gave their initials in the closing lines of the poem. Literary historians have identified three important Tagalog poets who wrote metrical romances, and attributed certain works to them. Jose de la Cruz, popularly known as Huseng Sisiw, is believed to have written Bernardo Carpio and Rodrigo de Villas. Francisco Baltazar, or Balagtas, wrote Florante at Laura. Ananias Zorilla wrote Dama Ines (Lady Ines) and Principe Florinio (Prince Florinio). Among the authors who later put their names to their romance works were Nemesio Magboo, Franz Molteni (pseud. of Meliton Fernandez), Cleto Ignacio, Joaquin Mañibo, Joaquin Tuazon, Feliciano and Jacinto Castillo, and Pedro and Simeon Aranas.

Like Jose de la Cruz, the Bikol migrant to Iloilo, Mariano Perfecto, who wrote more in Ilonggo than in Bikol (Realubit 1998, 127), is credited with the translation of the more popular romances like Principe Don Juan Tiñoso, Doce Pares de Francia, and Siete Infantes de Lara, aside from novenas, saints’s lives, and other devotional literature, into these two languages. Hence, together with Casimiro Perfecto and Nicolasa Ponte Perfecto he appears to be the reason why 31 of 53 metrical romances in Hiligaynon have versions in Bikol (Locsin-Nava 2008, 66).

As in the Tagalog context, well-known Ilonggo writers of romances, like the Perfectos mentioned, generally signed their works with their initials, their nicknames or anagrams (“Yorim” for Casimiro Perfecto), or place of origin (“Camarisnon” for “one from Camarines”). The author of Ang Hada Paribanu (The Fairy Paribanu) signed herself/himself as “Isa ca Bagonhon” (one coming from the city of Bago, Negros Occidental); the writer of Ang Nagsibu nga Damguhanon ni Vidavid cag ni Dama de Noche (The Matching Dreams of Vidavid and Dama de Noche) identified himself/herself as “Isa ka Baisnon” (one who comes from Bais, Negros Oriental); Marta Jalandoni up until her last work, Kasingkasing sa Botelya (Heart in a Bottle), in which she reveals her identity, generally signed her works “Isa ca Carloteña,” after the city intersecting the barrio where she comes from.

The author of Ang Lahog nga Pulos Milagro ni Cente cag ni Manong Tonio nga Bata sang Duha ca Babaye nga Pulos Francisca (The Joke Full of Miracles of Cente and Brother Tonio Who Are Children of Two Women Named Francisca), 1928, enigmatically identified herself as “Isa ca Curiosa.” A host of less shy writers, however, like Nemesio Ledesma, B. J. Jimenez, Ruperto Javier, and Bernardo Belonio, acknowledged authorship of their works and signed their names in full. A singular exception, however, was Republic Cultural Heritage Awardee Magdalena Jalandoni. She acknowledged authorship of only three out of the six she wrote because she found them inferior to her poetry (Nite 1977, 140-44).

Jalandoni’s disavowal is a telling reminder that at the turn of the century, serious writers like Hiligaynon critic Augurio Abeto and polymath nationalist poet, novelist, and sarsuwela writer Serapion Torre looked down upon the metrical romance as a debased form.

An interesting feature of Philippine metrical romances is their titles, which essentially identify the person or persons whose life and adventures are to be narrated. Often, the title gives the names of the two central characters and their kingdom of origin, as in Pinagdaanang Buhay nina Florante at Laura sa Kahariang Albania (Life Experienced by Florante and Laura in the Kingdom of Albania) or Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan ni Don Rodrigo de Villas at ni Doña Jimena sa Kaharian ng Espanya (History and Life Experienced by Don Rodrigo de Villas and Doña Jimena in the Kingdom of Spain). Some titles identify not only the central characters but also the names of their parents and their parents’s kingdom, as in Salita at Buhay na Pinagdaanan nang Tatlong Principeng Magkakapatid na Anak nang Haring Fernando at nang Reina Valeriana sa Kahariang Berbania (History and Life Experienced by Three Princes Brothers Who Are Sons of King Fernando and Queen Valeriana in the Kingdom of Berbania). Probably to catch the interest of prospective readers or buyers of the romances, authors added qualifying, emotion-laden adjectives in the titles, as in Salita at Buhay na Kahabaghabag na Pinagdaanan ng Pitong Infantes de Lara at ng Kaabaabang Kanilang Ama sa Reynong Espanya (History and Pitiful Life Experienced by the Seven Princes of Lara and by Their Miserable Father in the Kingdom of Spain). A noteworthy feature of some romances is the very long title, which practically summarizes the plot of the romance, by giving the names of the major characters, the main action, and the ending of the tale, as in Salita at Buhay nang Doce Pares sa Francia na Kampon ng Emperador Carlo Magno hangga nang Ipagkanulo ni Galalon na Nangapatay sa Roncesvalles (History and Life of the Twelve Peers of France, Followers of Emperor Charlemagne, until They Were Betrayed by Galalon and Killed in Roncesvalles). The use of affective language to attract attention gains an added fillip in a Hiligaynon anti-abortion corrido: Corrido nga Makapamudlo sang mga Mata sang Babae nga Mabuot Apang indi Con Panalabiton sang Isa ca Bata nga Wala Mabunyagan cay Hungod sang Iloy nga Matunaw cag Mahulog (Corrido Designed to Widen the Eyes of a Woman Who Appears Good but Isn’t or the Lamentations of a Child to Her Shameless Mother).

Long after the Spaniards had left, metrical romances continued to enjoy immense popularity. Fansler, writing in 1916, noted an ever increasing output of printed editions of the most popular romances, in at least six major Philippine languages. Leading the list were Rodrigo de Villas, Doce Pares, Bernardo Carpio, and Siete Infantes de Lara. A recent compilation of these romances, by no means complete, contains 229 titles in Tagalog, 89 in Bikol, 66 in Hiligaynon, 65 in Kapampangan, 48 in Ilocano, and 5 in Pangasinan. All these have survived to the present.

Awit and korido employ a stereotyped narrative technique. The standard pattern may be briefly described as consisting of a conventional opening, which is either a religious invocation or apology; a narration of the story in strict chronological order; and a conventional ending consisting usually of a moralizing passage followed by an apology and sometimes also by the initials of the author. Complexity of plot is a quality that authors of metrical romances strive for. When the romances are derived from short pieces like ballads, the tendency is for the poet to take several ballads and combine them into one romance. Thus, in the korido Baldovino, all the ballads about Baldovino and the Marquis of Mantua are brought together in one story. Romances derived from folktales seldom limit themselves to the basic, original story or to one story. The folktale is usually expanded by adding an introductory episode as in Don Juan, Ang Haring Patay (Don Juan the Dead King), or a concluding episode as in Doncella Teodora. Often two or more tales are combined to form one romance, as in Ibong Adarna and Palmarin. There are many repetitions both in situation and narration, which add to the length of the romance. The writers also observe a variety of conventions, or “formulaic writing.” There is an accepted, de rigeur chronology of situation, action, and resolution, which would roughly take the following pattern: description of the male hero and the heroine, the sending of emissaries and their presentation of demands from either contending party or kingdom, the response of the characters addressed, the description of the ensuing battles, the terms of surrender, the conversion of the vanquished enemy, the wedding of the male hero and heroine with the accompanying seven-day or nine-day feast, and the coronation of the hero with which most of the romances inevitably end.

In Philippine metrical romances, three elements stand out: the romantic or love relationships, the religious-moralistic, and the magical or marvelous. Love is the motivating force in most of the tales. It is introduced into a story when the original does not have this element. In Siete Infantes de Lara, the love between Busto de Lara and the Moorish princess Hismena is made almost as important as the adventures of the hero Morada Gonzalo. Religious didacticism is an equally prominent element in both awit and korido. This is seen not only in the religious invocation but in the story itself. All the heroes are portrayed as being very religious. Most of them happen to be devotees of the Blessed Virgin Mary. The holiness of the Catholic sacraments is constantly emphasized, such being made key events in the story. Baptism, matrimony, penance, and the Holy Eucharist predominate. Above all, the religious element is evident in the numerous miracles that occur in the romances. Voices from heaven and the miraculous power of prayer come a very close second to love at first sight as the motif with the greatest frequency in the romances. Religion and romance are, however, inextricably bound together. Conversion to Christianity—indeed the triumph of the Christian faith over that of the heathen—invariably occurs in the stories.

Side by side with the devout and devotional element in the romance is the didactic. The moralizing conclusions of the romances give one a good idea of the moral precepts which the authors, products of their own religious culture, try to inculcate through their romances: filial piety, purity in maidens, constancy of lovers, and devoted service to God. The magical and the marvelous are closely intertwined with the religious element, with authors trying hard to reconcile the two. God and His saints are sometimes made to play the role ordinarily played by friendly witches and magicians, like furnishing the hero with magic objects, as in Jaime del Prado or with extraordinary companions, as in Palmarin. Occurrences obviously magical are attributed to the power of religion. In Eliseo at Feliza (Eliseo and Feliza), for instance, the friendly monkey assures the hero that the wealth it acquired for him by deceiving the witch and by using the power of the witch’s magic ring, came from God.

While it is true that most of the metrical romances were derived from European sources, many were indigenized—that is, took on a local flavor, by gradually losing their foreign aspect and being situated in a native setting. In Palmarin, a story supposedly set in Marseilles, France, the strong man Carguin Cargon is depicted as moving a mountain from Candaba to Arayat when the hero meets him for the first time. Similarly, Bernardo Carpio, a hero in Spanish folklore, was adopted as a folk hero of the Tagalog, and the mountains between which he was supposed to have been trapped and imprisoned have always been associated with the mountains of San Mateo, Rizal. Heroines are often portrayed as though they were Philippine country maidens.

Likewise in Vida ni Principe Alfredo cag ni Blanca Nieves sa Ginharian sang Babiera (Life of Prince Alfredo and Snow White in the Kingdom of Babiera), 1912, the wicked stepmother offers to delouse the heroine like a Filipino barrio girl using a fine-tooth comb called sulod in Ilonggo. Later when she disguises herself as a fruit vendor she brings apples, oranges, pears, grapes as well as Philippine fruits like lanzones, chicos, mangoes, and pomelos to entice the girl (Locsin-Nava 2008, 18).

Many of these stories were altered to make them conform to Philippine customs and moral standards. Courtship scenes are typically Filipino, with the male suitor making long sentimental declarations of love, which almost always end with a threat to stab himself if his love be rejected. Lovers’s trysts are altered in description to conform to local romantic norms of conduct. The value attached to virginal chastity and the strong disapproval of intimate relations between the sexes before marriage are upheld. Filipino lowland culture is basically monogamous, and the romances were altered to suit this culture. Doña Sancha, therefore, in Siete Infantes, had to die after giving birth to the seven princes in order that Busto de Lara may be free to marry the Moorish princess Hismena and make the hero legitimate. Illegitimacy is considered a stain on one’s character, so that all bastard heroes (Morada Gonzalo, Bernardo Carpio, and Rodrigo de Villas) had to be made legitimate. The religious nature of Filipinos infused the romances with a humane quality which was often lacking in their sources. In Baldovino, the cruelty of the punishment meted out to Carloto is greatly toned down. He is not sentenced to be dragged by wild horses, beheaded, and quartered, as in the Spanish ballad, but merely hanged and exposed to public view, after which monks come and bury him in the churchyard.

The Filipino fondness for allegorical and figurative language manifests itself in the romances. Morada Gonzalo in Siete Infantes presents his grievances before King Almanzor by speaking of a plant, the seven flowers of which have fallen prematurely because of treachery. But the traitor, he declares, has failed to uproot the plant and now its roots, having sprouted, will avenge the death of the seven flowers. In the romances, feasts are celebrated in characteristic Philippine fashion, with arches across every street, houses hung with damask, bands parading through the town, cannons booming, exhibition jousts or tournaments and games of all kinds ongoing, and the staging of the indispensable komedya, the theatrical spectacle depicting the wars between Christians and Moors, in which the Moors are inevitably defeated and converted to Catholicism. This last one presents a rather complex picture of the genre: a metrical romance (awit or korido) containing another genre (komedya) which in substance, in color, and in purpose resembles the art form in which it is contained, and which it possibly even influenced in the first place.

By the late 19th century, the metrical romance had become so much a part of the Philippine literary tradition that it produced a masterpiece that could be read as an expression of protest against the repressive character of Spanish rule, Francisco Baltazar’s Florante at Laura, written ca. 1838. Certainly passages abound in the poem that could be read as allegorical descriptions of Philippine social conditions of the time. Furthermore, Balagtas defied the Moro-versus-Christian stereotype that was a fixed convention of the genre by making his Moro characters, Aladin and Flerida, good people who come to the rescue of Florante and Laura. This awit had an impact on Jose Rizal and his generation, who read it as a nationalist tract. Belonging to this tradition of the metrical romance as political allegory is Sa Dakong Silangan (In the East), 1928, by Jose Corazon de Jesus. It continues the anticlerical theme begun by the Reformists of the Spanish colonial period, but focuses its attack on American colonialism. The characters’s allegorical names—Haring Felipo, Reyna Malaya, Haring lberio, Prinsipe Dolar, and Duke Democrito—signify the country’s transfer from the Spanish to the American colonial master. Through the character of the treacherous Prinsipe Dolar and the foreshadowing device of the eagle, this awit exposes the US government’s twin instruments of colonial rule: repression and capital.

The metrical romances reigned supreme for three centuries lasting up to the early part of the 20th century with some 300 of them circulated nationally. They lasted longer than that in the Ilonggo context: corridos were published by La Panayana as late as the 1960s (Locsin-Nava 2001, 42). The case seems to be true of the Ilocano metrical romance, too, as the existence of these works attests: Comedia a Biag ni Principe Atamante iti Reyno Verona (The Comedia of the Life of Prince Atamante in the Kingdom of Verona), 1958; Biag Daguiti Aggayyem D. Alejandre iti Reyno a Moscobia Quen ni D. Luis iti Reyno a Francia (Life of Two Friends Don Alejandre of the Kingdom of Moscow and Don Luis of the Kingdom of France), 1964; and Historia a Pacasaritaan ti Panagbiag ni Principe Jayme del Prado nga Anac da Ari D. Enrico (The Story of the Life of Prince Jayme del Prado, Son of King Enrico and Lady Isabela of the Kingdom of Hungary), 1964.
Alternative Metrical Romances

Like the Tagalog, the Ilonggo also used the metrical romances as an instrument against repressive colonial rule. However, where the Tagalog turned to political allegory, the Ilonggo turned to satire and parody, diverging from the traditional by violating expectations set by dominant conventions and ideologies. Thus, these works explode the standard concept of romance hero or heroine, tackle taboo subjects like defecation and abortion, invert power relationships, and expose oppressive binary oppositions like foreign/native, civilized/primitive, oppressor/oppressed, in which the powerless can triumph over the powerful.

Where typical romances feature attractive, fair, highborn and refined Caucasian protagonists from exotic kingdoms in Europe, Masadianga Vida ni Capiñahan cag ni Bulan-bulan sa Barrio nga Malapit sa Madyaas (The Happy Life of Capiñahan and Bulan-bulan in a Barrio near Madyaas), 1930, transgresses the social snobbery of the form by featuring Bulan-bulan as hero, a short, dark, ugly dimwitted young farmer from Sibalom, Antique, while the heroine is a lusty, sexually liberated Aeta from a barrio in Madyaas, who engineers her own wooing by slyly providing her suitor the answers to three riddling questions her father poses to enable him to win her hand.

Casimiro Perfecto’s Ang Lahog nga Pulos Milagro ni Cente cag ni Manong Tonio nga Bata sang Duha ca Babaye nga Pulos Francisca (The Joke Full of Miracles of Cente and Brother Tonio who are Children of Two Women Named Francisca) turns the saint’s life or vida into a picaresque tale. The prepubescent saints Vincent and Anthony are depicted as precocious rapscallions who play tricks on the mentors they dislike.

The anonymous Paghigugma-anay sang Pispis nga Bucao cag Maya, Pagcapatay si Punay Naman ang Nahagugma (The Love Affair of the Owl and the Maya; After Her Death Punay Supplanted Her as Love Object) parodies not only the romantic concept of everlasting love and its emotional extravagance but also romance literature’s pretentious erudition and linguistic bombast. An anthropomorphic, pompous, and sententious owl woos a maya in Hiligaynon heavily interlarded often with wrong Spanish terms, a practice among corrido writers that linguistic purist Serapion Torre satirized in his play Mga Anak ni Sisa (The Children of Sisa), 1926. A member of the reformist Academia Bisaya, an organization established by writers and journalists in 1901 to counteract the widespread adulteration of Hiligaynon with Spanish and English loan words, Torre coined terms like hatud-dulus for telegram, hunghungan for telephone, sakayan usbong for steamship, luthang paarak for machine gun in his search for the authentic Hiligaynon word (Locsin-Nava 2008, 61-62; Locsin-Nava 2001, 48-49) rather than use a foreign loan word.

Showing mastery of both form and content, Casimiro Perfecto in Masadia nga Vida ni Princesa Azucena nga anac ni Don Diego del Dia cag Dama de Noche sa Guinharian sang Florefortuna (Happy Life of Princess Azucena, Daughter of Don Diego del Dia and Dama de Noche, in the Kingdom of Florefortuna), 1926, mocks the authorial practice of killing off unimportant characters in a tale that puts a new spin to the romantic concept of dying for love. The poet abbreviates the death of 24 bridegrooms in four lines. Gimaya cag Calisud ni Liberato nga Villano nga Nagpangasawa cay Librada cag cay Princesa Estelita sang Reino sang Francia (Joy and Sorrow of the Villager Liberato who Married Librada and Princess Estelita of the Kingdom of France), 1930, draws the reader in as it mocks its own prolixity.

Such romances subvert form and content in the process of “writing back” to colonizers by standing conventions on their head. Ang Guintago nga Magayon nga Dalagang si Mileguas nga Napanga-sawa ni Principe Melindres sang Roncesvalles (The Kept Maiden Mileguas Whom Prince Melindres of Roncesvalles Married), 1915, turns the tables on our colonizers by satirizing the uselessness of the heroine’s Western education which fails to prevent her from getting pregnant on her first encounter with a man. Ang Nagsagad Caon Santo Inga Gintubol (The One Who Overate Santol and Got Constipated), 1918, satirizes the pernicious effects of American pragmatism with marriage contracts being informed by crass materialism and calculation.

Although studies on the metrical romance across regions (Burgos 1924; Carpio 1959; Ronquillo 1953; Gosioco 1974; Eugenio 1987) have focused exclusively on the traditional type, Lanuza’s case and the many translations into Bikol by the Perfectos show subversive corridos are not exclusive to Hiligaynon literature.

Unlike in other ethnolinguistic groups, corridos did not die out in the Ilonggo context. Rather, they got transformed into the composo. The composo (from the Spanish word composicion) is a ballad in dodecasyllabic lines sung to a preset melody (Tan 1981, 52). Tan’s contention that the Ilonggo’s desire for something shorter, more realistic, and easier to memorize may have motivated them to modify the Hiligaynon corrido into the composo bears some thought in view of two hybrid corridos that capture this transition: one described by its author Nemesio Ledesma as novela nga binalaybay (novel in verse) titled Si Valing cag si Minong, based on a real-life domestic tragedy that gave rise to a composo by the same title; and Ang Cabuhini Pedro Tabios cag ni Manuela Lilay sa Imperiong Roma (The Life of Pedro Tabios and Manuela Lilay in Imperial Rome), 1912, where instead of the standard address to the reader or opening prayer, the corrido plunges straight into Pedro Tabios’s story by identifying the character and the setting very much in the manner of the composo.

Dismissed by critics like Pardo de Tavera and Leopoldo Yabes as “lengthy, exaggerated, puerile, absurd in the extreme” and “outlandish,” the metrical romances have been rescued from ignominy by scholars like Resil Mojares, who describes them as the vehicle by which the aesthetic tendency in the novel came into greater play. Probably the most influential of all foreign literary genres introduced by our colonizers whose impact transcends their literary importance, the metrical romances have shaped not only our tastes but also Philippine attitudes and worldview. Proof of their durability is the tenacity with which komedya, its dramatic counterpart, has survived not only in depressed backwoods like Barangay San Antonio, Barbaza, Antique, but in the eternal love triangle, black-and-white characters, and overelaborate plotlines (Reyes 1994, 26-31) that characterized vernacular novels serialized in weekly publications like Hiligaynon and Bisaya and continue to inform Philippine formula films and soap operas today.
Written by Damiana Eugenio,

The term “new media” was originally used by practitioners of advertising, marketing, and market research to distinguish online content and social interactions from that of traditional media: print, radio, and television. New media consists of digital content, usually uploaded or accessed online or over a network. Examples of these are online blogs, websites, smartphone or mobile-friendly apps, social media networks, streaming videos, interactive web content, and so on. Compared to traditional media, new media is characterized by a more fluid and real-time interaction between creator and audience.

The flexibility of new media provides a platform for both writers and readers to interact in the creation and assessment of works and to find new and innovative ways of experimenting and playing around with form and genres. This quality of new media also affects the traditionally linear structure of institutions involved in the production and dissemination of literary works, including the academe, booksellers, and publishing houses. For instance, a writer can bypass the print publishing hierarchy and make their manuscripts available online, to be purchased or downloaded as e-books, where they have control over the marketing and availability of their works.

The phenomenon of new media in the Philippines is intertwined with the history of the Internet in the country. The first public access bulletin board system was established in Aug 1986, the precursor to the contemporary online message boards and forums. E-mail gateways and services became subsequently available in 1991, and on 29 Mar 1994 at 1:15 am, Benjie Tan became the first Filipino to access the Internet.

By 1997, there were approximately 85,500 Internet users in the Philippines. Media conglomerates ABS-CBN and GMA Network launched their official websites, as did the newspapers Business World, Manila Bulletin, Philippine Star, Manila Times, and Philippine Daily Inquirer. By August, there were over 1,090 registered Philippine domain names on the World Wide Web. By 2014, there were over 41 million Internet users in the country, or about 41 percent of the population, even if domestic Internet service is the slowest and most expensive in the region. The ensuing rise in mobile Internet usage further connected Filipinos online.

Alongside that of the World Wide Web, cellphone usage experienced a rise. In 1991, Piltel, a subsidiary of PLDT, became the first telecommunications company to provide cellular phone network support in the Philippines. SMS, or short message service, was introduced in 1994. Unlike the Internet’s dependence on a desktop computer and phone lines to connect to the World Wide Web, the cell phone allowed people to communicate on the go. With the advent of the smartphone in late 2010 to early 2011, the Internet finally arrived in the hands of the cell phone user.

The first attempt to bring literary writing to a digital platform was the “textula,” which as its name implies, is a poem, or tula, circulated by text messaging. Director and playwright Frank Rivera is said to be the first to use the cell phone as a platform for his poetry, in 2005. His texted poems were “read in political rallies, forwarded, read on radio, posted on social media, printed in tabloid and newspaper columns, recited in school programs and utilized as material in oratorical and declamation contests” (Tariman 2013).

The Filipinas Institute of Translation Inc, along with the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), the University of the Philippines Institute of Creative Writing (UP ICW), and the Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas, instituted a contest that encouraged participants to write traditional Filipino poetic forms, such as tanaga, dalit, and diona, using their cellphones and sending their works to the institution’s contest phone number. The winning entries were compiled and published as Textanaga, 2003; Dalitext, 2003; and Dionatext, 2004. The annual competition, which began in 2003, ended in 2008.

 

Another early adaptor of digital storytelling platforms is writer and visual artist Adam David, with his website Project Crumbs, with Indira Endaya. Launched in 2008, the now-defunct website used text and images to tell the story of 20-somethings trying to find meaning in their lives. Project Crumbs offered an interactive and collaborative way of reading. Its use of hypertext and hyperlink enabled users to customize the way they experienced the website. These links allowed the weaving of different kinds of stories depending on a randomized algorithm of words and images created by David and Endaya (Gonzales 2009, 207-8).

The difference between this “hypertext paradigm” and the “print paradigm” has been noted by Gonzales in his examination of Project Crumbs. Print-based forms are linear, bordered, and univocal, while hypertext narratives can potentially be scattered, borderless, and polyphonic (208-9). That the project existed only on the World Wide Web and not on paper also gave the creators the freedom to expand the story infinitely and in multiple directions.

Arguably, the group that best exploited the new media early on was comic book writers and artists. Using free web publishing services such as Blogspot and LiveJournal onto which they uploaded their webcomics, they widened their reach, with many of the works eventually getting compiled and printed.

Among the early creators of webcomics was Tobie Abad, whose Diliman Diaries (dilimancomics.blogspot.com) details the adventures of “salamangka, aswangs, and the magic, politics, and drama of human relationships” (Abad 2011). The webcomic series ran from 2005 to 2011 with 15 issues. A digital compilation of Diliman Diaries, in CD format, was sold at the Philippine Komiks Convention (Komikon) in 2011.

 

Trese by Budjette Tan and Kajo Baldisimo also began online. The archives of Trese (tresekomix.blogspot.com) go back as far as Dec 2005. It was first published simultaneously online and in zine format by Alamat Comics. In 2008, the first 13 issues were compiled and repackaged into three volumes by Visprint Enterprises: Trese: Murder at Balete Drive, Trese: Unreported Murders, and Trese: Mass Murders. In 2010, the third compilation received the National Book Award for Best Graphic Literature. The fourth volume, Trese: Last Seen After Midnight, won the same award in 2012. The Trese website is now used for, among other things, posting the authors’ works in progress.

In 2010, comic book creator Mervin Malonzo came out with Tabi Po (www.tabi-po.com), a reimagining of the gentrified Hispanic society based on Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1887. The work is told from the point of view of newborn aswang Elias. Malonzo intends his work to be a reworking of Philippine aswang lore by interweaving folklore and Catholic elements. Originally in Filipino, the series was translated into English. A print version of the first few issues was issued as Tabi Po: Book 1 in 2014.

 

While popular webcomics, many of them using Philippine mythological creatures, have periodically been printed, comic strips have conversely found their way online. Manix Abrera’s Kikomachine, which details humorous students’ lives, began as a newspaper comic strip before it landed on an online platform www.kikomachinekomix.com. These strips have been collected into 10 Kikomachine volumes. Aside from Kikomachine, Abrera also has a regular online comic strip called News Hardcore featured exclusively on GMA Network’s website.

Like Abrera, Pol Medina Jr moved from print to online media. His Pugad Baboy comic strips began in the Philippine Daily Inquirer in 1988 and regularly compiled into volumes, but his employment with the Inquirer was discontinued in Jun 2013. He now publishes exclusively online on Rappler.

Emiliana Kampilan’s Dead Balagtas series is published exclusively through the artist’s Facebook and Tumblr pages. Beginning Oct 2013, Dead Balagtas is structured as a “today in history” update, the strips focusing on a monthly or weekly theme, depending on pertinent historical events or holidays.

 

Aside from these creators, there are now individuals and organizations using the Internet as a platform for publication and distribution of creative content. The digital media publishing platform is used three ways, though overlaps are visible: academic, commercial, and independent or indie publishing.

Academic digital platforms include electronic-accessed academic journals and information portals hosted and maintained by academic institutions and serve mostly an academic audience. Commercial digital platforms are those that use digital media to produce, market, and distribute electronic books, or e-books, in much the same way physical bookstores use their space to display and market print books. Independent publishers include individuals or small groups that upload their content using free services or websites, and cultivate their own audiences in order to increase e-book sales.

All three types of users rely on two important things: one, that the reader has a device through which they can access the digital content, and two, that the reader is connected, in some way or form, to the internet. Except in the case of some online services that require users to read content on-site while connected, downloaded e-books can be read off-line, sometimes via the apps or software developed by the same distributor.

Since the beginning of the second millennium, academic institutions have been using digital publishing in order to widen the reach of its publications. In Philippine basic education alone, the use and distribution of e-textbooks were four times higher in 2014 than in 2012, the baseline distribution year (de Peralta 2014). There are also university and school presses that cater exclusively to the captured school markets—namely, Salesian Books by Don Bosco Press, Phoenix Publishing House, and Diwa Learning Town (de Peralta 2014). These presses still produce print textbooks but provide an option for digital versions that students can read on their devices. A number of university presses also sell e-books through digital publishing platforms.

Another trend in academic publishing is the transition of journals from print to digital. This allows the journals to be accessed by more readers and researchers whether in the Philippines or beyond. In particular, two journals have led this trend: Ateneo de Manila University’s Kritika Kultura and University of the Philippines’s Likhaan: Journal of Contemporary Philippine Literature. Established in 2002 as an online journal, the first of its kind in the Philippines, Kritika Kultura publishes critical essays in language, literary, and cultural studies, and carries a literary section.

Likhaan: Journal of Contemporary Philippine Literature, under the auspices of Likhaan: UP Creative Writing Center (now Likhaan: UP Institute of Creative Writing) and the University of the Philippines Press, began in 1995 as an annual of the best published works. Since 2007, when it made the transition to digital, it has been an annual journal of unpublished works. The print copy is exclusively distributed to the contributors, while the digital copy is accessible for free through the institute’s website.

Panitikan.com.ph was put up in 2006 as a resource for literary news, announcements, and calendar of events as well as a Philippine writers’ portal. A project of the UP ICW and the NCCA, the website likewise aims to disseminate Philippine literature online by providing a database of authors' profiles and their works. Its other features, like the writers market and monthly calendar of activities, seek to stimulate literary interest. It also houses exclusive content that concerns writers: features on various concerns such as freelance writing, writing workshops, independent publishing, small book presses, as well as the state of various literary genres and languages in the Philippines.

In 2002, Dumaguete-based writer Ian Rosales Casocot began to maintain a website called A Critical Survey of Philippine Literature, an offshoot of his literature class readings at Silliman University, which archives short stories, poems, novel excerpts,dramas, films, essays and creative nonfiction by Filipino writers whether in the Philippines or abroad (Casocot n.d.).

Commercial digital publishers make their books available for public consumptions with a fee, usually similar to purchasing a print book in a physical bookstore. In the Philippines, there are already a handful of commercial digital publishers and distributors. At the forefront of this movement is Flipside Publishing Services Inc (FPSI), the parent company of Flipreads, the first e-bookstore in the Philippines.

Flipside was established in 2011. It began by carrying digital versions of print books, mainly educational books and titles from university presses. Flipside now also publishes exclusive digital content available through its own online bookstore, as well as through Amazon.com, the largest e-book retailer in the world. It also secured approval from Apple as a service provider for the official iBook app, the default e-book reader on all Apple mobile products. FPSI has also pioneered the Philippine Educational E-Book Reader or PEER system for education e-books, becoming a distribution platform for university presses and K-12 textbooks used by schools, colleges, and universities migrating their educational content from print to digital.

Another company that offers Filipino e-book titles is buqo. The company behind buqo, Hand.Interactive, promotes exclusive Filipino content on its digital publishing platform. The platform may be accessed online and may be installed as a mobile app on any Apple product. Launched in Feb 2014, buqo was intended to be a one-stop shop for digital content specifically for Filipino readers, although anyone with an Internet connection can access it. Aside from partnering with local publishers looking for a way to adapt print content for digital publication, buqo also offers pro bono services for self-published writers who are looking to sell their manuscripts to the e-book market. This arrangement allows cheaper production costs on the part of the writer as well as larger sales margins for both writer and distributor.

Unlike Flipside and buqo, the website Storylark.ph serves exclusively comics creators in the Philippines looking to sell their work online. While both Flipside and buqo provide in-house services to convert and market various manuscripts for digital readership, Storylark describes itself as a “digital comics distribution service” (2014) that allows readers to access independent comics on-site for a small fee. Many of the comics on their site, such as Para Fierra by Fidelis Tan and Kiko Dans, and Manosaur by Elbert Or, first made the rounds as physical printed zines peddled during the biannual Komikon.

Children’s book publisher Adarna House has also transitioned from print to new media with Adarna Digital, which specializes in creating interactive storybook applications, or apps. This was piloted in 2014 using two children’s books—namely, That Won’t Make Me Sleep by Annie Pacaña-Lumbao and Araw sa Palengke (Day at the Market) by May Tobias-Papa. A third title, Raquel’s Magnificent Hair by Luis Gatmaitan, was recently launched in 2015. All of these titles started as print books before being adapted as interactive story media.

The growth of these commercial digital publishing and distribution platforms aims to address the growing number of digital readers in the Philippines. At least 30 percent of the Philippine population accesses information online and through mobile networks, a fact that has pushed traditional print publications such as broadsheets, magazines, and book publishers to make the leap from print to digital as well (IMMAP 2014).

Although both academic and commercial booksellers and developers have benefited greatly from the rise of digital publication and distribution, one of the biggest beneficiaries on the digital publication front is independent writers and creators.

Independent digital literary publication in the Philippines can be traced back to NaNoWriMo, or National Novel Writing Month, an online writing challenge that started in 1999 in the San Francisco Bay Area. During NaNoWriMo, participants are challenged to write a 50,000-word novel in one month. This challenge has expanded and grown in the last decade and a half, welcoming participants from all over the world. Aspiring participants only need to register on the NaNoWriMo website, after which they can begin posting chapters online and keeping track of their word count. The first draft of Dean Francis Alfar’s Salamanca, 2006, which won the Carlos Palanca grand prize for the novel in 2005 and which was subsequently published as a print book under Anvil Publishing, was completed as a NaNoWriMo challenge the year before.

Another avenue for self-publication is through blogs. The term “blog,” which gained traction in 1999, comes from the words “web” and “log.” Many writers who found legitimacy in print, such as Jessica Zafra and Lourd de Veyra, became active writers online. Zafra currently writes a weekly column for InterAksyon, the online news website for TV5. De Veyra also writes a regular column, This Is a Crazy Planets, for Spot.PH. In an interesting inversion, several essays from de Veyra’s online column were compiled and published as a collection of essays with the same name in 2011.

Digital publishing has also opened up the avenues for collaborative storytelling, similar to the idea behind David’s and Endaya’s Project Crumbs. Twitter, a microblogging site that allows users to post up to 140-character public messages has been the favored site for very short fiction known as microfic or Twitterfic, or collaborative fiction writing. One of the most popular annual collaborative writing events in the Philippines is #RP612fic, in which contributors can post tweet-length stories often premised on a certain historical occasion, like Independence Day on 12 Jun. Sometimes humorous, hilarious, obscene, or incredible, it presents a snapshot of Philippine popular culture as filtered through the lens of social media. Since 2009, Filipino writers and Twitter users have participated in this annual event.

Some contemporary writers in the Philippines transition back and forth seamlessly from print to digital and back again. Authors such as genre writer Eliza Victoria and Mina V. Esguerra, a noted writer of new adult and young adult novels, have both published books in print, as well as online. Paolo Chikiamko, the controlling force behind #RP612fic, published his Mythspace series of comics both as zines and online, finally compiling them in a print anthology and releasing them under Visprint, an established publishing company.

 

Similarly, the annual anthology Philippine Speculative Fiction series, helmed by Alfar and a rotating roster of editors from his writing group, the LitCritters, began as a print publication from volumes one to five, before going digital from six onward. However, The Best of Philippine Speculative Fiction, 2005-2010, 2013, was published by the University of the Philippines Press, an esteemed academic publishing house.

While blogging is a largely independent activity, community writing has also gained a foothold in the world of Philippine digital content creation. WattPad, a community writing and reading platform, was launched in Nov 2006 as a mobile app, allowing users with smartphones and other digital reading devices to download and read content written by their peers. Like the community of writers participating in NaNoWriMo, WattPad allows both unpublished and published writers to upload original and derivative works, such as fan fiction, on the site, as well as receive comments from readers. The site is free-to-use and the content is free-to-read. Many of the stories are serialized, and their writers derive from popular tropes and genres found within fan fiction and other fan-based transformative works.

WattPad first partnered with Project Gutenberg to provide access to over 15,000 titles in the Gutenberg archives for a mobile phone-reading public, but it was only when the site began allowing users to upload original content that the community began to expand. After the United States, the Philippines was the second-biggest user of WattPad in 2014.

The success of WattPad writers has transitioned off-line. Summit Media, in partnership with WattPad, has published WattPad stories in print formats through its Pop Fiction Books imprint. In 2013, it published 20 titles from WattPad. Ten more stories were optioned for publication starting in May 2014. By 2014, over a hundred WattPad stories have been published as books.

Compared to other printed works by local authors, the novels are designed to appeal to young readers, with the covers using bright colors and manga-inspired illustrations to draw potential buyers’ attention to the shelves. The price point is also appealing to young readers, with most books in the 100-200 peso range. For these reasons, WattPad-sourced novels are best sellers in local bookstores.

Bianca Bernardino’s She’s Dating the Gangster, 2013, became the primary example of a WattPad success story. The story was first serialized in Candy Magazine before the author shifted to WattPad. It was finally published as a book by Summit Media, and had sold 30,000 copies by the end of 2013. It was adapted into a commercially successful movie with the same title the following year. Another WattPad novel that found success both online and off-line is Aly Almario’s Operation: Break the Casanova’s Heart. Also printed under Summit Media, Almario’s novel was also optioned for film rights.

 

PSICOM Publishing is a rival of Summit Media in turning WattPad stories to print. Its Diary ng Panget (Diary of an Ugly), 2013, whose writer uses the pseudonym HaveYouSeenThisGirL, is a comparable feat. It was adapted into a hit movie in Apr 2014.

WattPad authors have a very strong online presence. For instance, Bernardino’s She’s Dating the Gangster was read over 1.1 million times on WattPad. Marcelo Santos III, author of Para sa Broken Hearted (For the Brokenhearted) and Para sa Hopeless Romantic (For the Hopeless Romantic), also began on WattPad and turned into a social media celebrity with over 4.1 million page likes on Facebook and over 111,000 followers on Instagram.

 

The success of WattPad has also resulted in television adaptations. In Sep 2014, TV5 started the series WattPad Presents, which as its title suggests, sources its episodes from WattPad at a rate of one book per week.

Aside from WattPad, digital self-publication is another alternative platform for indie writers. Esguerra has taken advantage of Amazon.com’s current system of uploading e-books to the international Amazon webpage, enabling her to bypass the need for agents and publishers. Amazon Kindle Direct Publishing allows authors like Esguerra to digitally upload their books to Amazon’s online marketplace, allowing readers from anywhere in the world to access their works.

Aside from social media sites, a new crop of storytelling websites has emerged to allow writers to experiment with collaborative storytelling. One of these websites is Twine, which allows for the reader to participate in the story as it unfolds on the screen. Eliza Victoria uploaded her horror story “The Glass Jar” on Twine as a writing experiment in 2014. It follows the exchange between a killer and his victim, with the reader participating in the unfolding of the narrative similar to the old Choose Your Own Adventure books.

New media has allowed individual authors to disrupt the traditional model of local print publishing and promote a democratization of production and consumption. By eschewing the middleman, so to speak, writers are able to publish independently, and materials that traditional publishers would have ignored or set aside now have an outlet that is relatively inexpensive and easy to manage. Writers can potentially reach more readers than in traditional media. Meanwhile, readers are able to read what they want to read when they want to as long as they have their devices at hand. They are also able to make the transition from different storytelling platforms—online, print, television, film—and follow their favorite stories throughout their different incarnations.

The situation, however, has created new issues. Bypassing editorial gatekeeping, peer review, and quality control measures that traditional publishing houses follow, new media has allowed the circulation and legitimation of substandard works or even editorial practice. The crop of new writers, such as Bernardino, Almario, and Santos, and many other writers who used WattPad as their primary platform for their stories receive very little or no input from the publishers when their works are committed to print. Thus, these online-to-print novels have a “what you see is what you get” quality.

This path also allows aspiring writers to sidestep the normal process espoused by the so-called literary community. Academic creative writing programs and national writing workshops, sponsored by various Philippine educational and cultural institutions, espouse certain aesthetics and styles of writing that are deemed “literary,” in addition to training and mentorship regimens. Thus, the question of literariness becomes tied up with the question of literary production. The latest development in this debate came in 2015 when a 20-year-old Wattpad writer, Charmaine Mercader Lasar, won the Palanca grand prize for the novel in Filipino for her 33,000-word novel manuscript “Toto O.” It blurred the divide between so-called literary and popular literature even more.

With new technologies regularly being developed, there will always be new ways of telling and distributing and reading stories from Filipino authors.  Written by Gabriela Lee

article.value: While popular webcomics, many of them using Philippine mythological creatures, have periodically been printed, comic strips have conversely found their way online. Manix Abrera’s Kikomachine, which details humorous students’ lives, began as a newspaper comic strip before it landed on an online platform www.kikomachinekomix.com. These strips have been collected into 10 Kikomachine volumes. Aside from Kikomachine, Abrera also has a regular online comic strip called News Hardcore featured exclusively on GMA Network’s website.

Like Abrera, Pol Medina Jr moved from print to online media. His Pugad Baboy comic strips began in the Philippine Daily Inquirer in 1988 and regularly compiled into volumes, but his employment with the Inquirer was discontinued in Jun 2013. He now publishes exclusively online on Rappler.

Emiliana Kampilan’s Dead Balagtas series is published exclusively through the artist’s Facebook and Tumblr pages. Beginning Oct 2013, Dead Balagtas is structured as a “today in history” update, the strips focusing on a monthly or weekly theme, depending on pertinent historical events or holidays.

Aside from these creators, there are now individuals and organizations using the Internet as a platform for publication and distribution of creative content. The digital media publishing platform is used three ways, though overlaps are visible: academic, commercial, and independent or indie publishing.

Academic digital platforms include electronic-accessed academic journals and information portals hosted and maintained by academic institutions and serve mostly an academic audience. Commercial digital platforms are those that use digital media to produce, market, and distribute electronic books, or e-books, in much the same way physical bookstores use their space to display and market print books. Independent publishers include individuals or small groups that upload their content using free services or websites, and cultivate their own audiences in order to increase e-book sales.

All three types of users rely on two important things: one, that the reader has a device through which they can access the digital content, and two, that the reader is connected, in some way or form, to the internet. Except in the case of some online services that require users to read content on-site while connected, downloaded e-books can be read off-line, sometimes via the apps or software developed by the same distributor.

Since the beginning of the second millennium, academic institutions have been using digital publishing in order to widen the reach of its publications. In Philippine basic education alone, the use and distribution of e-textbooks were four times higher in 2014 than in 2012, the baseline distribution year (de Peralta 2014). There are also university and school presses that cater exclusively to the captured school markets—namely, Salesian Books by Don Bosco Press, Phoenix Publishing House, and Diwa Learning Town (de Peralta 2014). These presses still produce print textbooks but provide an option for digital versions that students can read on their devices. A number of university presses also sell e-books through digital publishing platforms.

Another trend in academic publishing is the transition of journals from print to digital. This allows the journals to be accessed by more readers and researchers whether in the Philippines or beyond. In particular, two journals have led this trend: Ateneo de Manila University’s Kritika Kultura and University of the Philippines’s Likhaan: Journal of Contemporary Philippine Literature. Established in 2002 as an online journal, the first of its kind in the Philippines, Kritika Kultura publishes critical essays in language, literary, and cultural studies, and carries a literary section.

Likhaan: Journal of Contemporary Philippine Literature, under the auspices of Likhaan: UP Creative Writing Center (now Likhaan: UP Institute of Creative Writing) and the University of the Philippines Press, began in 1995 as an annual of the best published works. Since 2007, when it made the transition to digital, it has been an annual journal of unpublished works. The print copy is exclusively distributed to the contributors, while the digital copy is accessible for free through the institute’s website.

Panitikan.com.ph was put up in 2006 as a resource for literary news, announcements, and calendar of events as well as a Philippine writers’ portal. A project of the UP ICW and the NCCA, the website likewise aims to disseminate Philippine literature online by providing a database of authors' profiles and their works. Its other features, like the writers market and monthly calendar of activities, seek to stimulate literary interest. It also houses exclusive content that concerns writers: features on various concerns such as freelance writing, writing workshops, independent publishing, small book presses, as well as the state of various literary genres and languages in the Philippines.

In 2002, Dumaguete-based writer Ian Rosales Casocot began to maintain a website called A Critical Survey of Philippine Literature, an offshoot of his literature class readings at Silliman University, which archives short stories, poems, novel excerpts,dramas, films, essays and creative nonfiction by Filipino writers whether in the Philippines or abroad (Casocot n.d.).

Commercial digital publishers make their books available for public consumptions with a fee, usually similar to purchasing a print book in a physical bookstore. In the Philippines, there are already a handful of commercial digital publishers and distributors. At the forefront of this movement is Flipside Publishing Services Inc (FPSI), the parent company of Flipreads, the first e-bookstore in the Philippines.

Flipside was established in 2011. It began by carrying digital versions of print books, mainly educational books and titles from university presses. Flipside now also publishes exclusive digital content available through its own online bookstore, as well as through Amazon.com, the largest e-book retailer in the world. It also secured approval from Apple as a service provider for the official iBook app, the default e-book reader on all Apple mobile products. FPSI has also pioneered the Philippine Educational E-Book Reader or PEER system for education e-books, becoming a distribution platform for university presses and K-12 textbooks used by schools, colleges, and universities migrating their educational content from print to digital.

Another company that offers Filipino e-book titles is buqo. The company behind buqo, Hand.Interactive, promotes exclusive Filipino content on its digital publishing platform. The platform may be accessed online and may be installed as a mobile app on any Apple product. Launched in Feb 2014, buqo was intended to be a one-stop shop for digital content specifically for Filipino readers, although anyone with an Internet connection can access it. Aside from partnering with local publishers looking for a way to adapt print content for digital publication, buqo also offers pro bono services for self-published writers who are looking to sell their manuscripts to the e-book market. This arrangement allows cheaper production costs on the part of the writer as well as larger sales margins for both writer and distributor.

Unlike Flipside and buqo, the website Storylark.ph serves exclusively comics creators in the Philippines looking to sell their work online. While both Flipside and buqo provide in-house services to convert and market various manuscripts for digital readership, Storylark describes itself as a “digital comics distribution service” (2014) that allows readers to access independent comics on-site for a small fee. Many of the comics on their site, such as Para Fierra by Fidelis Tan and Kiko Dans, and Manosaur by Elbert Or, first made the rounds as physical printed zines peddled during the biannual Komikon.

Children’s book publisher Adarna House has also transitioned from print to new media with Adarna Digital, which specializes in creating interactive storybook applications, or apps. This was piloted in 2014 using two children’s books—namely, That Won’t Make Me Sleep by Annie Pacaña-Lumbao and Araw sa Palengke (Day at the Market) by May Tobias-Papa. A third title, Raquel’s Magnificent Hair by Luis Gatmaitan, was recently launched in 2015. All of these titles started as print books before being adapted as interactive story media.

The growth of these commercial digital publishing and distribution platforms aims to address the growing number of digital readers in the Philippines. At least 30 percent of the Philippine population accesses information online and through mobile networks, a fact that has pushed traditional print publications such as broadsheets, magazines, and book publishers to make the leap from print to digital as well (IMMAP 2014).

Although both academic and commercial booksellers and developers have benefited greatly from the rise of digital publication and distribution, one of the biggest beneficiaries on the digital publication front is independent writers and creators.

Independent digital literary publication in the Philippines can be traced back to NaNoWriMo, or National Novel Writing Month, an online writing challenge that started in 1999 in the San Francisco Bay Area. During NaNoWriMo, participants are challenged to write a 50,000-word novel in one month. This challenge has expanded and grown in the last decade and a half, welcoming participants from all over the world. Aspiring participants only need to register on the NaNoWriMo website, after which they can begin posting chapters online and keeping track of their word count. The first draft of Dean Francis Alfar’s Salamanca, 2006, which won the Carlos Palanca grand prize for the novel in 2005 and which was subsequently published as a print book under Anvil Publishing, was completed as a NaNoWriMo challenge the year before.

Another avenue for self-publication is through blogs. The term “blog,” which gained traction in 1999, comes from the words “web” and “log.” Many writers who found legitimacy in print, such as Jessica Zafra and Lourd de Veyra, became active writers online. Zafra currently writes a weekly column for InterAksyon, the online news website for TV5. De Veyra also writes a regular column, This Is a Crazy Planets, for Spot.PH. In an interesting inversion, several essays from de Veyra’s online column were compiled and published as a collection of essays with the same name in 2011.

Digital publishing has also opened up the avenues for collaborative storytelling, similar to the idea behind David’s and Endaya’s Project Crumbs. Twitter, a microblogging site that allows users to post up to 140-character public messages has been the favored site for very short fiction known as microfic or Twitterfic, or collaborative fiction writing. One of the most popular annual collaborative writing events in the Philippines is #RP612fic, in which contributors can post tweet-length stories often premised on a certain historical occasion, like Independence Day on 12 Jun. Sometimes humorous, hilarious, obscene, or incredible, it presents a snapshot of Philippine popular culture as filtered through the lens of social media. Since 2009, Filipino writers and Twitter users have participated in this annual event.

Some contemporary writers in the Philippines transition back and forth seamlessly from print to digital and back again. Authors such as genre writer Eliza Victoria and Mina V. Esguerra, a noted writer of new adult and young adult novels, have both published books in print, as well as online. Paolo Chikiamko, the controlling force behind #RP612fic, published his Mythspace series of comics both as zines and online, finally compiling them in a print anthology and releasing them under Visprint, an established publishing company.

Similarly, the annual anthology Philippine Speculative Fiction series, helmed by Alfar and a rotating roster of editors from his writing group, the LitCritters, began as a print publication from volumes one to five, before going digital from six onward. However, The Best of Philippine Speculative Fiction, 2005-2010, 2013, was published by the University of the Philippines Press, an esteemed academic publishing house.

While blogging is a largely independent activity, community writing has also gained a foothold in the world of Philippine digital content creation. WattPad, a community writing and reading platform, was launched in Nov 2006 as a mobile app, allowing users with smartphones and other digital reading devices to download and read content written by their peers. Like the community of writers participating in NaNoWriMo, WattPad allows both unpublished and published writers to upload original and derivative works, such as fan fiction, on the site, as well as receive comments from readers. The site is free-to-use and the content is free-to-read. Many of the stories are serialized, and their writers derive from popular tropes and genres found within fan fiction and other fan-based transformative works.

WattPad first partnered with Project Gutenberg to provide access to over 15,000 titles in the Gutenberg archives for a mobile phone-reading public, but it was only when the site began allowing users to upload original content that the community began to expand. After the United States, the Philippines was the second-biggest user of WattPad in 2014.

The success of WattPad writers has transitioned off-line. Summit Media, in partnership with WattPad, has published WattPad stories in print formats through its Pop Fiction Books imprint. In 2013, it published 20 titles from WattPad. Ten more stories were optioned for publication starting in May 2014. By 2014, over a hundred WattPad stories have been published as books.

Compared to other printed works by local authors, the novels are designed to appeal to young readers, with the covers using bright colors and manga-inspired illustrations to draw potential buyers’ attention to the shelves. The price point is also appealing to young readers, with most books in the 100-200 peso range. For these reasons, WattPad-sourced novels are best sellers in local bookstores.

Bianca Bernardino’s She’s Dating the Gangster, 2013, became the primary example of a WattPad success story. The story was first serialized in Candy Magazine before the author shifted to WattPad. It was finally published as a book by Summit Media, and had sold 30,000 copies by the end of 2013. It was adapted into a commercially successful movie with the same title the following year. Another WattPad novel that found success both online and off-line is Aly Almario’s Operation: Break the Casanova’s Heart. Also printed under Summit Media, Almario’s novel was also optioned for film rights.

PSICOM Publishing is a rival of Summit Media in turning WattPad stories to print. Its Diary ng Panget (Diary of an Ugly), 2013, whose writer uses the pseudonym HaveYouSeenThisGirL, is a comparable feat. It was adapted into a hit movie in Apr 2014.

WattPad authors have a very strong online presence. For instance, Bernardino’s She’s Dating the Gangster was read over 1.1 million times on WattPad. Marcelo Santos III, author of Para sa Broken Hearted (For the Brokenhearted) and Para sa Hopeless Romantic (For the Hopeless Romantic), also began on WattPad and turned into a social media celebrity with over 4.1 million page likes on Facebook and over 111,000 followers on Instagram.

The success of WattPad has also resulted in television adaptations. In Sep 2014, TV5 started the series WattPad Presents, which as its title suggests, sources its episodes from WattPad at a rate of one book per week.

Aside from WattPad, digital self-publication is another alternative platform for indie writers. Esguerra has taken advantage of Amazon.com’s current system of uploading e-books to the international Amazon webpage, enabling her to bypass the need for agents and publishers. Amazon Kindle Direct Publishing allows authors like Esguerra to digitally upload their books to Amazon’s online marketplace, allowing readers from anywhere in the world to access their works.

Aside from social media sites, a new crop of storytelling websites has emerged to allow writers to experiment with collaborative storytelling. One of these websites is Twine, which allows for the reader to participate in the story as it unfolds on the screen. Eliza Victoria uploaded her horror story “The Glass Jar” on Twine as a writing experiment in 2014. It follows the exchange between a killer and his victim, with the reader participating in the unfolding of the narrative similar to the old Choose Your Own Adventure books.

New media has allowed individual authors to disrupt the traditional model of local print publishing and promote a democratization of production and consumption. By eschewing the middleman, so to speak, writers are able to publish independently, and materials that traditional publishers would have ignored or set aside now have an outlet that is relatively inexpensive and easy to manage. Writers can potentially reach more readers than in traditional media. Meanwhile, readers are able to read what they want to read when they want to as long as they have their devices at hand. They are also able to make the transition from different storytelling platforms—online, print, television, film—and follow their favorite stories throughout their different incarnations.

The situation, however, has created new issues. Bypassing editorial gatekeeping, peer review, and quality control measures that traditional publishing houses follow, new media has allowed the circulation and legitimation of substandard works or even editorial practice. The crop of new writers, such as Bernardino, Almario, and Santos, and many other writers who used WattPad as their primary platform for their stories receive very little or no input from the publishers when their works are committed to print. Thus, these online-to-print novels have a “what you see is what you get” quality.

This path also allows aspiring writers to sidestep the normal process espoused by the so-called literary community. Academic creative writing programs and national writing workshops, sponsored by various Philippine educational and cultural institutions, espouse certain aesthetics and styles of writing that are deemed “literary,” in addition to training and mentorship regimens. Thus, the question of literariness becomes tied up with the question of literary production. The latest development in this debate came in 2015 when a 20-year-old Wattpad writer, Charmaine Mercader Lasar, won the Palanca grand prize for the novel in Filipino for her 33,000-word novel manuscript “Toto O.” It blurred the divide between so-called literary and popular literature even more.
With new technologies regularly being developed, there will always be new ways of telling and distributing and reading stories from Filipino authors.
Written by Gabriela Lee
